Alexander’s jaw tightened with resolve. "Regardless, Victoria has already chosen to marry Nathaniel and will remain in Bern City. The distance between them is vast enough that bringing Evelyn home wouldn’t disrupt anything."

His voice dropped lower, firm. "Besides, Victoria is marrying into the Whitmore dynasty. It’s not as if we’re abandoning her."

Olivia arched a delicate brow. "Terminate Victoria’s adoption? Do you honestly think she’d agree to that?"

Evelyn’s rise from an orphanage to her current status was nothing short of extraordinary—something most could never comprehend. And truthfully, Olivia had never warmed to Victoria.

Alexander’s expression darkened. "I won’t let Evelyn suffer another injustice. When the time comes, I’ll ensure Victoria receives a fair settlement—assets, not empty promises."

His tone softened slightly. "It’ll be an amicable separation. I’ve upheld our agreement with her. There’s no betrayal here."

The next morning, Evelyn returned to work at the studio, slipping back into routine.

Before long, two colleagues approached, each holding a small pastry box.

"Evelyn, we owe you an apology," the first murmured, guilt flickering in her eyes. "Cassandra misled us."

The second extended her offering. "Please accept these as a peace offering."

Evelyn recognized the influence Cassandra Blake had wielded over them. With a gracious nod, she accepted the gifts. Holding grudges served no purpose—professionalism mattered more.

Then Natalie rushed in, breathless. "Evelyn, you have a visitor. It’s that woman who confronted Cassandra last time."

A tense silence settled over the studio.

Evelyn hadn’t expected Genevieve Stewart to seek her out. Had Cassandra spread more lies?

As Evelyn stood, Genevieve strode forward—but this time, her usual arrogance was absent. Dark circles shadowed her eyes, her posture weary.

Keeping her voice steady, Evelyn asked, "What brings you here?"

Without warning, Genevieve dropped to her knees with a thud.

"Ms. Carter," she said hoarsely, "I was a fool. Cassandra played me, and I believed her lies about you. My words were unforgivable. I’m begging for your forgiveness."

Evelyn recoiled, stunned. "What are you—?"

Gasps rippled through the room. Genevieve Stewart, heiress to a fortune, kneeling in apology? Unthinkable.

Jonathan Reeves emerged from his office, frowning. "What’s happening?"

Evelyn shook her head. "I have no idea."

She was just as baffled as everyone else. This had to be tied to something she didn’t know yet.

Then her phone buzzed. A message from Sophia:

"Reginald Stewart’s company just got acquired. His family’s facing bankruptcy. Karma’s finally biting back."

Evelyn’s breath caught. Reginald’s empire had fallen?

But why would that make Genevieve apologize to her?
###Chapter 177

Evelyn forwarded the link to Jonathan with a quiet murmur. "Jonathan, you should see this."

Across the room, Genevieve turned toward Evelyn, her voice trembling with desperation. "Ms. Carter, please—forgive me. I admit it was my fault."

Her hands clenched at her sides. "I shouldn’t have confronted you without verifying the facts first. This is entirely on me."

Evelyn studied her, skepticism flickering in her gaze. She wasn’t convinced Genevieve’s sudden remorse stemmed purely from regret—not when her family’s company had just been swallowed whole.

After a weighted pause, Evelyn arched a brow. "Why did you come to see me?"

Genevieve blinked, caught off guard, but quickly composed herself. "Ms. Carter, I truly recognize my mistake. Please, just give me this one chance."

"Get up first," Evelyn urged, her tone firm.

Genevieve shook her head, stubborn. "Not until you forgive me."

She stayed kneeling, defiance and fear warring in her posture.

Only when Evelyn finally muttered a reluctant pardon did Genevieve rise, her earlier arrogance replaced by something far more unsettling—genuine trepidation.

Once she was gone, the office settled back into uneasy silence.

Jonathan, standing nearby, finished reading the forwarded message. His gaze slid to Evelyn, a new layer of intrigue darkening his eyes. He hadn’t anticipated her maneuvering things so deftly behind the scenes.

Even with Keystone Construction collapsing, the Stewarts were old money—generations deep in wealth. Seeing Genevieve kneel to Evelyn? That was unexpected.

Lowering his voice, Jonathan beckoned, "Evelyn, my office. Now."

She followed, already knowing the unspoken question. "Jonathan, honestly? I’m just as lost as you are," she admitted before he could ask.

His lips thinned, but he relented. "Fine. If you won’t explain, I won’t push. But this situation… it’s working in your favor."

Evelyn didn’t bother correcting his assumption.

Back at her desk, she couldn’t resist digging into Keystone’s sudden downfall. One name stood out—Vista Properties.

A cold realization slithered down her spine.

Victoria’s family’s company.

Just yesterday, Victoria had sneered at her in that restaurant, boasting about her powerful brother’s backing. Now, coincidentally, that same brother had acquired Keystone?

What game was Victoria playing?

Scrolling further, Evelyn stumbled upon reports of environmental violations at Keystone’s golf course. Public outrage had sent stocks plummeting.

Then came the news: Reginald Stewart, overwhelmed, had suffered a stroke.

Now fighting for his life, his empire crumbled as his scattered heirs clawed for scraps.

Overnight, Keystone had imploded.

Evelyn wasn’t surprised. A man like Reginald, who’d ruined countless lives, deserved no less.

But the timing… it was too perfect.

Her phone buzzed—Penelope’s name flashed on the screen.

Evelyn answered warily. "Yes?"

"Evelyn, did you tattle to Nathaniel?" Penelope’s voice was venomous. "He canceled my cards and forbade my family from helping me. You heartless witch!"

Evelyn froze.

She had mentioned Penelope’s interference to Nathaniel—but only so he’d rein her in. All Evelyn wanted was peace.

She never expected him to cut Penelope off entirely.

Not when they were family.
###Chapter 178

The phone buzzed in Evelyn's hand as Victoria's shrill voice pierced through the receiver.

Evelyn kept her tone steady. "It's not like I froze your accounts. You should take that up with whoever did."

Without another word, she ended the call.

But Victoria was relentless. The phone lit up again and again, forcing Evelyn to mute it entirely.

The rumors that had been swirling around her lately had died down faster than she expected. She hadn't even needed to lift a finger.

A quiet relief settled over her.

Her fingers brushed gently over her abdomen, where the faintest flutter reminded her of the life growing inside.

After Eleanor's surgery at the end of the month, she could finally cut all ties with Nathaniel for good.

The thought brought a strange mix of sorrow and freedom.

She realized she should schedule a prenatal appointment.

Pulling out her phone, she booked the earliest slot available and gathered her things to leave work early.

"Evelyn, heading out already?"

Jonathan's voice made her turn.

"Yes, there's something I need to take care of. My workload is light today, so I thought I'd go now."

She hesitated, then added, "If anything urgent comes up, I can stay."

He shook his head. "No, it's fine. I was just worried about you. After the rumors, people are bound to talk, especially at the university."

A small smile touched her lips. "Thanks, but I'm not going to campus."

Jonathan chuckled. "Evelyn, you don't have to be so guarded around me. I'm not the enemy. We're friends, aren't we?"

She relaxed slightly, though the instinct to keep her distance remained. Her past with Nathaniel had left her wary of men, even well-meaning ones.

Luckily, Jonathan didn't press further.

Stepping into the elevator, Evelyn headed straight for the hospital.

She hadn't told Julian about the appointment.

His schedule was always packed, and she didn’t want to burden him. She could handle this alone.

The doctor’s words were a balm to her nerves. "Everything looks perfect. The baby is healthy."

Carefully, she tucked the ultrasound images into her bag. She had started keeping every scan, every report—tiny fragments of her child’s existence, even if the details were still blurred.

Glancing at the time, she realized it was still early.

Maybe she’d stop by Julian’s office.

The elevator doors slid open.

And then she froze.

Julian stood in the hallway, deep in conversation with a woman.

Victoria.

Evelyn’s breath hitched.

What were they doing together? Did they know each other?

She ducked behind a corner before Victoria could spot her.

Every encounter with that woman brought trouble. The last thing she wanted was to drag Julian into it.

From her hiding spot, Evelyn watched as Victoria gestured animatedly, her expression tight with frustration.

Were they arguing?

Julian’s voice was clipped, impatient. "I already told you—I don’t have time for your engagement."

"But Alexander promised you’d make it! I can’t have my own engagement without a single family member there. Do you know how that would look?"

Julian’s tone turned sharp. "If family matters so much, why did you refuse his help in finding your real one?"

Victoria paled.
###Chapter 179

A shadow of remorse flickered in Victoria's gaze. She had no intention of reuniting with her birth family.

Being abandoned long ago meant they either didn’t want her or couldn’t care for her.

With the Sinclair family offering her privilege and status, why should she seek out those who had discarded her?

Was blood truly thicker than water?

Having endured the harsh realities of the orphanage, Victoria understood the value of wealth and power. She had no interest in reconnecting with people who had once thrown her away.

With a strained smile, she said, "Finding my biological family won’t change anything about my engagement."

"You’re my family now. That’s why I want you all there with me when Nathaniel and I make it official."

Julian studied her with sharp scrutiny. "Victoria, you’ve already gotten what you wanted. I agreed to perform Eleanor’s surgery. Don’t push your luck."

"But Julian, I’m part of this family too. Is it really so much to ask that you attend my wedding?"

"Alexander was the one who brought you home. Frankly, I never approved of his decision, so I’ve never considered you my sister."

"And let’s not forget, Victoria, the years you’ve spent masquerading as the Sinclair heiress—you know exactly what you’ve done."

"I know exactly who you are, so I suggest you tread carefully."

Because Julian saw through Victoria’s facade, he chose to keep her identity—and Evelyn’s—hidden. He wouldn’t risk Victoria doing something reckless if she felt cornered.

With his words, the last flicker of hope in Victoria’s heart extinguished. Pretending was no longer an option.

Even as a child, Julian had seen right through her. She’d always kept her distance, afraid he might expose her.

Wiping away a stray tear, Victoria replied coolly, "Julian, Alexander promised me you’d all be there."

"If you refuse, I’ll have no choice but to tell Eleanor."

"You wouldn’t dare." His voice was ice.

"Julian, I don’t want to upset Eleanor after all her kindness. I just want my family beside me on my engagement day. Is that so unreasonable?"

With that, she turned and walked away, her expression darkening. She hadn’t expected Julian to be so blunt.

But it didn’t matter. Once she married Nathaniel, she’d never have to endure this humiliation again.

As Victoria left, Evelyn stepped out from around the corner. "Julian?" she called hesitantly.

Startled, Julian turned. "Evelyn? What are you doing here? Are you feeling unwell?"

"I came for a prenatal checkup and thought I’d visit you. I didn’t mean to interrupt your conversation with Victoria."

His expression tensed. "You saw us?"

Evelyn nodded. "Julian, do you know Victoria well?"

To her, their exchange had seemed far from casual—almost as if they shared a complicated history.

Julian’s mind raced. "Victoria came to discuss Eleanor’s surgery. I’ll be leading the procedure."

"Oh, I see. With you in charge, I’m sure everything will go smoothly."

She knew the surgery was complex, requiring multiple specialists. She just hadn’t realized Julian was involved.

Relief washed over him when Evelyn accepted his explanation. He’d come dangerously close to slipping up.

For now, at least, the truth remained hidden.
###Chapter 180

Evelyn's voice was firm. "Julian, since you're involved in this surgery, I need you to update me immediately if there's any change in Eleanor's condition."

Her concern for Eleanor was genuine.

Watching Evelyn's intense expression, Julian sighed. "Evelyn, relax. Eleanor will pull through. I give you my word."

He would give this surgery his all—not just for Eleanor, but to ensure Evelyn could finally break free from the Whitmore family's shadow.

After Evelyn left, Julian called Alexander. "When exactly did I agree to attend Victoria's engagement?"

Alexander cleared his throat. "Didn't I say I couldn't make it?"

"Then that's your problem," Julian snapped. "I never agreed to this. You made the promise, not me."

He despised Victoria's manipulative tactics—using Eleanor as leverage.

Had Victoria been sincere, things might have been different. But her actions shattered the illusion of innocence she wore so well.

Julian had no patience for two-faced people.

A sigh came through the phone. "Fine. I'll fly to Bern City in a few days."

"Olivia and I want to see the situation for ourselves, especially after the accusations against Evelyn."

"About Victoria's engagement—here's my idea..." Alexander laid out his plan.

Julian considered it. "It could work. But I doubt Victoria will agree. Still, worth a try."

"Just keep Evelyn out of it. I don’t want her dragged into more trouble."

"Julian, Victoria wouldn’t go that far," Alexander insisted.

Julian fell silent.

Beneath his brother's cool exterior lay unwavering trust—even in Victoria, despite her being adopted into their family.

In the end, Julian didn’t argue. If Victoria married Nathaniel and stayed in Bern City, that was enough.

Once Evelyn returned to Nord City, no one would dare hurt her again.

And when her child was born, they’d be welcomed into the Montgomery family without hesitation.

Evelyn would have the freedom—and protection—she deserved.

Attending the engagement might be Julian’s final goodbye to Victoria.

The next morning, Evelyn woke to breaking news—Victoria’s engagement had taken over every entertainment headline.

Photos showed Victoria in a wedding dress—the same one Evelyn had seen during her visit.

The engagement date was now public. Evelyn wasn’t surprised.

She went to class, then headed to the studio.

Repeating a year meant she barely knew her classmates—and she wasn’t interested in changing that.

At the studio, Cassandra’s workspace stood empty, stripped of all personal belongings.

Evelyn felt a twinge of regret.

Cassandra had been a talented designer, once placing second in the prestigious Fleur International Design Competition.

But one wrong choice had ruined everything.

Evelyn’s thoughts drifted to her own marriage—eerily similar to Cassandra’s downfall.

Then her phone buzzed.

The caller’s name made her eyes narrow. She hadn’t spoken to Beverly in months.

This call could only mean trouble.
###Chapter 181

Evelyn glanced at her phone, her fingers hovering over the screen. She had a sinking feeling that answering would only bring bad news.

The ringing persisted, sharp and relentless.

With a sigh, she finally picked up. "Hello?"

"Evelyn, you ungrateful brat! Why are you ignoring my calls?" Beverly's shrill voice pierced through the line. "I have something urgent to discuss!"

Evelyn's tone was icy. "What is it?"

"Transfer me a hundred thousand dollars. Now."

Evelyn scoffed. "A hundred thousand? You might as well ask me to hand over the moon."

She knew Beverly only reached out when she wanted money. And this time, the demand was outrageous from the start.

"Don’t play dumb with me," Beverly snapped. "Your husband is filthy rich. You control the finances now. With your real family in the picture, you can’t possibly be short on cash."

Evelyn’s grip tightened around her phone. "I don’t have that kind of money."

"You’ve been living comfortably while we struggle. If you don’t send it, I’ll make sure you regret it."

Evelyn’s frown deepened. "What do you even need it for?"

"Your brother Edward is getting married. His fiancée is pregnant. They need the money."

Evelyn’s voice turned colder. "I don’t have it. I’m using Aunt Margaret’s funds to pay for my tuition."

Beverly let out a mocking laugh. "Liar. Didn’t you win a million in that design competition? With Margaret’s money, you’re swimming in cash. Transfer it by tomorrow, or else."

The call ended abruptly.

Evelyn stared at her phone, then blocked Beverly’s number without hesitation. She wasn’t an ATM.

Her hand drifted to her stomach. She needed money too.

Growing up, Edward and his twin had tormented her. His wedding meant nothing to her.

That evening, when Evelyn returned home, she noticed Margaret’s troubled expression.

"Aunt Margaret, did Beverly call you?"

Margaret nodded. "She asked for money, didn’t she?"

Evelyn sighed. "A hundred thousand. Where am I supposed to get that? I’m still paying off my mortgage."

Margaret placed a comforting hand on her shoulder. "Don’t worry. A neighbor from our old place called. Beverly and Walter came looking for us, but I didn’t tell them where we live."

Evelyn exhaled in relief. "Good. I won’t give them a single cent."

She knew if Walter and Beverly caused trouble, her six brothers wouldn’t hesitate to step in.

For now, they’d stayed quiet—likely afraid of provoking them. In the countryside, a house full of men was an advantage in any fight.

Still, Evelyn remained on edge.

The next day, she went to class as usual.

Elizabeth approached her with a frown. "Evelyn, your adoptive parents contacted the college. They said they couldn’t reach you and need to talk."

Evelyn’s stomach twisted. "I don’t want to see them. They’re demanding money for Edward’s wedding. How am I supposed to afford that?"

Elizabeth, aware of Evelyn’s past, didn’t push further.

Throughout her classes, Evelyn’s mind wandered.

What unsettled her most was that Walter and Beverly had found her college—and knew about her previous education.

They were getting closer.

###Chapter 182

This was disastrous news.

After classes ended, Evelyn Carter slipped out of the university discreetly, her face hidden beneath a wide-brimmed hat and medical mask. She couldn't risk being spotted by Walter and Beverly Simmons.

Those two were perfectly capable of causing a scene - like blocking the university gates with their dramatic antics.

Reaching the curb, Evelyn scanned her surroundings with practiced caution. No familiar figures lurking in the shadows. Good.

She exhaled in relief and raised her hand to hail a cab home.

"Evelyn! Stop right there!"

A cherry-red convertible screeched to a halt beside her. Penelope Whitmore stormed out, her designer heels clicking angrily against the pavement. "Did you really think you could hide forever?"

Evelyn kept her expression neutral. "I wasn't hiding."

"Then why the disguise in this heatwave?" Penelope snapped, blocking Evelyn's path. "You're the one who snitched to my family! Now I'm stuck with a pathetic fifty-thousand-dollar monthly allowance that barely covers my spa treatments!"

She grabbed Evelyn's wrist. "You're coming with me to explain everything to Nathaniel. That whole Cassandra Blake mess had nothing to do with me. She acted alone!"

The financial restrictions had clearly devastated Penelope's lavish lifestyle. No more spontaneous shopping sprees or champagne brunches with her socialite friends. The deprivation showed in her pinched expression.

Evelyn almost pitied her. Almost.

Shrugging off Penelope's grip, Evelyn said coolly, "Not my problem. Nathaniel froze your accounts, not me."

"And Cassandra confessed everything under pressure! You expect me to believe you're innocent?"

"It was her personal vendetta against you! I had nothing to do with it!" Penelope's voice climbed an octave.

Evelyn knew better than to expect honesty from Nathaniel's scheming cousin. This argument was going nowhere.

Then movement caught her eye - Walter and Beverly Simmons were crossing the street toward them. Damn Penelope for delaying her!

Evelyn ducked her head, but Beverly's shrill voice carried across the intersection: "There you are, you ungrateful brat! Trying to avoid us?"

Evelyn's fingers twitched toward her phone. Maybe she could call security-

Penelope seized her arm again. "Going somewhere? Aren't those your lovely adoptive parents? Why not say hello?"

"Let go, Penelope!"

"Not until you agree to clear my name with Nathaniel!"

Seeing the Simmons couple closing in, Evelyn made a split-second decision. She wrenched open Penelope's car door and jumped in.

Facing Nathaniel's interrogation suddenly seemed preferable to another confrontation with her adoptive parents.

Penelope peeled away from the curb, leaving Walter and Beverly shouting obscenities in their wake. Evelyn glanced back at their furious faces and allowed herself a small, satisfied smile.

"Consider that your rescue," Penelope said smugly. "Now you'll explain everything to Nathaniel."

"What exactly am I supposed to explain?"

"That I'm innocent! He needs to restore my credit limit immediately."

Evelyn arched an eyebrow. "Do you really think Nathaniel acts without evidence? If he blocked your accounts, he already knows everything."

Penelope's grip tightened on the steering wheel. "So you refuse to help? Fine. Let's go back right now."

Evelyn bit back a scathing retort. This was going to be a long ride.
###Chapter 183

Just as Penelope was about to storm off, Evelyn quickly intervened. "Let's talk this through rationally. There's no need for dramatics."

Evelyn had worked too hard to break free from her adoptive family's toxic influence. She wouldn't let Walter and Beverly Simmons drag her back into their messy world.

No matter how much resentment they harbored, they held no power over her anymore. She was fiercely protective of her newfound peace.

Penelope smirked arrogantly as she accelerated the car.

Soon, the towering Whitmore Corporation headquarters came into view. Evelyn hadn't expected their destination to be here.

Parking smoothly, Penelope announced smugly, "This must be your first time here, Evelyn? Consider this your personal tour."

"When you were the Whitmore heiress, you never bothered visiting. But I'll generously show you around now. Don't thank me!"

Evelyn studied Penelope with detached amusement. "There's something I've been curious about."

Penelope tilted her chin up haughtily. "Ask away."

"How do you maintain that delusional sense of superiority?" Evelyn quipped.

Penelope's face flushed with anger. "What did you just say?"

"The way you talk, one would think you're the CEO," Evelyn retorted sarcastically.

Penelope stomped her foot in frustration, but remembering she needed Evelyn's cooperation for the meeting with Nathaniel, she swallowed her pride.

"Enough nonsense. Follow me."

Evelyn remained silent as they entered the elevator.

The executive floor exuded luxury befitting a corporate empire. Evelyn noted Nathaniel's usual impeccable taste.

Penelope marched straight to the secretary pool. "Where's Nathaniel?"

"Mr. Whitmore is in a meeting," a secretary replied politely. "You may wait in the guest lounge if you'd like."

"I'll wait in his office," Penelope insisted.

"I'm sorry, Ms. Whitmore, but unauthorized access to Mr. Whitmore's office is strictly prohibited."

Penelope turned away, visibly embarrassed.

Evelyn hadn't expected Nathaniel's security protocols to be this strict. Even family members received no special treatment.

"Told you," Evelyn murmured with a knowing smile.

Penelope bristled. "Stop looking so smug! Nathaniel has always been a stickler for rules. It's not like you were ever important enough to know that."

They proceeded to the conference room in tense silence.

To their surprise, Victoria Sinclair was already there.

The atmosphere grew palpably awkward as the three women exchanged glances.

Victoria's eyes narrowed suspiciously at seeing Evelyn with Penelope. "Penelope, why are you with her?"

Had Penelope switched alliances?

Evelyn was equally surprised by Victoria's presence. Apparently, neither woman held special privileges with Nathaniel.

Some things never changed - Nathaniel remained a workaholic through and through.

Penelope rushed to explain, "Victoria, don't misunderstand! I brought Evelyn to help with my credit card situation."

Victoria recalled how Nathaniel had frozen Penelope's cards after the Cassandra Blake incident. She hadn't expected Penelope to cave so quickly - what a weakling!

Putting on a sisterly smile, Victoria cooed, "Penelope darling, I've told you before - if you need money, just ask me."

"But Victoria, I can't keep relying on you," Penelope protested weakly.

"Nonsense! We're practically sisters now." Victoria produced her platinum card with visible reluctance. "Take this. Buy whatever you want."

Though it pained her, Victoria knew securing Penelope's loyalty required sacrifices.

Touched, Penelope accepted the card. "Thank you, Victoria. Or should I say... sister?"
###Chapter 184



Victoria wore a victorious smirk, though an undercurrent of unease twisted in her gut as she glanced at Evelyn.

Turning to Penelope, Victoria suggested, "Why don't we let her leave? When we meet Nathaniel later, I'll handle the credit card issue myself."

For reasons she couldn't explain, Victoria didn’t want Evelyn anywhere near Nathaniel—especially not now.

Penelope rolled her eyes and nodded. "Fine, Evelyn, you can go. We don’t need you here anymore."

Evelyn had no desire to stay. After all, Penelope had dragged her here against her will.

This outcome suited Evelyn perfectly. In fact, it might have just made things easier for her.

As Evelyn stepped out of the guest room, she nearly collided with a group exiting the adjacent conference hall.

At the forefront stood Nathaniel, impeccably dressed in a charcoal suit, his usual aura of icy detachment radiating around him. He was deep in conversation with Robert, his head slightly bowed.

Robert’s expression darkened the moment he spotted Evelyn. "Sir, Ms. Carter is here," he murmured.

Nathaniel’s gaze snapped toward Evelyn, his brows knitting together.

Why was Evelyn here?

A flicker of surprise crossed his eyes before he schooled his features. "Tell her to wait in my office," he ordered quietly.

He was certain she had a reason for coming.

Robert approached Evelyn. "Ms. Carter, Mr. Whitmore requests that you wait for him in his office."

Wait for Nathaniel?

Confusion flickered in Evelyn’s eyes. "Actually, I was just leaving. The person looking for Nathaniel is in the guest room."

Knowing Victoria was inside, Evelyn had no intention of lingering and risking humiliation.

Without another word, she turned toward the elevators.

Nathaniel’s lips pressed into a thin line as he watched her walk away. Was she playing games again?

Why come only to leave so abruptly?

Just then, the guest room door swung open.

Victoria stepped out, her expression sweet and cheerful as she approached Nathaniel. "Nate, are you finished with your meeting?"

Nathaniel ignored her, his gaze still fixed on Evelyn by the elevator.

Evelyn resisted the urge to look back as the doors slid shut.

At that moment, she was nothing more than a detached ex-wife.

As the elevator disappeared, Nathaniel’s expression tightened. He turned to Victoria and Penelope, his voice cool. "What are you two doing here?"

Victoria’s smile faltered. Before she could respond, Penelope blurted out, "Nathaniel, could you please reinstate my credit card?"

"The Cassandra incident had nothing to do with me. If you don’t believe me, ask Evelyn. She was just here—"

Penelope trailed off, realizing Evelyn had already left. She shot Victoria a pleading look.

Victoria cleared her throat awkwardly. "Nate, Evelyn just confirmed that Penelope wasn’t involved. She didn’t accuse her of anything."

Nathaniel’s gaze sharpened. "Did you bring Evelyn here?"

He still couldn’t fathom why she’d shown up unannounced.

Penelope nodded quickly. "On the way, I explained everything to her, and we reached an understanding. That’s why she agreed to come as a witness."

Nathaniel’s voice turned icy. "Did you apologize?"

Penelope hesitated, guilt flashing across her face. "Yes, of course. Otherwise, she wouldn’t have come with me."

"You’re lying."

Nathaniel saw through her instantly. "You’ll apologize to Evelyn properly. Only then will I consider reinstating your credit limit."

Penelope paled, turning desperately to Victoria.

Apologizing to Evelyn? That was far worse than admitting her own mistakes.
###Chapter 185

Under Evelyn's intense gaze, Victoria finally found her voice. "Nathaniel, this whole mess was just a small misunderstanding. Cassandra orchestrated everything, so please don't blame Penelope."

Nathaniel's expression remained icy. "I have matters to attend to. You may leave."

Flustered, Victoria pressed on. "Nathaniel, there's something important I need to discuss. For our engagement ceremony, Alexander and my brothers will be attending."

She had come specifically to inform him of this.

To her, their engagement held immense significance.

Now that Nathaniel was divorced from Evelyn, Victoria believed she was the perfect match for him.

No one could compete with her.

Nathaniel lowered his gaze, his tone cutting. "What does it matter? Our engagement was never real, and you know that better than anyone."

Victoria's breath hitched. "Nathaniel, please. Just help me save face in front of my brothers. Julian still believes our engagement is genuine."

"If he finds out next week that it's just a transaction—especially if you don’t show up—what if he changes his mind about Eleanor’s surgery?"

Nathaniel’s cold, distant eyes remained unreadable before he turned and walked away without another word.

Left standing alone, Victoria bit her lip, hesitation flickering in her eyes.

Beside her, Penelope wrung her hands anxiously. "Victoria, did you talk to Nathaniel about reinstating my credit card?"

Victoria’s eyes reddened. "Penelope, you saw how he treated me. There’s nothing more I can do."

Panic crept into Penelope’s voice. "Then what am I supposed to do? Apologize to Evelyn? That’s absolutely humiliating!"

She had always looked down on Evelyn, mocking her openly and behind her back.

The thought of groveling to her now made Penelope’s stomach churn.

Despite her own frustration, Victoria forced a composed smile. "For now, just use the card I gave you."

"Given time, Nathaniel will forget about this. Evelyn only told him to play the victim."

"If you confront her, you’ll be walking right into her trap."

Penelope’s resentment flared. "So she just gets away with it? I refuse to swallow my pride like this!"

She scoffed. "Cassandra is utterly useless. I even gave her two designer bags, and she still couldn’t handle something this simple."

Victoria’s lips curled in silent disdain. In her eyes, Penelope was just as incompetent, unable to deal with someone as insignificant as Evelyn.

Still, she needed Penelope’s loyalty—for now.

Once she married Nathaniel, she wouldn’t have to tolerate such foolishness anymore.

Suddenly, Penelope perked up. "Victoria, when I was looking for Evelyn earlier, I heard she’s been avoiding her adoptive parents. Apparently, they’re not easy to deal with."

"If they find her, she’ll be in serious trouble."

A sly glint flashed in Victoria’s eyes. "That’s an excellent idea. With Nathaniel and Eleanor protecting her, even I can’t touch her carelessly. This might be our only option."

She sneered. "I don’t understand what’s so special about Evelyn. Rumor has it she was adopted from an orphanage. How could someone like her ever be worthy of Nathaniel?"

At the mention of "orphanage," Victoria’s expression darkened momentarily. After all, she, too, had come from an orphanage—though she considered herself far luckier than Evelyn.

If not for her cunning back then, she might still be struggling at the bottom.

Shaking off the thought, Victoria lifted her chin.

She was the heiress of the Sinclair family now, destined for a life of luxury and power.

Nothing would stand in her way.
###Chapter 186

No matter how hard Evelyn tried, she could never outshine Victoria.

As Evelyn stepped out of Whitmore Enterprises, she paused to glance back at the towering glass structure before turning away decisively.

That evening, Margaret grasped Evelyn's hands excitedly. "Darling, I've got wonderful news! Our old neighborhood might be getting redeveloped!"

"Redevelopment? Are you certain?"

Evelyn had never imagined their modest neighborhood would qualify for urban renewal. Was fortune finally smiling upon them?

Just when she desperately needed funds, could this be her unexpected windfall?

Margaret's eyes sparkled with excitement. "Absolutely! I visited our old street today and spoke with neighbors. There's going to be a community meeting soon to discuss compensation options."

"I heard they're offering two choices - either replacement housing or monetary compensation."

Evelyn squeezed Margaret's hands. "This is incredible news. When the time comes, we'll carefully consider which option serves us best."

"I'm certain Walter and Beverly will hear about this eventually. We should inform your brothers before they cause trouble again."

"Let's see who dares to harass us when they're around. After all these years of suffering, it's our turn to stand strong."

Evelyn understood Margaret's unspoken wish - to finally have the upper hand against their tormentors.

With six formidable brothers by her side, who would dare cross them now?

After dinner, Evelyn sent a message to the family group chat explaining the redevelopment situation.

Olivia responded first: "Urban renewal is fantastic news! Evelyn, you've always been our lucky charm!"

Sebastian teased playfully: "Our little sister brings fortune wherever she goes. My property sales have skyrocketed lately - must be Evelyn's magic touch!"

Soon all her brothers joined the lively conversation, filling the chat with affectionate banter and exaggerated praise.

Evelyn shook her head at their antics, equal parts amused and exasperated.

"That's not the point," she typed. "The real concern is when Walter and Beverly find out, they'll definitely make trouble."

"I was wondering if any of you could come help handle the situation?"

Alexander replied instantly: "Count me in! I was planning to visit soon anyway."

Julian added: "Perfect timing - I haven't used my annual leave yet."

Christopher chimed in: "Conveniently, I'm already in Bern City for a concert but can arrive early."

Andrew wrote: "I can schedule a business trip there."

Daniel concluded: "Just wrapped filming - perfect timing for a vacation."

Reading their responses, warmth flooded Evelyn's heart. She gently touched her abdomen, imagining how many doting uncles her child would have.

The next morning, with no university classes, Evelyn headed straight to her design studio. Earning money remained her top priority.

She'd barely stepped inside when angry shouts erupted behind her. "Evelyn, you ungrateful wretch! Did you think you could hide from us forever?"

Turning to face Walter and Beverly, Evelyn's stomach dropped. "How did you find this place?"

This shouldn't be possible - they shouldn't know about her studio!

Beverly dramatically clutched Evelyn's legs, wailing. "Edward's life is ruined because of you! How can you live with yourself, avoiding us like this?"

###Chapter 187

Beverly's dramatic outburst made Evelyn lower her voice to a barely audible whisper. "We should take this conversation outside."

"Absolutely not!" Beverly declared loudly. "Let's settle this right here in front of all your fancy coworkers. I want them to know exactly why you're refusing to help your own family. Remember who took you in when you were starving in that orphanage? We gave you a home!"

Walter played his part perfectly, nodding along as he addressed the gathered colleagues. "We've spent our entire savings raising this girl. Now when we need help, she turns her back on us."

Evelyn's icy gaze locked onto her so-called parents. "You never paid a single cent for my education."

Beverly let out an exaggerated wail. "How can you say such things? Who else would have paid for your schooling? You won scholarships and now have this fancy job, but you won't share a penny with your own family!"

The commotion drew Jonathan from his office, his brow furrowed in concern. "What's happening here?"

Seizing the opportunity, Beverly launched into her performance. "You must be Evelyn's boss. Does she make good money? As her legal guardians, her salary should be going directly to us."

The sheer audacity almost made Evelyn laugh aloud. She'd never encountered such shameless behavior in her life.

Her adoptive parents always managed to redefine the boundaries of disgrace.

Jonathan studied them carefully. "You're claiming to be Evelyn's adoptive parents?"

"That's right," Walter confirmed. "We sacrificed everything to raise her, and this is how she repays us. We need that money to save a life. You should hand over her earnings immediately."

A cold laugh escaped Jonathan's lips. "Hand over her salary? On what legal grounds? You're making outrageous demands!"

Both Evelyn and Walter froze, unprepared for Jonathan's sharp rebuttal.

Jonathan continued mercilessly, "From what I understand, it was Margaret Dawson who raised Evelyn and funded her education. Her so-called adoptive parents relegated her to servant status the moment they had their own biological child."

He stepped closer to Evelyn's defense. "If not for Margaret's kindness, who knows where Evelyn might have ended up. How dare you show your faces here demanding money?"

Beverly and Walter exchanged uneasy glances, their carefully constructed facade cracking under Jonathan's scrutiny.

Dropping all pretense, Beverly revealed her true nature. "I don't care about any of that! We raised her, so she owes us. Either she pays up, or we'll take this to court. We've got nothing to lose."

Walter added his own threat: "If we don't get that money, we'll camp outside your precious studio every day. We'll pitch a tent right in your lobby. Let's see who lasts longer."

To emphasize their point, Beverly dramatically collapsed onto the floor. "Actually, this office isn't bad. Spacious, well-lit, air-conditioned... much better than our shack back home."

Even Jonathan seemed taken aback by their brazen behavior.

Evelyn, long accustomed to their antics, remained composed. She turned to Jonathan with an apologetic expression. "I'm sorry for causing another scene, Jonathan. I'll submit my resignation immediately."

If she left the studio, her adoptive parents would have no reason to cause trouble there.

Jonathan's frown deepened. "Evelyn, you need to reconsider this decision carefully."

Beverly immediately interjected, "Why would you quit such a good job, Evelyn? Our whole family depends on you! You can't resign - you need to work harder than ever!"
###Chapter 188

Evelyn Carter glared at Walter and Beverly Simmons with fire in her eyes. "Over my dead body! I'd rather be homeless than give you a single penny!"

"Mind your tone, girl!" Walter's face twisted with rage, his fists clenching. "You think I won't slap you right here?"

Jonathan Reeves moved like lightning, seizing Walter's collar. "Go ahead. Make my day."

The office erupted as male colleagues formed a protective circle around Evelyn, while female coworkers flanked her sides. The air crackled with tension.

"Disgusting parasites," another woman muttered. "Coming here to extort money from their own daughter."

Outnumbered, the Simmons couple retreated several steps.

Beverly planted her hands on her hips, her voice shrill. "This isn't over, Evelyn Carter! We'll be back!"

As the door slammed behind them, Evelyn turned to her colleagues with watery eyes. "I... I don't know how to thank you all. Coffee's on me today."

Evelyn's smile didn't reach her eyes. "That's why I'm resigning."

"Absolutely not." Jonathan's voice turned serious. "If it's money you need—"

"It's not about money." Evelyn shook her head firmly. "If I give in now, they'll bleed me dry forever."

She knew her adoptive parents' nature all too well - like sharks scenting blood in water.

Jonathan snapped his fingers. "Then fake your resignation! Come back when they stop lurking around."

"Jonathan..." Guilt twisted Evelyn's stomach. He'd gone above and beyond for her too many times already.

The office drama had left her emotionally drained, shame burning in her chest.

"Hey, that's what friends are for." Jonathan winked, sparking giggles from nearby coworkers. "Anytime you need help, just call."

Evelyn managed a small smile before heading out for coffee orders.



Her phone buzzed with an unknown number. "Hello?"

"Evelyn, did your lovely parents pay you a visit?" The smug female voice dripped with malice.

Evelyn's grip tightened on the phone. "Penelope Whitmore. You told them where I worked."

How else would they have found her? This had Nathaniel's scheming cousin written all over it.

"Listen carefully," Penelope hissed. "If you want peace, tell Nathaniel to unfreeze my accounts."

Evelyn's laugh held no humor. "A sincere apology might've worked, Penelope. I could've spoken to Nathaniel on your behalf."

"APOLOGY?" Penelope's shriek nearly shattered Evelyn's eardrum. "You delusional little—"

"My thoughts exactly." Evelyn ended the call and blocked the number with practiced ease.

She spent the day buried in textbooks at the university library, grateful for the temporary peace.

Jonathan called later. "They came sniffing around again. I told them you quit and owed the company damages." His chuckle was rich with satisfaction. "You should've seen them scramble away like roaches."

Evelyn's laughter bubbled up unexpectedly. Leave it to Jonathan to outsmart them.

As twilight painted the sky, her phone buzzed again. Evelyn frowned at the unfamiliar caller ID. Why would this person be contacting her now?
###Chapter 189

Evelyn Carter stared at her phone screen, blinking in disbelief at the caller ID—Nathaniel Whitmore.

Her fingers hovered over the answer button as she muttered, "Why is he calling me? Did he misdial?"

The relentless ringing forced her to pick up. "What do you want, Mr. Whitmore?" she snapped.

His voice was ice. "Your adoptive parents showed up at the villa, demanding money from me."

Humiliation burned through her veins. "Kick them out. Don’t give them a cent."

"I don’t have time for this. Handle it yourself," he said coldly before the line went dead.

After gathering her things, Evelyn hailed a cab to the villa.

Standing before the grand gates, memories rushed back. She hadn’t stepped foot here since she left.

Her finger hesitated over the doorbell before pressing it.

Even before the door opened, raised voices spilled into the foyer.

Her adoptive parents weren’t alone—Beatrice Harrington’s shrill tone cut through the chaos.

Evelyn’s stomach twisted. Why is she here?

She nearly turned to leave when Abigail Wilkins swung the door open with a tight smile. "Mrs. Whitmore! You’re back! Come in."

Suppressing her unease, Evelyn stepped inside and whispered, "What’s she doing here?"

Abigail sighed. "No idea. But this just got complicated."

Evelyn knew if the door hadn’t opened so fast, she would’ve fled.

The moment she entered the living room, all eyes locked onto her.

Beverly Simmons smirked. "Evelyn, so nice of you to finally show up."

She jabbed a finger toward Beatrice. "Tell your mother-in-law who’s in charge here! Your husband claims you make the decisions, but she seems to disagree."

Beatrice trembled with rage. "Answer me, Evelyn Carter! Who controls my son’s money? Who do you think you are?"

She had come to redecorate for Nathaniel’s second marriage—never expecting Beverly and Walter’s sudden appearance.

Evelyn exhaled sharply before meeting Beatrice’s glare. "There’s something you should know. Nathaniel and I are divorced."

Beverly’s face darkened. "What?"

"Evelyn Carter, how could you keep this from us?" Walter demanded. "Why divorce a man like him? Have you lost your mind?"

Beatrice sneered. "Let me remind you—someone like Evelyn was never fit for my son. Especially with those disgraceful parents. I’m relieved they divorced. It would’ve ruined our reputation."

Evelyn, already familiar with Beatrice’s cruelty, turned away, pretending not to hear.

She glanced at her adoptive parents. "Did you hear that? I was thrown out because I didn’t belong. I haven’t lived here in months. Stop coming here—you’re disturbing people."

Beverly scoffed. "Even if you’re divorced, he must’ve given you money. Hand it over!"

Walter nodded. "That’s how it works in dramas. You got assets. Give us the cash, and we’ll leave."

Evelyn’s lips thinned. "Sorry to disappoint, but I left with nothing. I only married him because I was shameless back then. We had a prenup—I get zero after divorce. So give up."
###Chapter 190

Evelyn's sharp words left Beverly and Walter speechless.

Across the room, Beatrice's pride took a direct hit. "It's 100 thousand dors, isn't it? I can write the check, but on one condition—you stay away from my son. He's engaged to a woman from the Sinclair family now. A perfect match."

With a flick of her wrist, she scribbled the amount and tossed the check onto the floor.

Beverly scrambled to pick it up, greed flashing in her eyes. "How generous of you. And you're absolutely right about Evelyn—just an orphan with no connections. Ungrateful, too. Good riddance she's divorced."

Beatrice smirked, disdain dripping from her gaze. "Take the money and get out of my sight."

Afraid it might disappear, Beverly shoved the check into her purse.

Without another word, she turned and left, not even sparing Evelyn a backward glance.

Evelyn inhaled deeply. "I'll pay you back."

Supporting her adoptive parents had never been her responsibility. And Beatrice covering the cost? That wasn't part of the plan either.

Beatrice scoffed. "Don't bother. That amount is pocket change to me. Frankly, it's worth it to be rid of the headache."

She crossed her arms. "You could never repay me anyway. Do I need to remind you of your salary? Just keep your family in check. Stay out of our lives. We move in different worlds now."

Evelyn pulled out her phone and transferred the money to Nathaniel. Then she met Beatrice's gaze. "It's done. You won't hear from me again."

"Why do you still have my son's contact?" Beatrice demanded. "What are you scheming? The divorce is final. There's no reason for you to stay connected."

Under her ex-mother-in-law's scrutiny, Evelyn deleted Nathaniel's number. "Satisfied?"

"Much better." Beatrice's lips curled. "The Sinclairs will be at the engagement party this weekend. That's the kind of family my son deserves."

She tilted her head. "Know your place. Don't aim for men out of your league. Someone like that famous actor, for instance—keep dreaming."

A mocking smile played on Evelyn's lips. "If I could marry Nathaniel, who's to say I can't land someone even better?"

The air turned thick with tension.

"Mr. Whitmore, you're back," Abigail announced loudly.

Evelyn's spine stiffened. She glanced over her shoulder—Nathaniel stood there, his dark eyes unreadable.

Her fingers curled into fists. Showing weakness now was the last thing she wanted.

Beatrice brightened. "Nathaniel, darling. You heard Evelyn, didn't you? Marrying someone better? The audacity. It's almost laughable."

Nathaniel strode into the room, his expression blank. But the way he loosened his tie betrayed his irritation.

Beatrice pressed on. "Evelyn's adoptive parents made a scene. They claimed she ran this household—handled the finances! Can you imagine? The lies she fed them!"

Nathaniel's response was flat. "I did say that."

Evelyn froze. Shock rendered her speechless.

She refused to believe those words had come from him.
###Chapter 191

Evelyn couldn't suppress a quiet laugh at Beatrice's stunned expression.

Honestly, Nathaniel had only used that excuse to dismiss Evelyn's adoptive parents, who had shown up unannounced—begging for money.

She hadn't expected him to turn it into a sharp retort against Beatrice, delivered with zero deference.

His gaze flicked to Evelyn the next second, making her breath catch.

It was strange, really. She hadn't even been the one to speak.

Nathaniel's voice was icy. "Why did you transfer a hundred thousand dollars to me?"

Evelyn blinked. "I was repaying your mother. Since I didn’t have her account details, I sent it to you. Could you forward it to her?"

He glanced at Beatrice. "What happened?"

"Nathaniel, Evelyn’s adoptive parents came demanding money. I gave them the hundred thousand just to get rid of them. It’s not a significant amount," Beatrice replied dismissively.

His brows drew together. "You shouldn’t have."

He knew exactly what kind of people Evelyn’s adoptive family were—opportunistic leeches. Give them an inch, and they’d take a mile.

"Nathaniel, I know you think it’s a waste, but consider it a small price to pay for peace," Beatrice reasoned.

His lips thinned. He didn’t say it was a waste. He said it was a mistake. Feeding their greed would only invite more trouble.

Evelyn scoffed. "If that’s all, I’ll be leaving. If they show up again, don’t let them in."

She turned on her heel and walked out without another word.

Outside, the night was thick and still. The upscale neighborhood had no public transport, and taxis were nonexistent.

A sleek black car rolled up beside her moments later. The driver lowered the window. "Mrs. Whitmore, let me take you home."

"No need," she said stiffly.

The driver persisted. "You won’t find a cab here, ma’am. Besides, I need to drop something off for Mr. Whitmore anyway."

Evelyn hesitated, then relented. Pride was one thing, but safety was another.

The silence in the car was heavy. She glanced at the driver. "Thank you."

"Of course."

From the rearview mirror, he watched her exhale in quiet resignation. Relief settled in his chest.

If he’d failed to bring her back, he wouldn’t have known how to face his boss.

At a red light, he quickly typed out a message to Robert. Mrs. Whitmore is in the car.

Robert read the text and hurried upstairs—only to walk into a heated argument between Nathaniel and Beatrice.

Beatrice was fuming. "Nathaniel, you’re divorced. Why won’t you clear out the walk-in closet? What if Victoria moves in and sees all of Evelyn’s things still here?"

Nathaniel’s patience was fraying. "Mother, this engagement is a business arrangement. Nothing more."

"That’s ridiculous. Victoria is perfect—beautiful, well-connected, obedient. She’d make an ideal wife. Forget the pretense. Make it real."

He pinched the bridge of his nose. "I’m thirty, not three. Stop barging into my room and dictating my life."

Beatrice’s temper flared. "You’re my son! I have every right to check on you!"

"You’ve checked. Now leave." He ushered her out and shut the door firmly behind her.

She huffed, powerless against his stubbornness. "The engagement party is this weekend. Don’t embarrass us. The Sinclairs aren’t people you want to cross."
###Chapter 192



Nathaniel's expression darkened. "Mother, I have an important meeting soon. You should return home first."

"Of course. Just remember not to push yourself too hard at work." Beatrice simply advised, knowing better than to interfere with his professional matters.

No matter how many unspoken words burned in her throat, she forced them down.

After she departed, he descended to the living room.

Robert promptly updated him, "Mr. Whitmore, the chauffeur has safely delivered Mrs. Whitmore home."

Nathaniel acknowledged with a hum, sinking into the couch. A faint crease of worry appeared between his brows.

He dismissed Robert with a wave. "You're free to leave for the evening."

Finally released from duty, Robert exited the residence.

Nathaniel's gaze lingered on Evelyn's message and the returned transaction. His lips pressed into a thin line.

The moment he hit send, he noticed Evelyn's profile picture had disappeared from his contacts - a clear sign she'd blocked him.

The air around him turned icy. For hours, he stared at his darkened phone screen before finally dialing her number.

Had Evelyn truly cut him off? The thought was inconceivable.

She hadn't planned to answer, but courtesy demanded it since she was using his family's driver.

The moment the call connected, Nathaniel's voice came through gritted teeth. "Evelyn Carter, how dare you block my number!"

Her jaw tightened. "I was simply following your mother's instructions."

"Since when do you take orders from her?" His voice vibrated with barely contained fury.

"She won't be checking your phone for deleted contacts. Besides, exes typically become strangers after divorce, don't they?" Evelyn pointed out.

Evelyn turned her gaze to the passing scenery, one hand absently stroking her barely noticeable baby bump.

"You're right. We'll be nothing to each other after this."

Future baby photos would certainly complicate matters otherwise.

"I'm not looking for another relationship right now," Evelyn replied.

"But you must! You need someone to protect you," Margaret insisted, her voice laced with maternal concern.

Evelyn understood Margaret's traditional worries, but times had changed.

If she could support herself, marriage wasn't a necessity.

After reassuring Margaret, Evelyn received a call from Alexander. "Evelyn, we're flying back to Nord City tomorrow."

The news of her brothers' return lifted her spirits. "Wonderful! What's your arrival time? I'll meet you at the airport."

The following day, Evelyn arrived early at the terminal to welcome Alexander and Olivia.

As she stepped from the taxi, a flash of familiar crimson caught her eye - a Maserati parked nearby. It wasn't until Penelope and Victoria emerged that recognition dawned.
###Chapter 193

###Chapter 194

The fact that Nathaniel had agreed to attend her engagement party was monumental.

Once she became Mrs. Whitmore, with Nathaniel’s influence behind her, her status in Bern City would skyrocket.

No one would dare challenge her position then. She would command the respect she deserved.

Victoria again.
###Chapter 195

No one in Bern City could know.

That's exactly why she was determined to marry Nathaniel and establish herself here.

###Chapter 196

Victoria Sinclair wasn't a reckless spender like Penelope Whitmore.

Had Victoria been the true heiress of the Sinclair fortune, she wouldn't have suffered so much.

Her life could have been as effortless as Penelope's.
