Victoria, who had never been one to cry easily, now let tears fall. "Julian, you have to help me. That woman dared to slap me. She has no respect for our family!"

Julian remained composed. "Victoria, you don’t need to make up excuses to provoke me. It won’t change anything."

"When we were kids, you used our family’s influence to bully others. You know that. Why bring up grievances now?"

"Julian, this is different! The one who hit me is Nathaniel’s ex-wife! We’re in Bern City—how could I have provoked her?"

Julian’s expression shifted slightly. "Nathaniel’s ex-wife hit you? Why?"

"She accused me of being a mistress."

"Well, technically, she’s not wrong. I’ve heard Nathaniel hasn’t finalized his divorce yet. And here you are, already engaged to him—doesn’t that sound like a mistress?"

Victoria hesitated before reluctantly admitting, "Julian, the engagement was called off because of you!"
###Chapter 269

Haunted by her broken engagement, Victoria Sinclair tossed and turned in bed, her mind burning with fury.

Everything had been perfect—until that disastrous day, when unforeseen circumstances tore her future apart.

Raising a brow, Julian Montgomery asked coolly, "Because of me?"

"According to Nathaniel, your decision to operate on Grandma Eleanor had nothing to do with me!" Victoria snapped.

Clearing his throat, Julian nodded. "You're right. It wasn't because of you."

Victoria's eyes widened in shock. "Julian, what are you saying?"

"If it's not me, then who? Nathaniel? Since when do you care about him? I thought you despised him!"

"I do."

"Then who?"

She had dug relentlessly for answers, yet the truth remained frustratingly out of reach.

Julian remained composed. "Victoria, some things aren't worth obsessing over."

"But lies can't last forever. Your broken engagement is the consequence of your own deception."

"Julian, fine, I lied. But you still haven’t explained why you agreed to operate on Grandma Eleanor. Who are you doing this for?"

"That’s none of your concern. You should leave."

Tears pricked Victoria’s eyes. "Julian, are you and Alexander hiding something from me? He’s even pressuring me to sign adoption termination papers."

"After all these years as family, why is he suddenly pushing me away?"

Julian hesitated.

Originally, he had planned to tell her after the engagement, but now, with everything falling apart, the truth would have to wait.

Glancing at her, he said, "I don’t want to discuss this now."

With that, he walked out, leaving Victoria standing alone, her mind racing.

Something was wrong—terribly wrong—but no matter how hard she tried, she couldn’t piece it together.

Just then, Isabelle Laurent approached, offering an ice pack. "This might help."

"Thanks," Victoria muttered, pressing it to her face as she wiped away her smudged tears.

"You're Dr. Montgomery’s sister, aren’t you?" Isabelle asked gently.

Victoria sighed dramatically. "Yes. Lately, he’s been acting like a stranger."

"Ms. Sinclair… I think it might be because he’s seeing someone," Isabelle whispered.

Victoria stiffened. "Julian is in a relationship? Why wasn’t I told?"

Lowering her voice, Isabelle continued, "There’s a woman staying in the ward downstairs. She’s been coming in for treatments—Dr. Montgomery personally oversees her care."

"Yesterday, she was brought back by helicopter. Rumor has it she was kidnapped."

Kidnapped.

A name flashed in Victoria’s mind. "Evelyn Carter?"

Isabelle nodded. "That’s her."

Victoria’s thoughts screeched to a halt.

Then, slowly, she turned to Isabelle. "You’re saying Evelyn visits Julian often?"

"Not just visits. He treats her like she’s special."

"Dr. Montgomery is respected here, but I’ve never seen him show this kind of attention to anyone before. Evelyn is different."

The realization hit Victoria like a punch to the gut.

Without another word, she stormed toward the stairs, determined to uncover the truth.

Silently, she crept to Evelyn’s ward, the door slightly ajar.

Peering inside, she saw Julian standing beside Evelyn’s bed, speaking softly as he peeled an apple for her.

Victoria didn’t need further proof.

Now she understood why Evelyn had grown so bold—why threats about demolishing her old neighborhood hadn’t fazed her.

At last, the truth was clear.
###Chapter 270

Evelyn Carter had not only successfully seduced Nathaniel Whitmore, but now she was also entangled with Julian Montgomery!

This explained why Julian had been so reluctant to reveal his reasons for agreeing to perform surgery for Eleanor earlier.

Could it be because of Evelyn?

All the puzzling mysteries that had eluded Victoria Sinclair suddenly became crystal clear.

Evelyn had orchestrated everything! This shameless woman dared to seduce Julian for her own benefit, showing no remorse whatsoever!

Victoria's fingers twitched with the urge to burst through the door and expose Evelyn's true colors. Yet she restrained herself at the last moment.

If she confronted them now, Evelyn would surely conjure up countless excuses.

Victoria needed a comprehensive plan - one decisive revelation that would settle everything permanently.

Inside the hospital room, Evelyn suddenly glanced toward the window.

Julian followed her gaze. "Something wrong?"

"Nothing." She shook her head. "Just my imagination playing tricks."

She'd felt someone watching, but perhaps it was just a passing nurse.

Julian handed her a sliced apple. "Evelyn, Nathaniel went out of his way to help you this time. His attitude seems... unusual."

Evelyn's expression turned awkward. "Julian, the only reason Nathaniel helped is because of Eleanor's influence."

"She's always been kind to me. If anything happened to me under his watch, she'd hold him accountable."

"Is that truly the only reason?" Julian pressed.

Evelyn nodded firmly. "What else could it be?"

The idea that Nathaniel still cared for her seemed impossible. He'd been more than eager to finalize their divorce and erase her from his life completely.

Seeing Evelyn's apparent indifference toward Nathaniel, Julian felt relieved. Her emotional detachment might protect her from further heartbreak.

"I want to go home tonight," Evelyn announced suddenly. "I can't stand another minute in this hospital."

"Of course," Julian agreed immediately. "Resting at home would be better. Call me immediately if you feel unwell."

Evelyn nodded obediently. Within the hour, discharge papers were signed, and she was finally free from the sterile confines.

Julian escorted her to the parking lot, one protective hand hovering near her elbow.

From a shadowed corner, Victoria watched them leave, her gaze turning glacial. "Evelyn," she murmured, "you're full of secrets, aren't you?"

Her assistant nodded. "Ms. Sinclair, Evelyn probably met Julian through Harrison."

"I know," Victoria snapped. "That woman only knows how to climb using men. This time, I'll make sure she falls hard."

A cruel plan was already forming in her mind.

Inside the taxi, Evelyn suddenly sneezed. Was she catching a cold? Shrugging it off, she gave the driver her address.

When Evelyn arrived home, Margaret Dawson burst into tears. "Evelyn! This is all my fault! I should have been more vigilant - I never imagined Walter and Beverly would conspire to hurt you like this!"

"How could they plot to send you into the wilderness? No one could survive those conditions!"

Evelyn hugged her adoptive aunt. "I'm fine, see? With my brothers protecting me, nothing bad will happen."

"This time, Walter and Beverly must face consequences," Margaret declared fiercely. "They won't trouble you again."

Evelyn blinked in surprise at Margaret's uncharacteristic assertiveness. The older woman had always advocated forgiveness before.

"Evelyn, I made your favorite chicken soup," Margaret said, wiping her eyes. "Eat well and regain your strength. These past days must have been terrifying."

Evelyn obediently sipped the soup, her free hand drifting unconsciously to her still-flat stomach.

Just as she finished, Alexander and Olivia Montgomery arrived. "Evelyn," Alexander said gravely, "we need to talk."
###Chapter 271

The tense expressions on Alexander and Olivia's faces made Evelyn wonder if they were about to bring up the recent kidnapping attempt orchestrated by Walter and Beverly.

A flicker of unease passed through her. Setting down her teacup, Evelyn asked, "What did you want to talk about?"

Alexander cleared his throat. "Olivia and I have been discussing this for some time. Would you consider returning to Nord City and living with us?"

Olivia, seated beside Evelyn, gave her and Margaret a reassuring smile. "Don’t worry. If you decide to come back with us, the entire family will relocate together."

"We’ll arrange for Benjamin to be transferred to a hospital there. In Nord City, you’ll all be well taken care of."

Evelyn instinctively glanced at Margaret, whose expression remained unreadable.

Given that Evelyn was carrying Nathaniel’s child, returning to Nord City for safety reasons had crossed her mind.

But Margaret had spent her entire life in Bern City. Uprooting her completely wouldn’t be an easy decision.

Margaret hesitated before speaking. "I need some time to think about this."

Evelyn gently squeezed her hand. "Don’t let me influence your choice. I’ll stay by your side no matter where you decide to go."

"Just like we promised before—I’ll take care of you and Uncle Benjamin in your old age. That hasn’t changed."

After the tragedy that took Margaret and Benjamin’s only child, Evelyn had become the last remaining family they had left.

She knew Margaret wouldn’t stand in her way if she chose to return to Nord City. But Evelyn had no intention of leaving her behind.

Alexander interjected, "There’s no need to rush. We have time to figure this out."

"Evelyn, after what happened with your adoptive parents, Olivia and I feel responsible for not protecting you better."

Evelyn shook her head firmly. "This wasn’t your fault. I’m sure Walter and Beverly won’t dare cause trouble again after this."

Alexander’s gaze hardened. "You’re right. They won’t be a problem anymore."

This time, Evelyn’s adoptive family would face severe consequences. They’d likely spend the rest of their lives behind bars.

Soon after, Evelyn’s brothers arrived at the house. Seeing her safe, they finally relaxed.

As Evelyn yawned, everyone began to disperse.

Alexander led his brothers outside, his expression stern as he turned to Andrew. "We need to handle Evelyn’s legal separation from her adoptive parents properly this time."

"Don’t worry, Alexander. I’ve already sent someone to negotiate with them. If they want to protect their son, Edward, they’ll have to agree to the termination terms."

At first, the Montgomery brothers hadn’t paid much attention to Walter and Beverly, focusing only on rebuilding their relationship with Evelyn.

But their audacity had shocked them. This time, they were determined to end the problem for good.

Retreating to her room, Evelyn lay down, replaying the terrifying experience of her kidnapping in her mind.

It all felt like a nightmare.

Closing her eyes, she drifted into another dream—Nathaniel descending gracefully from a helicopter, dressed in tactical gear.

He stood beside a van, silently extending his hand toward her.

Her heart raced at the sight of his outstretched palm.

The next morning, Evelyn woke with the dream still fresh in her mind. She splashed cold water on her face, determined not to let Nathaniel’s kindness sway her.

After all, Evelyn and Nathaniel came from entirely different worlds.
###Chapter 272

Evelyn Carter had to maintain strict control over her emotions, especially since she planned to keep Nathaniel Whitmore from discovering she carried his child.

If he ever found out, he might demand she terminate the pregnancy. He'd made his stance on children painfully clear before.

This thought jolted Evelyn fully awake. Her fingers trembled as they brushed against her still-flat abdomen.

No matter what challenges lay ahead, Evelyn was determined to protect this baby and bring it safely into the world.

After dressing in fresh clothes, her phone buzzed with a call from Julian Montgomery. "Evelyn, your prenatal appointment is scheduled for this afternoon. Don't forget."

"I know. My classes are packed today, but I'll make time later."

Scanning her schedule, Evelyn realized her weekdays were completely booked with back-to-back lectures.

Textbooks in hand, she headed to campus. Though only a weekend had passed, it felt like months had slipped by.

At least the recent chaos had finally settled down.

Evelyn slipped into her usual seat just as Professor Elizabeth Hartwell made an announcement. "Students, we have a mandatory event this afternoon."

"Vista Properties is establishing a scholarship foundation at Halvard University."

"Going forward, outstanding students may qualify for Vista-sponsored scholarships. Let's all strive for this opportunity!"

Vista Properties?

Evelyn's mind flashed to her childhood neighborhood's redevelopment - a project deeply entangled with Vista Properties. Why did this company keep appearing in her life?

Though technically, it was Victoria Sinclair's family enterprise.

Last time, Victoria had gone so far as to threaten Evelyn over the redevelopment project.

Still, Evelyn wasn't one to be easily intimidated.

Professor Hartwell approached her directly. "Evelyn, Vista is assembling a project team. Given your exceptional skills, we're recommending you join alongside a faculty representative."

"Students from multiple universities will participate. It's a chance for Halvard to shine."

"Additionally, you could advocate for increased investment in our department - better equipment, more opportunities."

Evelyn hesitated. "Professor Hartwell, may I have time to consider?"

While she might have welcomed such an opportunity with any other company, Vista Properties made her uneasy.

She wanted nothing to do with Victoria or her family.

Despite Vista's professional reputation, Evelyn couldn't forget Victoria's underhanded tactics during the recent Fleur International Design Competition.

Though Evelyn had ultimately triumphed, she had no desire to waste energy on unnecessary drama.

"Evelyn, this is an incredible opportunity."

"As our Fleur Competition gold medalist, declining might reflect poorly on Halvard."

"Please share any concerns. The university will support you however we can."

Evelyn struggled to articulate her reservations without sounding petty.

It wasn't fear of Victoria - just profound annoyance at the situation.

After a deep breath, Evelyn relented. "Very well, I'll join the project team."

She would face this challenge head-on.

During lunch break, Sophia Bennett - who had no afternoon classes - accompanied Evelyn to Vista's scholarship foundation ceremony.

The moment they entered the venue, Evelyn caught a whiff of overpowering perfume. She didn't need to look to know its source.

Only Penelope Whitmore would drown herself in such a cloying scent.

Turning, Evelyn's suspicion was confirmed - Penelope stood arm-in-arm with Victoria.

Sophia grimaced. "Evelyn, isn't that the insufferable woman from the mall last week?"

Evelyn nodded, realizing fate had a twisted sense of humor.
###Chapter 273

The confrontation came sooner than Evelyn had expected.

Victoria Sinclair stood before her, eyes flashing with barely concealed hostility.

Penelope Whitmore smirked, inserting herself between them. "Evelyn, this event is hosted by Vista Properties. Victoria's family empire. She's in charge tonight—and she'll be giving the keynote speech."

Victoria tilted her chin up, her posture dripping with superiority. The humiliation from their last encounter still burned fresh in her memory.

Evelyn arched a brow, her voice cool. "Fascinating."

Penelope's smile turned sharp. "You should be nervous. With Victoria running things, don't even dream about that scholarship."

Evelyn's lips curled. "The scholarship isn't my priority. But Victoria, as the host, aren't you worried about the scandal if people find out you're rigging the results?"

Victoria's laugh was icy. "Who would believe you? I'm a Sinclair. Pulling strings is effortless for me. There won't be a single trace left behind—what can you possibly do?"

Penelope covered her mouth, giggling. "Exactly! But Evelyn, we're not cruel. Kneel and apologize, and maybe we'll reconsider."

"One word from Victoria, and that scholarship could still be yours."

Evelyn remained silent, unshaken.

Sophia Bennett, however, couldn't stay quiet. "You should be ashamed! What if this gets out? Do you really think you'll walk away unscathed?"

Penelope rolled her eyes. "Oh please. Who would take the word of a nobody like you?"

Evelyn's expression darkened. "You'd be surprised."

She pulled out her phone, waving it lightly. "I recorded everything. Imagine the uproar if this went viral. It'd make your little scandal look tame, Penelope."

Victoria's face paled. Penelope lunged for the phone, but Evelyn stepped back, tucking it away.

"Too late. It's already backed up. Destroying my phone won't help you."

Penelope's jaw clenched. "You wouldn't dare."

"Watch me."

Evelyn unlocked her phone, fingers hovering over her social media.

Victoria grabbed her wrist, panic flickering in her eyes. "Stop."

Evelyn smirked. "Why? Feeling nervous?"

Victoria swallowed hard. "What do you want?"

If Alexander saw this, her reputation would be ruined. She couldn't afford another blow—not after nearly losing her place in the company.

Evelyn spun her phone between her fingers. "Simple. Apologize for your threats, and I won't post it."

Penelope scoffed. "Apologize? Are you insane?"

She turned to Victoria. "Don't let her scare you. You're a Sinclair. Your brother would never believe her over you. We can just say the video's fake."
###Chapter 274

Victoria's eyes flashed with irritation as she labeled Penelope as the perpetual source of ridiculous schemes.

If not for their shared last name "Whitmore," Victoria would have cut ties with Penelope long ago.

Taking a steadying breath, Victoria turned to Evelyn. "I was only joking earlier. Did you actually believe I meant it?"

"My brother despises any form of manipulation or interference in professional matters. I would never stoop to such behavior."

Standing beside Victoria, Penelope clenched her fists in frustration. Why did Victoria have to show weakness in front of Evelyn?

Sophia scoffed. "Ms. Sinclair, what’s your problem? If you don’t know how to apologize, let me teach you. An apology requires saying the words 'I’m sorry'!"

Victoria was nearing her limit.

Evelyn glanced around. "With the crowd growing, I was considering uploading the video to the campus network right before the scholarship ceremony."

"Imagine revealing the backdoor dealings at such a pivotal moment—wouldn’t that be entertaining?"

Victoria finally relented. "Evelyn, I spoke out of turn earlier. I shouldn’t have made such a joke. I sincerely apologize."

"Victoria, did you just apologize?" Penelope couldn’t believe her ears.

She glared at Evelyn. "I won’t apologize to you. If you want to release the video, go ahead. My reputation is already ruined because of you. One more scandal won’t break me."

Evelyn’s smirk widened. "Is that so? Then I won’t hold back."

A chill ran down Victoria’s spine. "But Evelyn, I’ve already apologized."

Evelyn’s gaze turned icy. "You were both involved. This is collective punishment."

Furious, Victoria yanked Penelope aside and hissed, "Penelope, didn’t you want me to introduce you to Sebastian?"

"Let me remind you—Sebastian despises women who engage in underhanded tactics. If he finds out about this, any chance with him will vanish."

"No, please!"

The mention of Sebastian shattered Penelope’s defiance. He was the man she had set her sights on.

Victoria feigned helplessness. "I’ve said all I can. The choice is yours."

"But Victoria, why should we fear Evelyn? Won’t your brother support you?"

"Penelope, this is my personal matter. If I keep relying on my brother to clean up my messes, won’t I seem incompetent? I refuse to leave that impression."

Grudgingly, Penelope approached Evelyn. "I apologize."

Sophia rolled her eyes. "That’s the most insincere apology I’ve ever heard."

Biting back her anger, Penelope forced out, "I genuinely apologize! Happy now?"

Evelyn tugged Sophia’s arm, radiating indifference. "Barely passable. Let’s hope there’s no next time. Come on, Sophia."

"Wait."

Victoria blocked their path. "Evelyn, we’ve apologized. Now delete the video."

Penelope nodded. "We won’t feel safe until it’s gone."

Evelyn’s lips curled. "No need."

Victoria paled. "Evelyn, are you going back on your word? Provoking the Sinclair family isn’t a game you can win."

"At worst, I’ll just apologize to my brother and end this quickly."

Evelyn waved her phone lazily. "What I mean is, there’s nothing to delete. I didn’t record anything."
###Chapter 275

The moment Evelyn revealed the truth, she immediately noticed the shift in Victoria and Penelope's expressions.

Their faces darkened with barely contained fury.

Penelope's voice trembled with outrage. "Evelyn, how dare you play us for fools?"

A smirk curled Evelyn's lips. "Oh, but I did. And you both played your parts perfectly. Can't handle the truth?"

Penelope's hands clenched into fists, her body tensing as if ready to strike.

Evelyn tilted her head, feigning indifference. "Think carefully before you act. There are witnesses everywhere. Do you really want to explain why you assaulted me in public?"

"I don't owe anyone an explanation!" Penelope snapped.

Victoria intervened, gripping Penelope's arm. "Let's go. We have more important matters than wasting time on her."

Evelyn had a point. As a public figure at this event, Penelope couldn't afford a scandal.

Victoria found Evelyn infuriating. Being with Julian had clearly made her bolder. But her victory wouldn't last.

As the two women stormed off, Evelyn finally looked away.

Beside her, Sophia burst into laughter. "Oh my god, Evelyn, that was priceless!"

"The look on their faces when you admitted there was no recording—absolutely classic."

Evelyn's smile turned icy. "Sometimes, being ruthless is the only way to survive."

"True," Sophia agreed. "But Evelyn, what about that woman with Penelope? The one who reeks of fake sweetness?"

"Victoria Sinclair. Sister of the owner of Vista Properties."

Sophia's eyes widened. "Wait—the one who was desperate to marry your ex-husband?"

"That's her."

Evelyn lowered her gaze. "Though my marriage to Nathaniel ended abruptly too."

A question still nagged at her. Why had Nathaniel called off his engagement with Victoria?

Hadn't he worried her brother would refuse to perform Eleanor's surgery out of spite?

She had asked Nathaniel at the hospital, but their conversation had been interrupted by her brothers.

"Evelyn," Sophia said hesitantly, "you handled that well, but aren't you worried about retaliation? These elite families don’t take humiliation lightly."

"Sophia, trouble finds me whether I provoke it or not."

"Besides, I plan to return to Nord City after graduation. The Whitmores won’t matter to me anymore."

Evelyn had already arranged to leave Bern City once she completed her credits—just in time before her pregnancy became obvious.

She intended to give birth in Nord City, where her child would be safe.

Sophia hugged her. "I’m glad you’ll be back home. I’ll visit you all the time."

"You’re always welcome."

Evelyn considered telling Sophia about the baby but decided against it. That revelation could wait.

Her thoughts drifted back to Eleanor’s surgery, her fingers tightening around her clutch.

Hours later, the scholarship foundation ceremony concluded.

Victoria, as the representative, gave a polished speech, basking in the audience’s admiration.

Evelyn didn’t stay. She and Sophia slipped out of the auditorium.

She had only attended to fulfill her sociology requirement.

"Evelyn, wait!"

Penelope caught up, her tone dripping with false sweetness. "Leaving so soon? We’re dining with the university board. You should join us."
###Chapter 276



"Sorry, I'm busy." Evelyn said flatly.

She had no interest in joining the group for dinner or socializing. Not when she was carrying a child.

"Evelyn, this is a major project for our college. Don't you care at all?" Penelope pressed, frustration creeping into her voice.

"Not my problem," Evelyn replied coolly, her expression unreadable.

Penelope clenched her fists. It was like Evelyn had become an entirely different person—untouchable, indifferent, impossible to manipulate.

"Evelyn, don’t let arrogance ruin you," Penelope hissed.

"Honestly, I find it amusing watching you all seethe when you can’t stand me but can’t do a thing about it. Bye!" With a smirk, Evelyn turned on her heel and walked away.

Penelope’s face burned with fury.

She whirled toward Victoria, voice sharp. "Did you see that? She just walked out on us! Since when did Evelyn become so untouchable? She dismissed us like we’re nothing!"

Victoria’s expression darkened. She knew exactly where Evelyn’s newfound confidence came from—her entanglement with both Nathaniel and Harrison.

She had underestimated Evelyn’s cunning, but she wouldn’t make that mistake again.

Without hesitation, Victoria pulled out her phone and dialed. "Mr. Harrison? It’s Victoria. I heard Vista Properties is planning a major redevelopment project in Bern City."

"I’d love to get some firsthand experience. Would it be possible for me to visit the branch office and observe?"

On the other end, Maxwell answered smoothly. "Of course, Ms. Sinclair. You’re welcome anytime."

"Perfect. I’ll be there soon."

Hanging up, Victoria’s lips curled into a cold smile. "Let’s see how long Evelyn stays this arrogant."

Penelope grinned. "This is perfect. If that demolition project falls through, she’ll be crawling back to us on her knees."



Victoria scoffed. Did Evelyn really think someone of her background could compete with her?

Meanwhile, Evelyn returned home to find her three brothers lounging on the couch, all watching her expectantly.

She paused. "Chris, Andrew, Daniel… what’s going on?"

Daniel grinned. "Guess what? I just won a million dollars in the lottery."

Evelyn blinked. "Seriously?"

She hadn’t expected such luck in her own family. Smiling, she said, "Congratulations, Daniel."

He waved it off. "Not a big deal. I invested it all in Harrison’s entertainment company. It’s about to go public—so I’m basically rich now."

He smirked, then added, "Oh, and Andrew started his own business. It’s doing pretty well."

Andrew nodded. "I opened a chain of piano academies in Nord City. It’s franchising now, so money’s not an issue."

Evelyn feigned envy. "Damn, why is everyone getting rich except me? But honestly, I’m happy for you guys."

Daniel ruffled her hair affectionately. "From now on, you don’t have to worry about anything. Come back to Nord City with us and live the easy life."

After the kidnapping, Daniel had noticed how guarded Evelyn had become.

No more pretending. He’d make sure she never had to struggle again.
###Chapter 277

The moment had come.

After lengthy discussions with Andrew and Christopher, Daniel and his brothers reached a unanimous decision—it was time to drop their pretense of financial struggle.

Evelyn deserved to know they could be her unshakable pillars of support.

Christopher nodded in agreement with Andrew's words. "Evelyn, your brothers and I are now in a stable financial position. Sebastian's company has also successfully gone public."

"With these developments, our family is no longer lacking in resources. From now on, you can buy whatever your heart desires without hesitation."

Evelyn was momentarily speechless, overwhelmed by their sincerity. "Then I’ll work even harder," she finally said. "I want to become a renowned designer—someone who won’t be a burden to any of you."

Hearing her determined words, Daniel felt his eyes sting. They had hoped she would lean on them, but her fierce independence and ambition left them both surprised and deeply moved.

How could she be so relentlessly hardworking and yet so utterly endearing?

As dusk settled, Alexander, Sebastian, and Julian returned home to find Evelyn preparing a celebratory feast in their honor.

Raising her teacup, she beamed. "Tonight, I toast to my brothers with tea instead of wine. May your paths to success be swift and prosperous. Cheers!"

Though Alexander was slightly irked that his younger brothers had acted without consulting him, seeing Evelyn’s radiant happiness made him question whether keeping his own wealth a secret had been the right choice.

Olivia gently took Evelyn’s hand. "Darling, leave the pursuit of wealth to your brothers. Like me, you should enjoy the comforts of home and indulge in shopping."

"There’s no need for you to exhaust yourself. You’re the treasured princess of this family."

Alexander nodded firmly. "Exactly. Once you return to Nord City with us, you won’t have to work so hard anymore."

Then, without warning, Daniel slid a bank card across the table. "Evelyn, there’s enough here to pay off your mortgage. I have more than enough to spare."

One by one, the Montgomery brothers followed suit, each presenting her with their own cards. "Consider this our heartfelt gesture," Julian said softly. "Please accept it."

Evelyn stared at the six gleaming cards, momentarily stunned. After a brief pause, she smiled and gathered them all. "Alright, I won’t hold back then."



She understood their intentions—this was their way of making amends. Rejecting their generosity would only hurt them.

Truthfully, Evelyn had long let go of past grievances. She had fully embraced the joy of having brothers who cherished her.

Later that night, after her usual routine, Evelyn laid the six bank cards on her dresser.

A thought crossed her mind—Victoria’s endless bragging about her own brothers. With a smirk, Evelyn snapped a photo and posted it on her social media with the caption: Life’s ultimate goal: Work hard today, be a wealthy woman tomorrow.

A satisfied smile curved her lips. Now, she too had brothers who spoiled her relentlessly.

Meanwhile, Nathaniel had just finished a grueling meeting. As he scrolled through his notifications, Evelyn’s latest post caught his eye.

Against his better judgment, he tapped on her profile and saw the photo of the bank cards.

His expression darkened as he read her caption. Since when had Evelyn’s values become so materialistic?

What unsettled him more was Eleanor’s immediate like and comment: "Well said, darling."

Nathaniel’s grip on his phone tightened.

Before he could process his irritation, Eleanor’s call came through. He adjusted his tie and answered with forced calm. "Hello, Grandmother."

"Nathaniel, I never took you for the romantic type," Eleanor teased.

His brows furrowed. "What do you mean?"

"I saw Evelyn’s post. Those bank cards are from you, aren’t they? Now that she’s expecting, you should spoil her more."

"While Evelyn isn’t materialistic, every woman adores thoughtful surprises from her husband."
###Chapter 278



Eleanor Whitmore's words sent Nathaniel into a rage. With a sharp tug, he ripped off his tie, the silk fabric crumpling in his fist.

Evelyn actually thought he was the one who gave her those bank cards in the photo?

The realization stung. He had trusted her, only for her to flaunt such recklessness. Clearly, they needed to talk.

"Nat, I believe in you. Don't disappoint me," Eleanor teased, her voice laced with amusement.

But Nathaniel found no comfort in her words. Instead, frustration coiled tighter in his chest.

Clutching his phone, he stormed out of the study. The villa’s halls were as familiar as ever, yet something—or rather, someone—was missing.

Back in his bedroom, he fired off a text to Evelyn: "Care to explain your Instagram post?"

Evelyn had just finished her nighttime routine, her skin still warm from the shower, when the notification lit up her screen.

She blinked. Hadn’t they unfollowed each other?

Then it hit her—she’d re-followed him to return the hundred thousand dollars Julian had taken. Nathaniel had never accepted the transfer.

But why was he messaging her now, his tone icy?

Her fingers flew across the screen. "If you can’t figure it out, why bother looking?"

His reply was immediate. "Who gave you those six cards?"

She smirked. "Six different men, obviously."

Nathaniel’s jaw clenched. The memory of those well-dressed men at the hospital—undoubtedly from the Montgomery family—flashed in his mind.

Something wasn’t adding up.

He meant to call her, but his thumb slipped, hitting the video button instead.

Evelyn’s breath hitched when the invitation popped up. In three years of marriage, Nathaniel had never video-called her.

But then she remembered the mountains, the terror of being kidnapped—how he’d come for her without hesitation.

Swallowing hard, she answered. "Hello. What do you want?"

Nathaniel froze. He hadn’t expected her to pick up.

The screen showed Evelyn propped against her headboard, damp hair curling over the straps of her silk camisole. His gaze darkened.

"Don’t play dumb," he said, voice rough. "You know why I’m calling."

Evelyn arched a brow. "Enlighten me."

"I never took you for someone so shallow."

She laughed, sharp and bitter. "Really? Took you long enough. I’ve always valued appearances. Handsome face, good values—that’s why I fell for you."

Nathaniel stiffened.

"And now?" he asked quietly.

Evelyn’s fingers tightened around her phone. Even through the screen, he was unfairly attractive.

"What do you mean, now?"

"You said you loved me."

"That was then." She forced a smirk. "Plenty of fish in the sea, Nathaniel. If one doesn’t work out, I’ll find another."

The words twisted like a knife in his chest.

Evelyn’s view on love was fickle—one moment burning hot, the next ice-cold.

Silence stretched between them, thick and suffocating.

Finally, Nathaniel changed tactics. "Evelyn. What’s really going on between you and Julian?"
###Chapter 279

Evelyn recognized that familiar tone in Nathaniel's voice—the one laced with arrogance and interrogation. His piercing gaze hadn't changed one bit.

She ran her fingers through her still-damp hair, a playful smirk tugging at her lips. "Why don't you figure it out yourself?"

Nathaniel's eyes flickered, catching the subtle shift in her posture.

Her hair tumbled over one shoulder, and the delicate strap of her silk nightgown slipped, baring a tantalizing expanse of sun-kissed skin that gleamed under the dim glow of her bedside lamp.

The sight was undeniably provocative.

Nathaniel stiffened, caught off guard.

His throat tightened, his stare darkening. Was she doing this on purpose?

Yet Evelyn seemed entirely unaware of the effect she was having.

When Nathaniel fell silent during their video call, she tilted her head. "Anything else? If not, I'm hanging up."

"Evelyn," he bit out, "you still haven't answered me. Don't think dressing like this will distract me. Even if you stripped right now, it wouldn’t work."

What was he talking about? She was just wearing a normal nightgown.

Glancing down, Evelyn gasped. The strap had slipped completely off her shoulder.

One wrong move, and she would’ve been exposed. Heat flooded her cheeks as she abruptly ended the call.

Fumbling, she yanked the strap back into place, then buried her face in her hands, mortified.

Did that insufferable man really think she was trying to seduce him?

The audacity!

She wanted to drag Nathaniel by the collar and scream at him. Who in their right mind would try to lure him in like this?

But she let it go. In a few months, once she finished her studies and her pregnancy became more noticeable, she’d leave for Nord City to have the baby.

If she was leaving anyway, why waste energy on Nathaniel?

The next morning, Evelyn had planned to go for her prenatal checkup.

But Julian texted, saying he had an appointment in the morning and suggested she come in the afternoon.

Right now, Julian was the only person she fully trusted.

Without him there, the checkup would feel incomplete. So she agreed to reschedule.

Instead, Evelyn decided to visit Eleanor at the private hospital. Eleanor had left a cryptic comment on her social media post yesterday.

Given Nathaniel’s recent decision to call off his engagement with Victoria, Evelyn needed to confirm whether Eleanor’s surgery was still happening as planned.

Before heading to the hospital, she picked up fresh flowers and a basket of fruit.

As she neared Eleanor’s room, muffled voices drifted into the hallway.

Peering through the slightly ajar door, she spotted doctors and nurses gathered inside. Had something gone wrong?

Panic seized her. She rushed in, calling out, "Grandma Eleanor!"

Then she froze.

Among the medical staff stood Julian—wearing a white coat.

What was he doing here?

Earlier, when Julian mentioned his morning commitment, Evelyn assumed it was a surgery. But she never expected to find him here.

Was he switching careers?

Julian’s expression faltered when he saw her. This was not how he wanted her to find out.

Today, he was overseeing Eleanor’s pre-op evaluations.

Given the complexity of her upcoming procedure, it required extensive tests and a detailed surgical plan.

Julian had deliberately scheduled this visit early, intending to return to Evelyn later.

But fate had other plans.

His stomach twisted. Was this the moment his secret would unravel?

Evelyn’s pulse quickened. Would Julian discover the truth about her and Nathaniel today?
###Chapter 280



Julian and Evelyn exchanged uneasy glances, their eyes flickering with unspoken tension.

Eleanor broke the silence first, waving at Evelyn with a warm smile. "Evelyn, darling! Don't just linger by the door—come in."

Forcing a polite smile, Evelyn reluctantly stepped forward. Her gaze briefly caught the fresh flowers in the vase before she turned to Eleanor. "How have you been feeling lately?"

"I’ve been quite well," Eleanor replied, taking Evelyn’s hand and studying her closely. "But you, my dear, look more exhausted than last time. Is your workload too demanding?"

Evelyn cleared her throat softly. "Not exactly. I’ve actually gained some weight recently."

She had been meticulously watching her diet, terrified that any noticeable change might reveal the secret she carried—her growing belly, the undeniable proof of her pregnancy.

"Gained weight?" Eleanor frowned, shaking her head. "Nonsense. You look thinner, if anything."

She squeezed Evelyn’s hand gently. "Remember, you're not just caring for yourself anymore. There’s a little one depending on you now. Don’t push yourself too hard."

Evelyn’s pulse spiked. Please, Eleanor, don’t say another word.

Running into Julian today had already been disastrous.

And now, Eleanor had unwittingly exposed her secret. How could she possibly explain this to Julian?

With a strained smile, Evelyn replied, "My workload isn’t too heavy, really."

Eleanor tutted. "Evelyn, I have no issue with you working, but circumstances have changed. You must prioritize your health. After the baby arrives, there will be plenty of time to return to your career."

She winked playfully. "I could even speak to Nathaniel about securing you a designer position at Whitmore Enterprises. As the young Mrs. Whitmore, no one would dare mistreat you."

Evelyn’s heart sank.

There was no salvaging this now. Eleanor had shattered the careful illusion Evelyn had maintained in front of Julian.



Evelyn refused to look in Julian’s direction, her stomach twisting with dread.

Instead, she kept her focus on Eleanor. "Grandmother, I understand. Please don’t worry about me."

Eleanor nodded firmly. "I know you value your independence, but I’ll speak to Nathaniel. When you’re ready to return, he’ll ensure you’re well taken care of. It’s settled."

Evelyn sighed inwardly. "We’ll discuss it when the time comes."

What Eleanor didn’t know was that Evelyn wouldn’t even be in Bern City by then.

Of course, she couldn’t reveal that now.

If the Whitmores discovered her pregnancy, escaping would become impossible—and protecting her child even harder.

Julian finally spoke up, his voice tight. "Grandmother, your checkup is finished. You should rest now."

Eleanor nodded, and the butler promptly ushered the medical team out.

Evelyn risked a glance at Julian, her anxiety spiking. How was she going to explain this?

Moments later, her phone buzzed with a message from Julian:

"Meet me outside. Now."

Evelyn exhaled shakily. There was no avoiding this conversation.

Sooner or later, this confrontation was inevitable.

After lingering a few more minutes with Eleanor, Evelyn excused herself, claiming she wanted to wash some fruit.

Tray in hand, she stepped out of the room—and found Julian waiting, his expression unreadable.

Without preamble, he demanded, "Evelyn. What exactly is your relationship with Nathaniel Whitmore?"
###Chapter 281

Evelyn let out a weary sigh as her gaze swept across the hospital corridor. "Julian, come with me. We need to talk privately."

"Do we really have to move? Can't we just speak here?" Julian's face twisted with visible reluctance, his fingers tightening around his medical clipboard.

With gentle insistence, Evelyn tugged at the sleeve of his white coat. "Please, Julian. This isn't the right place. We might disturb Grandma Eleanor."

After a tense moment, Julian finally relented.

She led him to a secluded corner at the far end of the hallway. Lowering her voice, Evelyn began nervously, "Julian, let me explain..."

"Yeah, I'm all ears." Julian's jaw tightened. "Tell me everything about your relationship with Nathaniel, and whose child you're carrying."

Evelyn drew a shaky breath before confessing, "By now you must have guessed... the baby is Nathaniel's."

"What?" Julian's face darkened instantly. "That bastard forced himself on you? I swear to God, I'll make him pay for this!"

Seeing Julian's mounting rage, Evelyn quickly grabbed his arm. "Julian, please calm down!"

"Calm down? After what he did to you?" Julian's eyes burned with fury. His mind raced with violent scenarios of revenge against Nathaniel Whitmore.

Evelyn's pulse quickened at his reaction. "Just listen to me first!"

"There's nothing to explain! Evelyn, you should go home. Once I deal with Nathaniel, I'll take you back to Northridge myself. No one will ever hurt you again."

"Julian, it's not what you think!"

He turned to her with protective determination. "Evelyn, you don't have to be afraid anymore. Before, you were alone and vulnerable. But now you have six brothers who would burn the world for you."

"Andrew's a lawyer - he'll make sure Nathaniel rots in prison for what he's done."

Evelyn winced at his words. "Julian, I don't think the law applies here..."

"Sexual harassment is a crime, Evelyn! It doesn't matter if he's the CEO of Whitmore Enterprises or the damn president!"

Clearing her throat, Evelyn admitted quietly, "We're still legally married, Julian. The baby was conceived during our marriage. Technically... it wasn't harassment."

The revelation hit Julian like a physical blow. He staggered back against the wall, his face draining of color.

"Julian!" Evelyn rushed to steady him.

"I'm... I'm fine," he managed, though his voice shook. "Just trying to process this. You're telling me you're married to Nathaniel Whitmore?"

Evelyn nodded meekly.

"Why didn't you tell us something this important? Were you planning to hide this forever if I hadn't discovered your pregnancy?"

"It... it was an arranged marriage," Evelyn whispered. "I never wanted anyone to know about our relationship."

"Evelyn, we're your family!" Julian's voice cracked with emotion. "You should have come to us!"
###Chapter 282

The realization hit Julian like a tidal wave—the woman who had married the comatose Nathaniel all those years ago was none other than Evelyn, his own sister!

A storm of emotions raged within him. Anger. Regret. Guilt.

Victoria had wanted to marry Nathaniel but was stopped by Alexander. In the end, she had given up, likely assuming Nathaniel wouldn’t survive.

Then, the Whitmores announced someone had agreed to the marriage.

Now, Julian wished they had found Evelyn sooner. If only they had known…

Evelyn’s voice trembled with remorse. "I know I was wrong. We weren’t close at first, so I didn’t know how to tell you. And we were already considering divorce—I thought it would be better to just let it go."

Besides, the Whitmores were one of the most powerful families in Bern City.

She hadn’t wanted to burden her brothers with the mess.

She lifted her gaze, eyes glistening. "I’m sorry. I should have told you."

Julian exhaled deeply, his hand gently resting on her head. "Don’t apologize. We’re the ones who failed you. If we had found you earlier… you wouldn’t have suffered like this."

What was done couldn’t be undone. He couldn’t bring himself to blame her.

No wonder Nathaniel had moved so swiftly when he learned of her kidnapping.

After a tense discussion, Julian and Alexander agreed—they would keep a close watch on Nathaniel, who clearly still had feelings for Evelyn.

Who could have guessed? Married for three years. And with a child.

Julian’s gaze darkened as he studied her. "Evelyn… did the Whitmores let you go knowing you were pregnant?"

She shook her head. "They didn’t believe me. Mrs. Whitmore only agreed to the surgery if I got pregnant. I had to lie, but they thought I was faking it. So I played along."

The full picture was finally clear.

Julian’s jaw tightened. "Disgusting. Evelyn, were you forced into this marriage?"

"No." Her voice was firm. "I chose it. Because I loved him."

His hands clenched. Every word was a knife to his heart.

She forced a weak smile. "I’ve decided to move on. But I have to keep up appearances until Mrs. Whitmore’s surgery is over. She’s been kind to me."

Julian hesitated. "Evelyn… are you sure you can let him go? If not… maybe you shouldn’t keep the baby."

Her fingers curled protectively over her stomach. "I want this child, Julian. Before I found you all, this baby was my only family. I won’t abandon them just because I have you now."

His heart shattered.

The thought of her, alone, with only this unborn child as her anchor—it was unbearable.

He pulled her into a tight embrace, his voice rough. "Alright. Keep the baby."

Whatever she asked, he would give.

They owed her that much. More than they could ever repay.

Evelyn buried her face against his shoulder, discreetly wiping away tears.

At least he understood.

Then—a prickle of awareness.

Someone was watching.

The weight of that gaze made her skin crawl.
###Chapter 283

Evelyn lifted her gaze to find Nathaniel standing a short distance away, his eyes glinting with something dark and unreadable.

Her breath caught in her throat.

Why was Nathaniel here? The timing couldn’t have been worse.

If Julian spotted him, the situation would spiral out of control.

Thinking fast, Evelyn tugged Julian’s arm sharply, pulling his attention away from the corridor where Nathaniel stood.

A distraction—she needed one now.

"Julian," she said quickly, "I almost forgot to ask—how is Mrs. Whitmore Senior doing? Why are you the one handling her examination today?"

The question caught him off guard, a flicker of guilt crossing his face. "Didn’t I mention her case is complicated? A surgery like hers requires extra hands. We need to be prepared for any emergencies."

Evelyn vaguely recalled him saying something similar. Still, his presence here made sense.

He cleared his throat, masking his unease. "Now that you mention it, I just remembered I have a meeting to attend—about Mrs. Whitmore Senior’s surgery."

Without another word, Julian turned and strode away. Evelyn’s pulse spiked.

Nathaniel was still here.

But when she glanced back at the corridor, he was gone.

Where had he disappeared to?

Relief loosened the tension in her shoulders. She called after Julian, "Will the surgery still proceed as scheduled?"

"Of course," he replied, though a hint of nervousness colored his tone.

Had she noticed something was off?

Evelyn hesitated before pressing further. "Julian, I heard the lead surgeon is one of the best in Nord City. And that his sister—Victoria—has feelings for Nathaniel. After everything that’s happened, I thought he might refuse to operate."

She was testing him.

Julian understood exactly what she was implying.

Nathaniel had broken off his engagement with Victoria because Julian had revealed he only agreed to the surgery for Evelyn’s sake.

It had been a warning—stay away from her.

But Julian never expected them to already be married. If he had known, he would never have interfered. Never.

Regret twisted inside him.

If he had realized their relationship sooner, he would have taken Evelyn far from Nord City, away from the Whitmore family’s tangled affairs.

"Don’t worry," he said smoothly. "A renowned surgeon is handling the procedure. I promise."

"Does this surgeon attend meetings with the other doctors?"

The question caught him off guard.

His words stumbled. "Why do you ask? Do you want to meet him?"

What if she did? How would he explain?

Hire an imposter?

Evelyn shook her head. "No, just curious. It doesn’t matter if I meet him. The only thing that matters is the surgery’s success."

That surgeon was Victoria’s brother. If Evelyn showed her face, his resentment might jeopardize everything.

What would she do then?

She could only hope things would go smoothly.

Julian exhaled in quiet relief.

It was better this way.

Otherwise, he wouldn’t know how to explain the truth.
###Chapter 284

Evelyn noticed the strange look on Julian's face. Something wasn't right.

"Julian, you're not yourself today."

"Am I? Must be work stress," he deflected, avoiding her gaze.

"Go ahead. Don’t you have a meeting? I’ll stay with Grandma Eleanor," Evelyn said, deciding not to push further.

He nodded. "I’ll pick you up later for your prenatal checkup."

Watching her grow closer to the Whitmores was the last thing he wanted. But he knew how deeply Evelyn cared for them.

Before the Montgomery brothers took her in, Eleanor had been the one to look after her. He couldn’t just tear her away.

Once he got her out of Nord City, away from the Whitmores, everything would be settled.

Evelyn watched Julian descend the stairs, exhaling softly.

After washing some fruit, she headed toward the patient’s room. The door swung open just as she approached.

Nathaniel stepped out, blocking her path. His towering frame loomed over her, intensifying the tension.

Holding the bowl of fruit, Evelyn met his piercing gaze.

He lowered his voice. "Evelyn Carter, I don’t care about your personal life. But this is the hospital where my grandmother is staying. Have you considered the consequences if she catches you two?"

She swallowed the bitterness in her throat. "I’m not here to argue. Grandma’s surgery is soon. Please move."

His warm fingers wrapped around her wrist. "Do you think I’m trying to fight with you? If you’re so eager to throw yourself at another man, fine. But I have one condition—don’t let Grandma find out before her surgery."

She yanked her arm free. "Don’t worry. I won’t tell her. Meanwhile, you’re the one engaged in scandals. Maybe you should be more careful."

Nathaniel stiffened at her words, his expression darkening. "You don’t get to say that. If it weren’t for you—"

"Enough. I don’t want to hear about your engagement," she cut him off.

Did she have anything to do with it being called off? How could he blame her?

She squared her shoulders. "Mr. Whitmore, from now on, let’s only discuss Grandma. Nothing else. Once her surgery is over, we’ll finalize the divorce and go our separate ways."

Frustration coiled inside him as he studied her resolute expression.

Earlier, he’d nearly lost control when he saw her in Julian’s arms.

But why? Why did her actions affect him like this?

It shouldn’t matter who she was with.

Yet, he couldn’t shake the turmoil she stirred in him. This was unfamiliar. Uncontrollable.

He released her, his gaze conflicted. "Evelyn, I’ll say this once—you and Julian aren’t right for each other."

His misunderstanding amused her. She tilted her head, a smirk playing on her lips. "Nathaniel Whitmore, are you jealous?"
###Chapter 285



Evelyn Carter lifted her gaze, studying Nathaniel Whitmore intently. His handsome features reflected in her luminous hazel eyes.

They stood in the hospital corridor where golden sunlight streamed through the windows, carrying the scent of summer blossoms.

Nathaniel saw his own reflection in her eyes, his pulse quickening inexplicably.

"Evelyn Carter, you've grown bolder since we last met. Do I look like a man who has feelings for you?" His denial came too quickly.

Despite his stern expression, his eyes betrayed hesitation. He adjusted his tie nervously, a telltale sign of his inner turmoil.

Nathaniel's jaw clenched visibly. "Mark my words, Evelyn Carter. You'll regret this."

"Evelyn, did you see Nathaniel? He came by earlier."

She hesitated. "No."

The immediate lie sent a pang of guilt through her.

Eleanor Whitmore grasped Evelyn's hand. "You must have missed him. He went downstairs for my surgery consultation. He should return soon."

Evelyn's expression faltered. Nathaniel attended the consultation?

This was disastrous! Julian Montgomery was downstairs too!

Only then did she realize Nathaniel had gone the same direction as Julian. Why hadn't she noticed sooner?



What now? Would they come to blows if Julian saw Nathaniel?

Anxiety twisted Evelyn's stomach. "Grandmother, I should attend that meeting too."

She needed to monitor the situation. If violence erupted, she could intervene.

Eleanor frowned. "Whatever for? Nathaniel's presence suffices. Those medical discussions are dreadfully dull. Keep me company instead."

Evelyn forced a smile. She didn't care about the meeting - she needed to prevent a confrontation.

"Grandmother, you don't understand my predicament," she thought desperately.

What excuse could she use to attend?

Downstairs, nearly every specialist gathered in the conference room to finalize surgical details.

As lead surgeon, Julian Montgomery occupied the central position, meticulously outlining critical procedure points.

Nathaniel sat in the front row, visibly irritated by Julian's presence but restraining himself - Julian was Eleanor's surgeon after all.

Julian noticed Nathaniel immediately. Ice flashed in his steel-gray eyes at the sight of his rival.

This bastard secretly married Evelyn? Impregnated her? The thought of her nearly becoming a widow made Julian's blood boil.

Neither man wanted this encounter.

The medical team praised Julian's expertise. "Dr. Montgomery, your insights were invaluable. We'll ensure everything proceeds flawlessly."
###Chapter 286

Julian nodded. "I'm not the only surgeon involved in this procedure. I'll need everyone's cooperation."

Thankfully, she'd arrived before things escalated.

Evelyn glanced back at Nathaniel, who remained rooted in place.

His expression was unreadable, something dark and turbulent in his gaze.

A strange pang twisted her chest, and she quickly looked away.

She must be imagining things.

Why would he look at her like that?

Nathaniel watched them leave, his jaw clenched as their intertwined hands burned into his vision.

Once they were gone, he loosened his tie and turned to Robert. "Tell me, does Evelyn have terrible taste? Of all people, she chooses Victoria's brother."

Robert hesitated. "I think she still cares for you. Why not win her back, Mr. Whitmore?"

Nathaniel stiffened. "What for? Don't be ridiculous."

Nathaniel always said the opposite of what he meant when it came to women.

Ever since Evelyn accepted the divorce without protest, he'd been acting out of character.

"I knew it! You're pregnant, Evelyn Carter! You're finished!"

Cassandra Blake smirked. "That's right. It's me."

This was their first encounter since the demolition incident.
###Chapter 287

"That’s right. It’s me." The woman yanked off her mask.

It was indeed Cassandra Blake!

This was their first encounter since the demolition incident.
###Chapter 288

"Why would I care?" Cassandra Blake sneered, her fingers tightening around the ultrasound report. "Evelyn Carter, you're carrying another man's child, aren't you? Is it him? I've finally caught you red-handed!"

The words gave Cassandra pause.

After the neighborhood demolition incident, they'd arranged for Cassandra to spend two weeks in police custody.

She should've learned her lesson, yet here she was, stirring trouble again.

Cassandra paled and bolted before they could react.

Julian gave chase, but she disappeared around a corner with surprising speed.

Evelyn touched his arm. "Let her go."

"But what if she tells the Whitmores about your pregnancy?"

Evelyn inhaled deeply. "No one would believe her. Besides, I have a plan. Trust me."

"I'll have your hospital records altered," Julian said immediately. "If the Whitmores investigate, they'll find nothing."

"Perfect." She carefully folded the ultrasound into her purse.

Nothing would harm these babies. Not while she breathed. There were still tests to complete today.

Julian remained uneasy.

While Evelyn underwent her examination, he made a call. "Find Cassandra Blake. Silence her. Permanently."

Until Evelyn's brothers returned to Nord City, Nathaniel Whitmore could never learn about these babies.

Though Julian didn't fear Nathaniel personally, a custody battle with the powerful Whitmore family would be disastrous.

Most importantly, Julian needed Evelyn to sever all ties with Nathaniel - before complications arose.

Meanwhile, Cassandra ran like the devil chased her, terrified Julian might catch up.

Fumbling with her phone, she tried calling Penelope repeatedly.

No answer.

Panic set in.

Why wasn't Penelope picking up?

Desperate, Cassandra sent a text: 'I have Evelyn Carter's ultrasound report.'

The moment the message delivered, a wicked grin spread across her face.

She didn't care what Penelope planned to do with the information - only that it would be valuable.

Cassandra needed money. Badly.

When Penelope finally called back, Cassandra's eyes lit up with greed.

Her fingers had just grazed the answer button when a strong hand clamped over her mouth.

Darkness swallowed her consciousness.

The phone kept ringing, unanswered.

She hung up, certain Cassandra would call back after seeing the missed calls.

###Chapter 289

If Evelyn was indeed carrying a child - regardless of who the father was - Victoria would ensure that pregnancy never came to term.

Margaret kept glancing at her phone like it might explode.

"Of course! I even took photos of the paperwork. The account number matches perfectly."

"Shoot."

Her natural aptitude for technology had surprised even herself.

When Cassandra had spread those vicious rumors at university, Sebastian had traced the IP address effortlessly.

That incident had sparked Evelyn's interest, leading to these secret hacking lessons.
###Chapter 290

The sun was just beginning to rise when Evelyn Carter first dipped her toes into the world of hacking. What started as curiosity had now turned into something far more serious—she was making rapid progress, faster than she had ever anticipated.

Maxwell Harrison worked here.

Evelyn forced a smile. "Of course."

She retreated to a secluded corner, pulled out her laptop, and got to work.

Within minutes, she was inside Vista Properties’ internal system.

Her fingers flew across the keyboard as she navigated through files, searching for anything related to the demolition project.

And then she found it—a schedule, complete with names and dates.

A photo of Maxwell Harrison stared back at her, his smug expression burned into her memory.

Fine. If he wouldn’t come to her, she’d force his hand.

Found it.

The call ended abruptly.

No answer.

He was avoiding her.

And she knew exactly why—Victoria Sinclair had something to do with this.

Evelyn’s fingers hovered over the keyboard.

If he wanted to play games, she’d play them better.

"Mr. Harrison, are you done yet?"

Across the office, screens lit up with the unexpected message.

Murmurs erupted.

"What the—?"

"Did we get hacked?"

His expression darkened. "What the hell is the IT department doing? Find out who’s behind this—now!"
###Chapter 291

Alexander Montgomery gathered the entire Technical Department the moment he discovered the breach in the subsidiary's internal system.

He wasn’t about to confess. Not when Victoria was on her way.

###Chapter 292

Olivia was stunned. Why would Evelyn hack their subsidiary company?
