His jaw tightened. "Given how much Grandmother adores you, your presence benefits her health. So... I’m considering letting you remain Mrs. Whitmore."

Evelyn’s mind blanked.

The silence stretched between them, heavy and charged.

Slowly, she leaned forward, closing the distance between them.

Nathaniel’s breath hitched as her face neared his.

Her scent—subtle yet intoxicating—filled his senses.

His pulse quickened.

Was she... affected by his words?

Then, without warning, Evelyn pressed her palm against his forehead.

Their skin touched, warm and intimate.

Nathaniel stiffened, his pupils dilating.

But just as quickly, she pulled back.

"Strange," she mused, frowning. "No fever. So why are you talking nonsense like a delirious patient?"

She had married Nathaniel—a man who once seemed like little more than a living statue—partly out of respect for Eleanor, but also because she had genuinely cared for him.

Without that affection, how could she have endured three years as his dutiful wife?

Evelyn crossed her arms. "Besides, just because you have no standards doesn’t mean I don’t."

Nathaniel recoiled as if struck.

Her voice chased after him. "Nathaniel, say something! If you’re sick, go see a doctor!"

He swallowed hard, rising abruptly from his seat.

He strode away, his usually graceful steps now stiff and uneven.

Evelyn watched him leave, calling after him, "Seriously, get yourself checked!"

Nathaniel’s expression darkened further before he disappeared down the hall.

Alone again, Evelyn exhaled sharply and slumped into her chair.

As her heartbeat steadied, Nathaniel’s unexpected proposal replayed in her mind.

Stay married?

Her fingers curled into fists.

After three years of indifference, why would he suggest such a thing now?

If not for Eleanor’s unwavering support, the Whitmore family would have discarded her long ago.
###Chapter 326

With Eleanor finally cleared for surgery, Evelyn expected Nathaniel to feel relieved about their impending divorce.

Yet to her astonishment, he voiced his wish to remain married, insisting they didn't need to separate.

This unexpected development left Evelyn utterly perplexed.

While Nathaniel appeared willing to give their marriage another chance, Evelyn had moved beyond accepting vague promises.

She refused to wait endlessly for changes that might never come.

Besides, with twins growing inside her, the thought of raising them within the Whitmore family seemed increasingly impossible.

After completing her final exams and earning enough credits, Evelyn planned to join her brothers in Nord City - to deliver her babies and start fresh.

This exit strategy had been part of her preparations for months.

Perhaps Nathaniel had finally seen through Victoria's manipulations and realized Evelyn, despite her perceived simplicity, made the most suitable wife.

That might explain his sudden reluctance to divorce.

Yet Evelyn remained doubtful.

As she mused, a cloying floral scent assaulted her nostrils, unmistakably signaling Penelope's approach.

Evelyn looked up just as Penelope stopped before her, wrinkling her nose in distaste.

"You might want to stand back. That perfume could contaminate the operating theater and distract the surgeons," Evelyn warned.

Penelope scoffed. "Don't play innocent, Evelyn. I know your little secret."

Evelyn's brow furrowed. "Fine, you've uncovered my secret. Since you know everything, could you please move away from the operating area?"

"Can't you smell that? Your perfume's strong enough to cure smoked ham. Or has your nose stopped working?" Evelyn added pointedly.

Furious, Penelope snatched up a nearby legal document. "So this was your plan all along? Keeping it hidden from everyone."

Evelyn glanced at the papers. "I have no idea what you're talking about."

"Stop pretending!" Penelope spat. "I'll admit your diversion tactics worked brilliantly. You've fooled everyone - even Nathaniel supported this without question."

Her lips curled in contempt. "But your schemes won't work on me, Evelyn. Now that I know, your plan will fail. I won't let you stay in the Whitmore family!"

Evelyn sighed. "Then enlighten me. What exactly have I done? What schemes? Unless you explain, how would I know?"

Penelope leaned in, eyes gleaming. "You're pregnant, aren't you?"

Evelyn's pulse spiked, her pupils contracting as she stared at Penelope.

Had Cassandra betrayed her pregnancy to Penelope?

But that made no sense. Julian had assured Evelyn the matter with Cassandra was resolved.

She trusted Julian implicitly - he wouldn't lie to her.

Quickly regaining composure, Evelyn replied calmly, "Yes, I'm pregnant. Why else would Grandma Eleanor designate my unborn child as Whitmore Group's heir?"

Penelope smirked triumphantly. "Everyone thinks you faked pregnancy to comfort Grandma before surgery. But I'm the only one who knows the truth."

"So was this all part of your scheme? Did you manipulate Grandma into signing those heir documents too?" Penelope's voice grew more animated, convinced of her theory.

She reveled in this moment, certain she'd finally caught Evelyn in an untenable position.

Evelyn cursed inwardly. Though Penelope often acted foolishly, she occasionally displayed surprising perceptiveness.

Now what?

What if Penelope truly possessed evidence from Cassandra?
###Chapter 327

This was a delicate situation Evelyn had to handle with care.

Penelope's unwavering certainty about her accusations left Evelyn bewildered. How could she be so bold?

"Ha! Cat got your tongue, Evelyn? Your silence speaks volumes—I’ve nailed it, haven’t I?"

Seeing Evelyn’s lack of reaction, Penelope grew giddy with excitement. She was convinced she’d uncovered a secret no one else knew.

Evelyn remained composed. "You’re absolutely right. I am pregnant, and I’ve deliberately kept it hidden while arranging the heir agreement behind the scenes."

Penelope’s eyes gleamed with triumph. "Finally admitting it, huh? I’ll make sure everyone knows the truth. You won’t get away with this!"

Evelyn arched a brow. "Penelope, you’re painfully naive."

Her dismissive tone stung, making Penelope bristle. "Excuse me? You’re the one who’s naive!"

"Really? Did you even read the document? Nathaniel’s signature is already on it. All it needs is mine, and it becomes legally binding."

Evelyn’s lips curled into a sly smile. "Once it’s finalized, my child will be the heir to the Whitmore empire. And guess who’ll have a say in the family’s financial decisions?"

She leaned in slightly, voice dripping with amusement. "That includes your credit limit, by the way."

Penelope paled. "Don’t get ahead of yourself. Once I expose you, Nathaniel will never let this happen. Your little scheme will collapse."

Evelyn scoffed. "With Eleanor backing me and a Whitmore heir in my belly, who can touch me?" She tilted her head. "Still think I’m the naive one?"

Penelope’s throat tightened. Her credit had been restricted for weeks, forcing her to rely on Victoria’s measly supplementary card. The humiliation was unbearable.

If Evelyn secured her position as the Whitmore heiress, Penelope’s future would be ruined.

Panicked, she stumbled back and fled.



Evelyn watched her retreat with quiet satisfaction. Penelope couldn’t handle pressure to save her life.

Still, one question nagged at her—how had Penelope been so certain about the pregnancy? If word got out, it could spell trouble.

Resting a hand on her stomach, Evelyn knew she had to act first.

Meanwhile, Eleanor’s surgery had stretched past two hours. Needing a moment, Evelyn rose and headed for the restroom.

Fate had a way of complicating things.

She nearly collided with Nathaniel in the hallway.

Their eyes met, tension crackling between them.

Evelyn cleared her throat. "Excuse me. Restroom."

Nathaniel stepped aside wordlessly, and she slipped past him.

Inside, her thoughts spiraled—Penelope’s threats, Nathaniel’s sudden reluctance to finalize the divorce.

The Whitmores were nothing but trouble.

With a sigh, she stepped back into the hall.

Nathaniel sat by the window, laptop abandoned, gaze distant.

Hesitating, Evelyn approached.

Outside, two birds perched on a branch, preening each other’s feathers, beaks brushing affectionately.

Since when did birds flaunt their relationships?

Silence settled between them again—until Evelyn’s stomach growled loudly.

Heat rushed to her cheeks as she pressed a hand to her abdomen. It wasn’t even lunchtime. Why now?
###Chapter 328

The morning hadn't been kind to Evelyn Carter. Not only had she barely eaten, but Victoria Sinclair had nearly collided with her in the hallway, sending her breakfast tumbling to the floor.

Nathaniel Whitmore observed Evelyn's predicament with narrowed eyes before turning to Robert Chambers. "Have lunch delivered," he commanded.

Evelyn quickly raised a hand. "Wait."

Nathaniel's expression darkened. "Problem? Am I not allowed to buy you a meal?"

She cleared her throat delicately. "That's not it. I just prefer lighter options—maybe some soup and fresh fruit."

Silence stretched between them.

Straightening his tie, Nathaniel remarked, "You certainly have a way of making requests, Evelyn. Did I say I was treating you?"

Without missing a beat, Evelyn countered, "With guests visiting Eleanor Whitmore, isn't it your duty as her grandson to provide hospitality? Or has the Whitmore family forgotten its manners?"

Nathaniel's jaw tightened.

Was she seriously pinning this on him?

Soon, Robert returned with an elegant spread—delicate soups, crisp salads, and a trolley of assorted fruits.

Evelyn wasted no time picking up her fork.

The twins in her belly had been protesting all morning, leaving her no choice but to eat.

Nathaniel, who had little appetite, found himself eating more just watching her enjoy the food.

His gaze lingered on her face. "Evelyn, have you put on weight?"

She choked mid-bite.

"Ridiculous," she scoffed, dabbing her lips with a napkin. "Where exactly?"

Nathaniel smirked. "That second chin is new."

Self-consciously, Evelyn touched her jawline—it did feel softer. "It's called baby fat," she shot back. "Not that you're funding my meals anyway."

Nathaniel leaned back, unfazed. "You ate at the Whitmore estate for three years."

"Yes, and I didn't gain an ounce then. Funny how it happened right after I left—what does that say about your household?"

His eyes glinted. "Are you accusing me of mistreating you?"

"Whether you did or not," Evelyn said sweetly, "you know the answer."

Nathaniel exhaled sharply. "For three years, your living expenses were more than covered. I never shortchanged you."

Evelyn's laugh was icy. "Oh, the money was always there. But your mother made sure I knew spending it would burden you. 'Nathaniel works so hard,' she'd say. 'Don't be wasteful.'"

"And yet," Nathaniel mused, "you never struck me as someone who'd obey blindly."

Evelyn's fingers tightened around her fork.

"I was naive," she admitted. "If I had today's mindset back then? I'd have lived lavishly—spa days, designer boutiques, luxury vacations. I certainly wouldn't have been some meek little wife."

It had taken her too long to realize: compromising endlessly won no one's love—only her own resentment.

Nathaniel studied her, his gaze unreadable.

"That's how it should be," he said at last. "As Mrs. Whitmore, you should command respect. Who would dare slight you? If trouble comes, I'll handle it. What are you afraid of?"
###Chapter 329

Evelyn's lips parted in shock at Nathaniel's declaration.

Why was he saying such absurd things again?

What did he mean by supporting her even if the world ended? Why would he express such sentiments to her now?

She blinked rapidly. "Mr. Whitmore, had I known you felt this way earlier, I wouldn't have suffered through three miserable years!"

"It's never too late to know the truth." Nathaniel's gaze burned with intensity, his meaning crystal clear.

As Evelyn studied his striking features - those sharp cheekbones and mesmerizing eyes - her pulse quickened uncontrollably. Every detail of his face seemed crafted to her exact preferences.

"You don't need to answer immediately," Nathaniel said calmly. "Take all the time you need."

Evelyn quickly composed herself, clearing her throat. "Mr. Whitmore, your feelings now don't change anything. It's too late."

Nathaniel's expression darkened instantly. His jaw tightened. "Must you always speak like this?"

Despite his clear intentions and promises, Evelyn remained stubbornly resistant.

A storm of emotions swirled in Evelyn's eyes. "Three years ago, those words would have made me so happy I couldn't sleep!"

Nathaniel looked surprised. "And now?"

"Now they make me so angry I can't sleep."

Nathaniel recoiled slightly.

Evelyn lifted her chin. "Mr. Whitmore, my feelings have faded. There's no reason to continue this marriage."

"After Eleanor's surgery, she'll recover completely. There's no need—"

Her words struck Nathaniel's heart like a sudden drumbeat disrupting his rhythm. He stared intensely at Evelyn, searching her eyes for any trace of their former adoration - and found none.

The emptiness in his chest surprised him. Once, he would have celebrated her indifference. Now, it left him hollow.

The operating room doors swung open abruptly.

Dr. Laurent emerged, face grim, holding documents. "The patient's condition is more complex than anticipated. We need emergency authorization."

A chill ran down Evelyn's spine. She instinctively turned to Nathaniel, whose face had gone deathly pale.

Evelyn snatched the forms and thrust them at him. "Sign quickly. We must trust the doctors."

There was no turning back now.

Nathaniel's hand trembled as he signed. The pen nearly slipped from his fingers. Evelyn placed a steadying hand on his arm. "Eleanor will be fine. She promised us."

Nathaniel remained frozen, staring at the operating room doors. Evelyn stood silently beside him as hours stretched into evening.

When Dr. Laurent finally reappeared, Evelyn's heart leaped to her throat. "How is she?"

"The surgery succeeded, but she's being transferred to ICU. No visitors during critical recovery."

Relief flooded Evelyn's veins. Without thinking, she threw her arms around Nathaniel. "Did you hear? Eleanor's going to be fine!"

Her spontaneous embrace caught them both by surprise. For the first time in years, they stood connected - not by obligation, but by shared relief.
###Chapter 330

Nathaniel's lips curved into a subtle smile. "That's wonderful news!"

Evelyn looked up at Nathaniel standing before her. His striking features, illuminated by the soft hospital lighting, looked like something out of a Renaissance painting.

For a brief moment, she was completely mesmerized.

Just then, Julian emerged from the operating room, exhaustion evident in his expression.

Seeing Evelyn embrace Nathaniel, Julian frowned. "What's going on here? Let go."

Hearing Julian's voice, Evelyn suddenly snapped back to reality. Overwhelmed by relief, she had instinctively hugged Nathaniel without thinking.

Blushing, she quickly released him and turned to Julian, her eyes shining. "I heard the surgery was a success!"

Julian had promised Evelyn that Eleanor's operation would go smoothly, and true to his word, he had delivered.

With a gentle smile, he ruffled Evelyn's hair. "Of course. I never break my promises to you."

Julian took his commitments to Evelyn seriously. This time, she gave him a genuine smile of gratitude.

Watching their affectionate exchange, Nathaniel's eyes narrowed. A sharp pang of jealousy twisted inside him.

It felt like someone was stealing what was rightfully his.

Julian, recognizing the look in Nathaniel's eyes, understood exactly what it meant.

But Nathaniel's chances were slim now. Julian and his brothers were determined to bring Evelyn back to Nord City permanently. By then, Nathaniel would be irrelevant.

After all, Nord City had no shortage of eligible bachelors.

Turning to Nathaniel, Julian said, "While Mrs. Whitmore's surgery went well, the next week in the ICU is critical."

"If she pulls through this period, she should be on the road to recovery."

Nathaniel's throat tightened. Emotions warred within him, leaving him momentarily speechless.

It felt as though Eleanor's survival had come at the cost of losing Evelyn, and the unfairness of it gnawed at him.

Evelyn spoke up. "I believe Grandma Eleanor will make it through this week."

Julian's gaze softened as he looked at her. "I think so too. It's getting late—we should head home."

Evelyn nodded. "Alright."

As soon as she said it, she felt the air around her grow noticeably colder.

Behind her, Nathaniel spoke in a low voice. "I'll go check on Grandma's condition."

Unable to bear the tension any longer, he turned and walked away, frustration simmering beneath the surface. If he stayed, he might lose control and do something he'd regret.

Watching Nathaniel leave, Evelyn felt a wave of relief. Eleanor was safe—that was what mattered most.

She turned back to Julian. "Julian, has the lead surgeon left? I didn’t see him come out."

Julian tensed slightly. "Ah, yes. He was exhausted."

"He left through a private exit. The surgery was long, and he performed it alone."

"That makes sense."

Julian hesitated. "Why do you want to meet him?"

"I just wanted to thank him in person. Regardless of his connection to Victoria, he’s the reason Grandma Eleanor made it through."

Whatever issues existed between her and Victoria were a separate matter.

Julian exhaled in relief. "I’ll make sure to pass along your gratitude."

"Thank you."

Evelyn didn’t press further. Given the awkward history with Victoria, she was content letting Julian handle it.

Julian studied her. "Let’s go home. You shouldn’t push yourself—you need rest."
###Chapter 331

Evelyn froze when she spotted Victoria across the hospital corridor.

Why was Victoria still here? Eleanor's surgery had concluded hours ago.

A nagging suspicion crept into Evelyn's mind. Was Victoria's hospital visit genuine concern, or just another calculated performance?

The air between them grew thick with tension.

Julian's pulse quickened at the sight of Victoria. What was she doing here?

If Victoria approached them now, it would undoubtedly trigger a catastrophic scene!

Julian's mind raced for damage control options.

Seeing Evelyn standing so close to Julian, Victoria's jealousy flared like wildfire. How dare that orphan girl cling to Julian!

Bitter regret washed over Victoria. She never should have allowed Evelyn to attend her engagement party.

Without that invitation, Evelyn wouldn't have gotten so many opportunities to worm her way into Julian's life.

Someone of Evelyn's lowly status would never normally cross paths with a Montgomery heir.

Victoria's face darkened with determination. Today, she would expose Evelyn's true colors.

She would make sure Evelyn understood the unbridgeable chasm between their social standings!

As Victoria marched forward in her designer heels, Evelyn's eyes flashed with alarm. She knew any confrontation would force Julian to defend her.

Julian had only recently established his reputation at this hospital. Offending Victoria meant crossing her powerful brother, the renowned surgeon Alexander Montgomery.

Such a scandal could ruin Julian's promising career.

Scenarios played out rapidly in Evelyn's mind. Though she was learning to stand her ground, she couldn't let personal drama jeopardize Julian's future.

In a split-second decision, Evelyn acted.

As Victoria reached them, Evelyn suddenly pulled her into an embrace. "What brings you here? Grandma Eleanor's been moved to ICU."

"The surgery went well. Come, I'll take you to see her." Maintaining the hug, Evelyn steered Victoria toward the elevators.

Victoria stiffened in shock, completely thrown by Evelyn's unexpected move.

The elevator doors slid open. Still holding Victoria, Evelyn guided them both inside.

Only when the doors closed did Evelyn exhale in relief - Julian couldn't follow them now.

Glancing at Victoria still trapped in her arms, Evelyn blinked rapidly.

Their eyes met briefly before both women quickly separated. Evelyn cleared her throat, remaining silent.

Victoria adjusted her dress with sharp, irritated movements. "Evelyn, what was that about? Why did you hug me?"

"I saw the elevator coming and didn't want to miss it," Evelyn replied smoothly, keeping her true motives hidden.

Victoria scoffed derisively. "You're clearly guilty about something. Don't think I don't see through your little act!"

"I was simply helping you visit Eleanor. Don't read too much into it," Evelyn countered.

As the doors opened, Evelyn stepped out quickly.

Victoria's venomous words followed her: "You're afraid of what I'll say to him, aren't you? That's why you dragged me away!"
###Chapter 332

Evelyn's spine stiffened instantly. Since when had Victoria, that airheaded socialite, become so perceptive?

She couldn't comprehend how Victoria had uncovered her hidden agenda.

As Evelyn turned, Victoria's smug smirk greeted her. "What exactly are you plotting?"

It almost slipped Evelyn's mind—Victoria's brother was a renowned surgeon too. Perhaps she had connections to Julian as well.

During the redevelopment of Evelyn's childhood neighborhood, Victoria had been pulling strings in the shadows.

If Victoria discovered Evelyn's relationship with Julian, what chaos would ensue?

With a victorious glint in her eyes, Victoria taunted, "Evelyn, darling, perhaps it's time to abandon this little fantasy of yours. You're utterly unworthy of Julian. Stop deluding yourself."

Evelyn's brows arched slightly at Victoria's words. There was an eerie familiarity to her tone.

Nathaniel had once voiced similar sentiments—that Evelyn and Julian were mismatched.

Of course they were incompatible—they were siblings! The mere thought of them as a couple was ludicrous.

Clearly, both Victoria and Nathaniel had misinterpreted Evelyn's relationship with Julian, assuming it was romantic.

If that were truly the case, resolving this misunderstanding would be far simpler.

A sly smile curled Evelyn's lips. "Victoria, isn't meddling beneath someone of your stature?"

"Fine then. I'll clarify matters directly with Julian. Then you'll see if I'm truly interfering," Victoria retorted, stepping toward the elevator.

Recognizing the impending disaster, Evelyn seized Victoria's arm and slammed her against the wall, determined to prevent her from reaching Julian.

"Release me this instant!" Victoria demanded, frustration lacing her voice.

"Not a chance!" Evelyn pinned Victoria's shoulders firmly against the wall, rendering her immobile.

Their proximity was uncomfortably intimate.



Evelyn suddenly realized she stood half a head taller than Victoria, whose petite frame was no match for her strength.

A cold voice sliced through the tension. "What's the meaning of this?"

Evelyn glanced over to see Nathaniel and Beatrice approaching, their expressions unreadable.

Nathaniel's face darkened. "Are you planning to release her?"

From a distance, the scene appeared compromising—Evelyn pressing Victoria against the wall in what could be mistaken for an intimate embrace.

Had Evelyn's targets now expanded to include women?

Beatrice rushed forward. "Evelyn, what are you doing to Ms. Sinclair?"

Spotting Beatrice, Victoria instantly adopted a wounded expression. "Mrs. Whitmore, I've no idea what Ms. Carter wants with me. She assaulted me without provocation! Look—she's bruised my wrist!"

Evelyn immediately released her, flashing an innocent smile. "Just playing a harmless prank on Ms. Sinclair, nothing more."

Beatrice frowned. "Is this appropriate behavior toward Ms. Sinclair? Nathaniel, you witnessed this!"

Evelyn studied Nathaniel's stormy expression, unease coiling in her stomach. Why was he so protective of Victoria?

It wasn't as if Evelyn had caused any real harm.

Victoria turned pleading eyes toward Nathaniel. "I can't believe Evelyn just harassed me like this. Thank heavens you arrived when you did—who knows what might have happened?"

She lowered her voice conspiratorially. "After all, I only have eyes for men. My preferences are... traditional."

Evelyn gaped at Victoria in disbelief. "When exactly did your moral compass shatter?"

Since when had Evelyn ever behaved inappropriately?
###Chapter 333

Evelyn never anticipated that Victoria would one day accuse her of harassment. The sheer audacity took her breath away.

"Did I say something wrong?" Victoria challenged with a smirk. "Who was the one who pulled me into that embrace downstairs? Who shoved me into the elevator? And who," she added with dramatic emphasis, "pinned me against the wall and refused to let go?"

Evelyn felt her dignity crumbling like dry sand between her fingers.

Before she could formulate a response, Nathaniel's strong fingers closed around her wrist. His jaw was set in that familiar stubborn line. "Evelyn. Come with me."

"Let go of me, Nathaniel!" Evelyn twisted to glare at Victoria, whose triumphant expression made her blood boil. She'd fallen into another one of their traps!

What game was Nathaniel playing now?

He maneuvered her into a secluded corner, his grip unrelenting. When she opened her mouth to protest, he caught her chin with his free hand. "Evelyn," he murmured, his voice dangerously low, "you're becoming bolder than I realized. How did I miss this side of you?"

Evelyn met his stormy gaze without flinching. "I've told you before - don't judge me by your limited understanding." She injected just enough sarcasm to make her point. "Though I doubt someone like you could comprehend."

Nathaniel's lips thinned. "Grandmother would be devastated to learn about your... preferences for women."

The absurdity of his accusation struck Evelyn like a physical blow. She was undeniably straight!

A bitter laugh escaped her lips. "Fine, since we're being honest - yes, I'm bisexual." She leaned closer, enjoying how his pupils dilated. "I've come to realize men rarely live up to their reputations."

"Women," she continued with deliberate provocation, "are compassionate. Understanding. We connect on levels you arrogant males could never fathom."

Nathaniel's expression darkened. He recognized the jab at his own behavior immediately.

Just as he drew breath to respond, Evelyn's phone vibrated. Julian's name flashed across the screen.

She shook off Nathaniel's grip. "If you'll excuse me."

Nathaniel's gaze dropped to her phone. His frown deepened when he saw the caller ID.

"If you can't accept me as I am," Evelyn tossed over her shoulder, "I'll find someone who will."

She pivoted sharply and took the emergency stairs two at a time, deliberately avoiding the elevator where Victoria and Beatrice might still be lurking.

Watching her retreat, Nathaniel's irritation spiked.

Her closeness with Julian already grated on him. Now this apparent interest in Victoria? It was too much.

Was Evelyn determined to bewitch every Montgomery in the city?

"Nat?" Victoria's saccharine voice interrupted his thoughts.

He turned to find her alone, her delicate features arranged in perfect distress. Evelyn's absence seemed to confirm Victoria's unspoken accusation of guilt.

Nathaniel studied Victoria's petite frame - so different from Evelyn's confident bearing. The comparison made Victoria's calculated vulnerability suddenly repulsive.

"Stay away from Evelyn," he commanded, his voice like ice. "Don't go near her again."

Victoria's eyes widened. "Nat, I knew you still—"

He didn't wait for her to finish. His abrupt departure left her standing alone, though her smug smile suggested she'd misinterpreted his warning as protection.

Beatrice materialized at her side. "What did he say?"

Victoria's lips curved. "He told me to avoid Evelyn. Clearly he still cares about me."

The satisfaction in her voice echoed down the hallway as Nathaniel strode away, his thoughts consumed by the infuriating woman who'd just turned his world upside down.
###Chapter 334

Beatrice's lips curled into a knowing smirk. "Ms. Sinclair, as I told you before, Mrs. Whitmore's surgery was completed without complications."

She leaned closer, her voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. "Nathaniel's devotion to his grandmother is the only reason he tolerated Evelyn's presence all this time. Now that Eleanor's procedure is done, that gold-digger will be out on the street before she knows what hit her."

Victoria's face lit up with malicious glee as a thought struck her. "But what about the inheritance agreement?"

"Don't trouble yourself over that," Beatrice waved a dismissive hand. "Evelyn isn't pregnant. That document might as well be toilet paper."

After a moment's consideration, Victoria visibly relaxed, her shoulders losing their tension.

Meanwhile, Evelyn descended the hospital stairs to meet Julian, who waited by the exit. They walked to the parking lot in companionable silence.

Settling into the passenger seat, Evelyn clenched her fists in her lap. Victoria's vile accusations echoed in her mind, each word like a dagger twisting in her gut. Being called a stalker? The sheer audacity made her blood boil.

She'd always known Victoria lacked morals, but this new low still managed to shock her.

Julian navigated the evening traffic with careful precision, stealing frequent glances at his sister's stormy expression. His pulse quickened with worry - had Victoria somehow revealed their secret during their confrontation?

After several tense minutes, he cleared his throat. "Evelyn... what exactly did you and Victoria talk about back there?"

Evelyn's fingers twitched, her gaze fixed on the passing streetlights. "Nothing important," she lied smoothly. "Just escorted her to see Eleanor outside ICU. Small talk, really."

There was no way she'd tell Julian about Victoria's harassment claims. Some humiliations were best kept private.

Julian exhaled slowly, relief washing over him. Whatever they'd discussed, it clearly hadn't involved their true relationship. His grip on the steering wheel loosened slightly.

"Julian," Evelyn's sudden question made him tense again, "how well do you know Victoria?"

His throat went dry. "We've crossed paths a few times at the hospital," he answered carefully. "Professional acquaintances, nothing more."

Evelyn nodded absently. It made sense - with Victoria's brother being a renowned surgeon, their paths would naturally intersect at the medical center.

"Why do you ask?" Julian's voice held a nervous edge.

Evelyn gave a humorless laugh. "Oh, just amusing myself with their ridiculous theories. Both Victoria and Nathaniel seem convinced there's something romantic between us."

Julian's palms grew clammy. "And... what did you tell them?"

If Evelyn had revealed their sibling bond, Victoria would have been crowing about it by now.

"I didn't bother correcting them." Evelyn's lips twisted in a bitter smile. "Let them believe what they want. Their opinions stopped mattering to me a long time ago."

Her tone carried such finality that Julian's chest ached. She was protecting him - protecting all of them - by maintaining their secret.

"Evelyn," he ventured cautiously, "why not just tell them the truth? That I'm your brother?"

The hurt in his voice made Evelyn turn to study his profile. She hadn't realized how much her silence weighed on him.

"There's no point," she said softly. "In a few months, I'll be leaving Bern City for Nord City anyway. Best to keep things simple."

Julian's knuckles whitened on the wheel. "Are you trying to protect yourself... or us?"

The realization hit him like a physical blow. All this time, they'd prided themselves on keeping their relationship hidden, when in truth, it was Evelyn who'd been shielding them.

His vision blurred unexpectedly. She'd shouldered this burden alone, never once complaining.

Evelyn reached over to squeeze his arm. "Honestly? I just prefer not to share my personal life with people who don't matter."

Julian swallowed hard, his throat tight with emotion. As they stopped at a red light, he turned to face her fully.

"Evelyn," he began, voice thick, "there's something you need to know."
###Chapter 335

Evelyn discreetly glanced at Julian in the driver's seat. She couldn't shake the feeling that his gaze held a trace of discomfort.

Julian's eyes revealed a tangled mess of guilt and tenderness, his emotions laid bare.

Intrigued, Evelyn wondered what secret Julian was about to reveal.

Lost in thought, she suddenly blurted out, "Julian, you never had a thing with Victoria before, did you?"

The car jerked to an abrupt stop.

"Of course not!" Julian answered, his voice laced with shock.

Before he could elaborate, the sound of metal crunching against metal echoed from behind them, cutting their conversation short.

Evelyn's face drained of color. "Julian, did we just get rear-ended?"

"Yeah, but it's minor. Evelyn, could you wait on the sidewalk while I deal with this?" Julian instructed.

Heart pounding, Evelyn stepped out and spotted a sleek sports car behind them.

Then, a woman emerged from the driver's side—elegant, poised, and radiating an effortless sophistication that immediately caught Evelyn's attention.

Something about her felt strangely familiar.

Relieved that the other driver wasn't some aggressive man, Evelyn exhaled slightly.

She stood by the roadside, watching as Julian and the woman exchanged words. Their striking looks made them seem like they belonged in a high-fashion ad.

As Evelyn studied the woman’s graceful demeanor, realization struck.

A quick search on her phone confirmed it—this was Genevieve Winslow, a singer whose music Evelyn adored.

Not quite a household name, which explained why Evelyn hadn’t recognized her right away.

Excitement bubbled up. Should she ask for an autograph?

Moments later, Julian and Genevieve exchanged contact details before she drove off in her sports car.

Julian pulled over and reassured Evelyn. "It was just a fender bender. Insurance will handle it. You can get back in."

As Evelyn settled into her seat, she couldn’t contain herself. "Julian, did you just get her number?"

"Yeah, WhatsApp. Easier for follow-up. Though honestly, it was my fault for stopping suddenly."

Evelyn hesitated, then asked, "Did you think she was pretty?"

Julian arched a brow, considering his answer before turning to her. "She's alright. But you? You're breathtaking."

No one could compare to Evelyn—her kindness, her wit, her beauty.

Julian adored her, and it showed.

Evelyn bit her lip. "I wanted to ask for her autograph, but I chickened out."

"Autograph? She’s famous?"

"Sort of. A singer who keeps a low profile. But she’s even more stunning in person. I’m a huge fan."

Julian hadn’t pegged her as a celebrity. Interesting.

Watching Evelyn’s admiration for Genevieve made him oddly uneasy. Was she… starstruck?

Once home, Julian parked and cleared his throat. "Evelyn, there’s something I need to tell you."

"What is it?"

"Don’t mention to Alexander that I drove you home and we got rear-ended. You know how explosive his temper can be."

Evelyn blinked. "Is he really that bad? He’s always been gentle with me."

Julian sighed, ruffling her hair playfully. "Alexander only softens for you. Sebastian and I got chewed out plenty growing up."

Evelyn smirked. "Probably because you two were troublemakers."
###Chapter 336

Evelyn stepped out of the car, flashing Julian a reassuring smile. "Don't worry, I won't say a word to Alexander."

The moment they entered the house, the rich aroma of Margaret's cooking enveloped them.

In the living room, Evelyn froze at the sight of a strikingly handsome man lounging on the couch. "Christopher?"

Christopher rose gracefully, his lips curving into a warm smile as he ruffled Evelyn's hair. "Evelyn, you're home early. Rough day at university?"

Evelyn hesitated. "No, Eleanor had surgery today. I stayed at the hospital until it was over."

Christopher's gaze flicked to Julian, disapproval flashing in his eyes. Having known Evelyn once worked as a caregiver for the Whitmores, he'd always opposed Julian assisting with their medical matters.

But since it was Evelyn's personal request, he held his tongue. Her kindness was impossible to refuse.

"Hungry?" Christopher asked, his voice smooth as silk. "Let's eat."

Margaret emerged from the kitchen, wiping her hands on her apron. "Perfect timing! Since everyone's here, let's wash up and dig in."

She turned to Evelyn. "Since Christopher's visiting and it's the weekend, why don't you show him around Bern City?"

Evelyn nodded. "Of course. Christopher, are you here for business or pleasure?"

Her brothers usually only visited during vacations or work trips, their schedules packed.

"Business," Christopher replied casually, "but I thought I'd take a break too."

Truthfully, his main purpose was seeing Evelyn.

After her recent discovery, Christopher had been swamped with work, making it impossible to visit Bern City sooner.



Now that he'd finally cleared his schedule, he was determined to spend quality time with Evelyn.

Though Evelyn got along well with all six brothers, she'd always felt a distance between herself and Christopher and Andrew.

Andrew, being a lawyer, had helped Evelyn when she faced false accusations.

But with Christopher, there was an unspoken barrier she couldn't breach.

Despite knowing little about him, Evelyn couldn't deny his breathtaking looks. If Christopher ever entered show business, he'd undoubtedly become an overnight sensation.

The next morning, Evelyn prepared to visit the studio.

She'd texted Jonathan the night before, requesting time off.

With Christopher visiting and needing to check on Eleanor at the hospital, Evelyn had no spare time this weekend.

Arriving at the studio, Evelyn powered up her computer and efficiently wrapped up pending tasks, ensuring a smooth transition.

Given her limited availability moving forward, she decided against taking new projects.

"Evelyn! I thought you were off this weekend?" Jonathan's eyes lit up at the sight of her.

Evelyn shrugged. "Just dropping off some documents."

Before Jonathan could respond, the guest room door opened, revealing Judith. "Jonathan, are you done? Oh, hello Evelyn! What brings you here?"

Evelyn's smile faltered slightly. "Just finishing some work. Don't let me interrupt your plans."

Judith's elegant outfit suggested they were heading out.

Jonathan quickly clarified, "Nothing important. My mother rarely visits, so I'm taking her sightseeing this weekend."

Judith linked arms with Evelyn, her gaze calculating. "Evelyn, I've been meaning to ask—is your cousin currently single?"

Evelyn blinked.

Jonathan groaned. "Mother, please."

Judith waved him off. "What? It's a simple question."

Evelyn suppressed a sigh. This was going to be a long weekend.
###Chapter 337

Evelyn blinked in confusion. "My cousin?"

She didn't have any cousins.

Before she could process the situation, Judith leaned forward eagerly. "Don't be shy, Evelyn. Tell me, is your cousin single? Married? With that handsome face and wealth, he must be quite the catch!"

Jonathan frowned, cutting in sharply. "Mother, what nonsense are you spouting? Mr. Whitmore couldn't possibly be single."

Nathaniel was the heir to Bern City's wealthiest family. Even if marriage wasn't in his immediate plans, someone of his status would never be unattached. And even if he were single, he existed in a stratosphere far beyond their reach.

Jonathan's real plan was to win Evelyn's affection, then use her connection to Nathaniel to catapult his own career forward.

Evelyn's mind whirled at Judith's question. Was she seriously considering playing matchmaker for Nathaniel?

Judith waved a dismissive hand. "No harm in asking! My niece studied abroad—beautiful, educated, excellent pedigree. Can't I inquire on her behalf?"

Evelyn's suspicions were confirmed—Judith was indeed attempting to arrange a match.

Those piercing eyes locked onto Evelyn. "I'm just asking for my niece's sake. If he's taken or uninterested, we'll drop it."

Evelyn's lips twitched. She cleared her throat. "I believe he's technically single."

With their divorce proceedings scheduled for next Monday at the courthouse, Nathaniel would soon be officially available.

Judith's face lit up like a Christmas tree. "Really? What's his type? As Jonathan mentioned, my niece has exceptional standards—ivy league education, impeccable manners. Your cousin runs a corporation, doesn't he? This could be mutually beneficial."

Evelyn found herself drowning in the sudden interrogation.

"Are you hesitant to introduce them? They might hit it off splendidly! Then we'd practically be family."

"Mrs. Reeves, it's not that I object. He's a rather distant relative."

The truth was, with Nathaniel's status, he had socialites and heiresses lining up for his attention. Beatrice's obvious preference for Victoria made the situation even more complicated. Marrying into the Whitmore dynasty wasn't something just anyone could achieve.

"Evelyn darling, you needn't lift a finger. Just share his WhatsApp. Or give it to Jonathan—he'll pass it along to my niece."

Jonathan abruptly intervened. "Mother, we're running late for our appointment. We should go."

Only then did Judith reluctantly leave the office. Outside, she hissed at her son, "Why did you stop me?"

"Mother, if my cousin starts seeing Evelyn's 'cousin,' that creates complications. What if the Whitmores find such connections beneath them?"

Judith scoffed. "Evelyn's no aristocrat. The woman you're meeting today comes from real money—your cousin's Oxford classmate. You'd better impress her."

"If Evelyn doesn't pan out, you've got this alternative. No harm pursuing both options simultaneously. With your looks, you should aim for wealth and beauty."
###Chapter 338

Jonathan admired his reflection in the elevator's polished surface, a smug smile playing on his lips.

Progress with Evelyn was slow - she wasn't the type to open up easily. He needed to focus on his own advancement first.

Evelyn finished organizing the documents and stepped out of the studio.

She reached for her phone to call Christopher, wanting to let him know she'd finished work. But the call went unanswered.

Strange. Was he still occupied?

They'd made plans last night to meet after her shift ended.

Assuming he must be busy, she decided against calling again. Instead, she sent a text: "Christopher, I'm done with work."

Her phone rang within seconds.

Evelyn answered immediately. "Christopher, I-"

"Who is this?" A sharp female voice cut her off. "Why are you calling this number?"

Evelyn blinked at her phone screen. "My apologies, I must have dialed wrong."

Had Christopher given her the wrong number last night? That seemed impossible.

The woman's tone turned accusatory. "Don't play dumb! What's your relationship with Christopher? How do you know him?"

Evelyn's breath caught. This was definitely Christopher's number.

But who was this woman? A girlfriend? If so, Evelyn needed to clarify things to avoid complications.

"It's not what you're thinking," Evelyn explained quickly.

"Oh really?" The woman scoffed. "I've seen your WhatsApp history. You've had his number for months - since his business trip to Bern City."

Evelyn's fingers tightened around her phone.

"You stopped talking for a while, but he kept sending you money. Quite the lucrative arrangement, isn't it?"

Evelyn's jaw clenched. "That's uncalled for. You're making assumptions without hearing me out. How dare you imply I'm some sort of escort?"

The woman laughed coldly. "Then what exactly do you do? Women like you always swarm around Christopher because of his money and looks. I've dealt with your type before."

"Let me make this clear - stop deluding yourself. He'll never stay with someone like you." The line went dead.

Evelyn stood frozen. Was that Christopher's girlfriend? From how she spoke, he sounded like a complete playboy.

This wasn't her business to interfere with his personal life. But the misunderstanding needed clarification.

They'd exchanged numbers but rarely messaged. The money transfers were bonuses after the Fleur International Design Competition - nothing inappropriate.

After a moment's hesitation, Evelyn typed: "Christopher, your girlfriend seems to have misunderstood our relationship. Please explain things to her."

Her message bounced back. She'd been blocked.
###Chapter 339

Evelyn stared at her phone screen in disbelief.

Christopher had blocked her number.

The realization hit her like a physical blow. Her own cousin's girlfriend had cut off all communication.

She clenched her jaw, frustration bubbling beneath her skin.

Nathaniel must have been preoccupied. That was the only explanation for why he hadn’t noticed her messages—or the misunderstanding that had spiraled from them.

After a tense moment, Evelyn exhaled sharply. There was no point dwelling on it now. She’d deal with it when Nathaniel was free.

Even if she tried to explain herself to that woman, it wouldn’t matter. The damage was already done.

With a resigned sigh, Evelyn tucked her phone away.

Since she’d already taken leave from the studio and Nathaniel was swamped, what now?

Her thoughts drifted to Eleanor.

"Grandma," she murmured.

Decision made, she flagged down a taxi and directed it toward the hospital.

Eleanor remained in the ICU, still too fragile for visitors. Evelyn could only hover outside, anxiously questioning the nurses for updates.

One nurse offered a reassuring smile. "Her blood pressure spiked early this morning, but we stabilized her. She’s resting comfortably now."

Evelyn’s pulse stuttered at the mention of the crisis. Relief flooded her when she heard Eleanor was stable.

Unable to see her grandmother, Evelyn closed her eyes and whispered a silent prayer.

As she turned to leave, the elevator doors slid open. Nathaniel stood there, deep in conversation with a group of doctors.

His head snapped up when he noticed her.

"Keep me updated," he told the doctors briskly before dismissing them.

One physician nodded. "Of course, Mr. Whitmore. Mrs. Whitmore Senior is under constant supervision. We won’t leave anything to chance."

Nathaniel acknowledged this with a curt nod, and the medical team dispersed.

Evelyn had overheard enough. With round-the-clock care, Eleanor was in good hands.

Nathaniel’s lips pressed into a thin line. "She’s stable. Don’t worry." His tone was stiff, almost guarded.

Evelyn nodded. "That’s good to hear."

A beat of silence stretched between them.

Nathaniel’s gaze flickered over her. "You’re not working today? I thought you had weekend shifts."

Someone of Evelyn’s skill shouldn’t have needed to waste her time at that small studio. The thought of its owner made Nathaniel’s jaw tighten.

Evelyn hesitated. "I’ve decided to prioritize my studies. I can freelance for extra income."

His brows drew together. "You need money?"

"Everyone does," she said flatly. "Bills don’t pay themselves."

Nathaniel studied her for a long moment before reaching for his wallet. He extracted a sleek black card and held it out.

"Take it."

Evelyn eyed the card but made no move to accept it. "No, thanks."

"You refused the assets before, but now you’re struggling. If word gets out, it reflects poorly on me."

She frowned. "How does my financial situation affect your reputation?"

Was this some kind of power play?

Nathaniel’s expression darkened. "You’re still my wife."

"For now."

"Even after the divorce, people will talk if I let my ex-wife struggle." His voice hardened. "Just take it."

Evelyn took a deliberate step back. "Not happening."

Accepting his money would only muddy the waters between them. She refused to be labeled a gold-digger.

Just then, her phone buzzed. Christopher’s name flashed across the screen.

Evelyn answered immediately. "Finally."

The voice on the other end wasn’t Christopher’s.

"Are you Christopher Montgomery’s family?"

Evelyn’s breath caught. "Yes. I am."
###Chapter 340

The phone rang sharply in Evelyn's hand.

"We're the police. There's a situation at the Grand Royale Hotel. Could you come over?" The officer's tense voice made her stomach drop.

Something had happened to Christopher.

He hardly ever visited Bern City—he was practically a stranger here!

Despite his playboy reputation, no one disparaged his cousin in his presence.

Evelyn's cheeks burned at the unexpected praise. How could he say such things so boldly when his girlfriend looked like she'd stepped off a magazine cover?

He pulled out his phone to check—but Evelyn's name wasn't in his recent messages.
###Chapter 341

Typical playboy behavior.

###Chapter 342

Earlier, curiosity and concern had gnawed at him. He'd wanted to know what had unsettled Evelyn, worried for her safety.

Robert hesitated after calling the hotel for details, unsure whether to disclose the truth.

###Chapter 343

The scene screamed "arranged marriage meeting."

She shook her head. "Just curious. I'm probably too old to start now."

Had that wretched nanny not lost baby Evelyn, she would never have endured such hardships.

Christopher had yet to reveal his true identity as a renowned pianist. Soon, he would need to assemble his team to establish a prestigious music academy right here in Bern City.

###Chapter 345

Evelyn Carter never imagined she'd bump into Jonathan Reeves at the bank.

###Chapter 346

###Chapter 347

###Chapter 349

###Chapter 350
