Her tone was light, as if it were the most natural request. "Patients shouldn't eat leftovers. Consider it a favor."

Evelyn wasn't fooled. She'd nearly collapsed from hunger earlier, and now Judith expected her to eat Jonathan's scraps? Never in a million years.

Without another word, she turned on her heel and left.

Regret gnawed at her. Playing the good Samaritan had backfired spectacularly. If Christopher hadn't roughed Jonathan up, she wouldn't have wasted her afternoon tending to him, only to be treated like an afterthought.

Once alone, Jonathan frowned. "That was too much, Mom."

"Oh, so you can speak? Why stay silent earlier?"

"I was putting on a show. For the police, yes, but mostly for Evelyn. Pity makes her pliable. Easier to ask for favors later."

Judith smirked. "Clever boy. Still, letting her walk away from the chicken soup and pork was a mistake. What if you're still hungry?"

"I like her, but boundaries matter. Once she's ours, she’ll learn to prioritize me. Leftovers? That’s a wife’s duty."

Like mother, like son—neither saw an issue. Still, Jonathan added, "Just don’t push too hard yet."

"Once things are official, we’ll set the rules properly."

Judith wasn’t done. "The hospital’s a trek from home. Cooking for three takes time. Why not have Evelyn handle meals? She can bring them here."

He hesitated. "She won’t agree."

"Leave it to me. I’ll convince her tomorrow. This way, I’ll have more free time while she tends to you. Trust me, I know how to handle women."

Jonathan relaxed. Christopher’s assault had given him leverage. Now, Evelyn owed him care—and maybe more.

His mind raced. Winning her heart meant access to her brothers’ investments. If not, he’d sue Christopher. Either way, he held all the cards.

Closing his eyes, he envisioned it: moving into Evelyn’s home, Judith in tow, living off her family’s wealth.

Meanwhile, Evelyn sat in a diner, savoring a bowl of noodles. Clarity returned with each bite.

If Jonathan sued Christopher, she’d need a plan—fast. Negotiating privately meant hefty compensation, but letting it go to court? That risked everything.

She’d have to talk to Andrew. This mess was far from over.
###Chapter 372

Judith Reeves was never an easy woman to handle.

When Evelyn returned home, her eyelids felt like lead weights from exhaustion. She glanced at Margaret.

"I'm craving honey-glazed chicken and pineapple pork tomorrow."

"Of course, dear. I'll get the freshest ingredients at the market. You should invite Christopher over too."

Only then did Evelyn remember Christopher's unusual silence that day. Perhaps guilt was consuming him after what happened with Jonathan.

After a quick shower, she collapsed onto her bed. Nothing could have stopped her from falling asleep—her body demanded rest.

At dawn, her phone's shrill ringtone shattered the silence.

She fumbled for the device. "Hello?"

"Wake up, Evelyn! We're going shopping for Jonathan's recovery meal. At my age, I can't handle these early mornings anymore. Consider this your chance to learn his preferences—"

Evelyn ended the call immediately. 5:03 AM glared from her screen.

Had Judith really called at this ungodly hour just to cook for Jonathan? Absurd!

She silenced her phone, officially resigning from unpaid maid duties. Jonathan's situation didn't concern her anymore.

With Nathaniel involved, Christopher would be fine anyway.

Evelyn burrowed back under the covers, sleeping until sunlight streamed through her curtains. Stretching lazily, she finally felt human again.

Her phone showed seven missed calls from Judith. The woman's persistence knew no bounds.

But Evelyn deserved this break. Pregnancy drained her energy—she couldn't be at everyone's beck and call.

The moment she stepped into the hallway, heavenly aromas from the kitchen made her stomach growl.

"Aunt Margaret, you're a culinary genius!"

"Where's Christopher? Call him over," Margaret suggested while stirring a pot.

Evelyn dialed Christopher's number. The line connected instantly—to a woman's voice.

"Hello?"

Evelyn froze. This wasn't the usual assistant. Had Christopher moved on already?

Remembering last time's embarrassment, she muttered, "Wrong number," and hung up.

If Christopher had female company now, they'd probably spent the night together. Best not to disturb.

"He's swamped with work," Evelyn told Margaret, happily devouring the entire honey-glazed chicken herself later.

Her heart and stomach overflowed with contentment. Nothing compared to good food and peace.

"Evelyn, your appetite's grown remarkably," Margaret observed. "You're practically glowing. Though careful—that belly might make people think you're expecting!"

Evelyn's smile faltered for a millisecond. "Oh, I'm definitely expecting... more chicken and pork!"

Margaret's laughter filled the kitchen.

Post-lunch, Evelyn lounged on the sofa when her phone buzzed—Jonathan this time.

She moved to the balcony. "Jonathan?"

"Don't mind Mother. She means well, always fussing over me."

"I get that. But please ask her to stop calling me. Since I'll never be her daughter-in-law, she needn't train me for the role." Her voice stayed flat.

"What's that supposed to mean? You're not coming to the hospital anymore?" Jonathan's tone sharpened.
###Chapter 373

Evelyn found Jonathan's demanding tone utterly ridiculous.

The apple didn't fall far from the tree—Judith and Jonathan were equally shameless.

Since they had chosen to confront her with such audacity, Evelyn saw no point in continuing the conversation.

She responded coldly, "Jonathan, I owe you nothing. What I did yesterday was the last shred of kindness you'll ever receive from me."

"Evelyn, if it weren’t for your brother, I wouldn’t be lying in this hospital bed. I even kept quiet to the police about who attacked me—for your sake. After everything I’ve sacrificed, can’t you show a little compassion?"

Just then, Judith’s shrill voice cut in. "What? Jonathan, are you saying Evelyn’s brother is responsible for your injuries? Why didn’t you tell me?"

The phone was abruptly shoved back at Evelyn. "Get to the hospital right now, Evelyn Carter. I demand answers, or I’ll have the police arrest your brother!"

"Go ahead." Evelyn ended the call.

Though worry gnawed at her, Nathaniel had assured her everything would be fine.

Surely, he wouldn’t let anything happen to Christopher—they were brothers, after all.

The thought steadied her. That afternoon, she headed to campus for lectures.

She needed to focus on her studies to pass her exams in one go.

Her phone buzzed relentlessly, but she ignored it.

Jonathan’s true colors were finally exposed. If he was using the assault as leverage now, he’d only demand more later.

After some thought, she decided she’d rather he went to the police.

Christopher wasn’t careless—he wouldn’t leave evidence behind. Without proof, Jonathan had no case.

Besides, with Nathaniel, a skilled lawyer, in the family, she had nothing to fear.

During a break, she checked her phone. Missed calls and furious messages from Judith and Jonathan flooded her notifications.

She dismissed them, but an entertainment headline caught her eye:

"Scandal Unfolds: Rising Star Linked to Wealthy Tycoon."

The photo showed the same woman who had been clinging to Julian that night.

Evelyn had assumed there was something between them, but perhaps she’d jumped to conclusions.

Her finger tapped the link before she could stop herself. The singer looked stunning in a sleek black dress.

But the man beside her was only captured from behind.

Evelyn zoomed in. The suit button was unmistakable—she had sewn it herself for Nathaniel.

A bitter smile touched her lips as emotions churned inside her.

First, it was Victoria Sinclair. Now, a famous singer.

Both women matched Nathaniel’s world perfectly.

She had vowed to move on, yet seeing him with someone else still stung.

Her hand drifted to her stomach. "You’re all I have now, my darlings. Let’s forget about that heartless man."
###Chapter 374

The jerk had the nerve to call Evelyn yesterday, taunting her about being a gold-digger. As if he had any right.

Fuming, she sent the picture to Nathaniel. "You're not so innocent either. Who's this backup girl now?"

But after typing it out, she thought it sounded too desperate. Too weak.

So she deleted it.

Instead, she mirrored his cold, clipped style. "Nice."

One word. That was all it took to drip with sarcasm.

People who knew how to cut deep didn’t waste words.

Evelyn tossed her phone aside and forced herself back to her notes.

But focus was impossible.

Her gaze kept flicking to the silent screen, wondering how Nathaniel would react.

Nothing.

Then, finally—a notification.

Her pulse jumped before she could stop it.

But it wasn’t him.

It was Jonathan.

"Evelyn, I still have the recording. The one where you admitted your brother was the real culprit."

Her stomach dropped.

She had said that. In a moment of weakness, she’d confessed.

Her fingers tightened around the phone. "What do you want?"

"Come to the hospital. Let’s talk."

"We have nothing to discuss."

"If you don’t show up, I’ll send this to the police. You really want your brother in jail?"

Her jaw clenched.

Fine.

She grabbed her bag and hailed a cab.

She knew exactly what this was. Blackmail.

But she wasn’t defenseless. If it came down to it, she’d handle the fallout.

The hospital room was too bright.

Jonathan and Judith sat waiting, their expressions smug.

Evelyn didn’t bother with pleasantries. "Get to the point."

Judith’s lip curled. "That attitude won’t help you. If it weren’t for your brother, my son wouldn’t be here!"

Evelyn scoffed. "Mrs. Reeves, let’s be clear—I’ve never had feelings for your son. Not once. And I certainly never led him on. You’re delusional if you thought I’d ever be your daughter-in-law."

Why sugarcoat it? The gloves were off.

Judith’s face turned red. "Then why are you still working for him? Have you no shame?"

"Correction—he begged me to stay. Ask him yourself."

She turned to Jonathan, done with Judith’s dramatics.

But he just smirked.

"Evelyn, you must’ve liked me a little. Otherwise, why take a job at my small studio instead of some big corporation?"

Disgust twisted in her gut.

She’d expected the blackmail.

But this? Pathetic.

"Where’s the recording?" she demanded, cutting straight to the chase. "What’s your game?"
###Chapter 375

Evelyn had no patience for games. Not a single second.

Yet Jonathan gazed at her with adoration. "Evelyn, you're dodging my question."

Disgust twisted her lips. "I swear on my life—if I ever have feelings for you, may lightning strike me dead. Do you understand now?"

Her brutal oath left him utterly speechless.

Never in his wildest dreams had he imagined being rejected so harshly.

In his mind, a divorced woman like Evelyn should be grateful for his attention. A successful man like him was a rare catch.

Still, he recovered swiftly. "Evelyn, there's no need for cruelty. I won’t hand that recording to the police—on one condition. Be mine. Once we're together, your brothers become family. I’ll let bygones be bygones."

This was a trap. Blatant manipulation.

How could he speak of family so casually?

The world truly was a twisted place.

She had thought her adoptive parents were bizarre, but Jonathan and Judith took insanity to new heights.

Good people were rare indeed.

Nathaniel had warned her about Jonathan’s cunning nature. So had Christopher. Now, she saw it firsthand.

Just as she suspected—he was using the assault incident as leverage.

Desperate, she offered, "Jonathan, we can compensate you. Name your price."

Judith’s eyes gleamed at the mention of money, but Jonathan dismissed it instantly. "I don’t want money. I want you."

Marriage would bind Evelyn to him—and grant him access to her brothers’ wealth. Far more valuable than a one-time payout.

Evelyn scoffed. "Jonathan, as your mother said, a divorced woman like me isn’t worthy of you."

"My heart belongs to you, Evelyn. Your past doesn’t change that."

"Then here’s the truth—I’m pregnant." She played her final card.

Judith gasped. "Pregnant? Is it yours, Jonathan?"

Evelyn nearly laughed. As if she’d ever let him touch her.

Calmly, she clarified, "They’re my ex-husband’s twins. I’m keeping them. If you still want me, congratulations—you’ll be a stepfather. Can you handle that?"

Jonathan’s jaw clenched. The thought of raising another man’s children sickened him.

But he forced a smile. "If it means having you, I’ll accept anything."

Money could buy him his own heirs later.

Evelyn hadn’t expected that answer. It almost sounded sincere—but her instincts screamed lie.

Christopher had spent days teaching her how to spot deception. No man would surrender his pride so easily.

Jonathan’s quick acceptance? Suspicious.

She narrowed her eyes. "What exactly do you see in me? Tell me, and I’ll change it."

Why would he chase an orphan with nothing to offer?

"I’ve proven my devotion. No other man would go this far for you. I’d even jump off a building to show you."

Madness.

Evelyn didn’t hesitate. "Jonathan, I’ll never love you. Not even if you die. That’s final."
###Chapter 376

The tension in the air was suffocating. If this conversation dragged on any longer, Evelyn feared her blood pressure would skyrocket beyond control.

"Evelyn Carter, are you really just going to walk away? What about the recording?" Jonathan's voice cut through the silence like a blade.

She turned slightly, casting him a sidelong glance. "Why don’t you play it for me first?"

The prolonged silence that followed told her everything she needed to know—there was no recording. It had all been a bluff.

This entire visit had been pointless.

Frustration coiled in her chest as she wondered why Christopher hadn’t responded to any of her messages. The only way to settle this mess was to speak with him directly.

But right now, Christopher seemed as unreliable as ever.

Lost in her thoughts, Evelyn stepped out of the elevator, the lingering disgust from her confrontation with Jonathan and Judith clinging to her like a shadow.

Then, Nathaniel called.

She answered immediately. "What is it?"

"About that photo—it's not what you think."

Today had been full of surprises, but this? Nathaniel Whitmore, explaining himself to her? Unbelievable.

"Enough. I don’t want to hear it. I’m done," she snapped, her voice icy.

Before she could hang up, Judith’s shrill voice pierced the air from behind. "Evelyn Carter! How dare you be so heartless? Jonathan jumped off a building for you! You ungrateful wretch!"

Evelyn barely had time to react before Judith shoved her violently.

She crashed to the ground, her arms instinctively wrapping around her abdomen. A sharp pain shot through her, draining the color from her face as she gasped.

Nathaniel’s voice crackled through the phone, laced with panic. "Evelyn! What happened? Where are you?"

She reached weakly for the phone, but it was just out of reach. Gritting her teeth, she managed a strained whisper, "Nathaniel, I—"

Darkness swallowed her before she could finish.

On the other end, Nathaniel had just landed from his flight. His expression turned glacial as he turned to Robert. "Which hospital is Jonathan at?"

"Hope Hospital."

"Get a helicopter ready—now!" Nathaniel barked, his voice razor-sharp.

He tried calling Evelyn again, but there was no answer.

Dread coiled around him like a vice. It was the same suffocating fear he’d felt when he’d learned of Evelyn’s abduction. Even with Julian by her side, he had pulled every string to find her.

Now, her desperate cry for him had left him breathless.

Regaining his composure, he ordered Robert, "Evelyn might be hurt at the hospital. Contact the director immediately—ensure her safety at all costs."

The news hit Robert like a thunderbolt, sending a chill down his spine.

Within minutes, a helicopter was prepped, and Nathaniel was airborne, racing toward Hope Hospital.

Mid-flight, the hospital director called. "Mr. Whitmore, your wife has been taken to the emergency room."

Nathaniel’s grip on the phone tightened. "She walks out of there unharmed. I’ll arrange for any medical equipment you need."

"Don’t worry, Mr. Whitmore. We’re doing everything we can, but her condition is unstable," Simon Whitmore reported.

Nathaniel’s jaw clenched. "Did she hit her head?"

"No." A pause. "She’s pregnant."
###Chapter 377

Nathaniel's thoughts spiraled out of control as the shocking news sank in.

"Evelyn's pregnant? Then who's the father?" A torrent of questions assaulted his mind.

Before he could process this further, Simon's urgent voice crackled through the phone. "Mr. Whitmore, if complications arise, who should we prioritize? The mother or the child?"

Confronted with this impossible choice, Nathaniel drew a sharp breath.

All he knew in this moment was that the universe was mocking him - he'd been betrayed.

If Evelyn was carrying another man's child, what did that make him?

His voice turned glacial. "Must I really spell it out?"

"The child then?" Simon pressed, assuming heirs mattered most to wealthy men like Nathaniel.

A dark storm crossed Nathaniel's features. "Save the mother. The baby means nothing to me."

He would never waste concern on a child that wasn't his blood.

Suppressing his urge to demand the hospital treat Evelyn was the only mercy he could muster.

If anyone dared suggest he care about that baby, he couldn't be responsible for his actions.

Meanwhile, Robert caught the crucial detail from that conversation - Evelyn was pregnant!

Robert expected Nathaniel to be overjoyed by the news.

Yet judging by Nathaniel's thunderous expression, the baby clearly wasn't his.

Though Robert trusted Evelyn's character, he wisely kept silent.

After hanging up, Nathaniel radiated fury. Robert sealed his lips tight.

Would knowing this secret get him killed?

Being an executive assistant these days required nerves of steel.

Twenty minutes later, the helicopter touched down on the hospital roof.

Nathaniel disembarked to find Simon waiting. As the hospital's largest benefactor, Nathaniel warranted VIP treatment.

Despite his stormy demeanor, concern bled through. "How is she?"

"Congratulations, Mr. Whitmore. Both mother and baby are perfectly healthy."

Nathaniel froze momentarily - he'd secretly hoped this accident would resolve his problem.

Without another word, he stormed toward the private suite.

Evelyn lay peacefully in bed, her expression serene.

No matter how furious he felt, he reined in his temper for now.

He turned sharply to Simon. "What happened? I heard shouting on the phone. Someone pushed her."

Evelyn wouldn't have screamed like that without cause. Something terrible had occurred.

That middle-aged woman's shrill voice - she must be involved.

Simon answered carefully, "Security footage confirms Mrs. Whitmore was pushed. But while we treated her, the woman and her son fled the hospital."

Nathaniel yanked at his tie, baffled why Evelyn would visit that scheming man at the hospital, only to get hurt.

A terrible suspicion took root - was Jonathan the father?
###Chapter 378

"Don't worry, Mr. Whitmore. We'll investigate this thoroughly. Their medical expenses remain unsettled," Simon assured in a professional tone.

"Lower your voice. I can hear you perfectly fine," Nathaniel scolded quietly.

But it was too late. Evelyn had already regained consciousness.

Pain radiated through every inch of her body. As her eyelids fluttered open, her trembling hands immediately went to her abdomen, terrified for her unborn children.

Their safety remained uncertain, sending waves of panic through her. When she lifted her gaze, Nathaniel stood before her.

Her pulse quickened. "What are you doing here? Weren't you supposed to be overseas? Am I hallucinating?"

His lips curled into a mocking smile. "Feeling guilty about something, Evelyn?"

She pressed her lips together, refusing to respond.

Robert, sensing the mounting tension, discreetly gestured for Simon and the medical staff to exit.

The room emptied, leaving the estranged couple in suffocating silence.

A weakened Evelyn propped herself against the headboard, noticing the bandages covering her knees and the antiseptic smell from her treated elbow.

Though questions burned in her mind, she dared not inquire about her babies' condition under Nathaniel's piercing stare.

"Lost your tongue, Evelyn Carter? Weren't you boasting about being some independent woman? Collecting admirers like trading cards? Enjoying your little rebellion now that your backup plan turned against you?"

His cruel words stung. "This was an accident! How was I supposed to predict that deranged woman would attack me?" she fired back.

"Problems with your master plan? I thought you had that scheming bastard wrapped around your finger. Couldn't handle your future mother-in-law's temper?" he taunted.

Her eyes widened in disbelief. "Who told you I came here for him? I only—"

"Then enlighten me. Were you touring hospitals for fun? Checking what mental disorder you qualify for?" he interrupted.

Frustration boiled over. "You're the one who needs psychiatric evaluation! Jonathan got hospitalized! If I hadn't intervened, he would've filed charges!"

Nathaniel's eyebrows shot up. "Excuse me?"

"Someone assaulted him and fractured his leg. That's why he's here. I came to settle matters before he involved the authorities. Why else would I be in this godforsaken place?" she snapped in one breath.

His expression became unreadable, the intensity of his gaze making her skin prickle. "Why are you looking at me like that?"

Nathaniel hadn't anticipated Evelyn confronting Jonathan about the incident, hence his surprise. "Even if he reported it, the perpetrator would never be identified."

The professionals he'd hired were experts—they'd broken just enough bones to cause pain without permanent damage. A coward like Jonathan would never trace it back to him.

Evelyn scoffed. "With today's forensic technology? Please. Criminals always leave traces. When they're caught, assault charges carry severe penalties."

The corner of Nathaniel's mouth twitched. "Indeed. The consequences would be... severe."

"Then why spout such nonsense?" Her irritation grew.

His mood inexplicably lightened. "Save your efforts. Jonathan has no evidence."

Her laugh held no humor. "How very confident. One might think you're the culprit yourself."
###Chapter 379

Evelyn barely had time to process her own words when Nathaniel's confession hit her like a thunderbolt.

"You're right," he admitted without hesitation, his voice dripping with arrogance. "I am the one who did it."

Her breath caught.

Had she misheard him?

His lips curled into a smirk as he took in her stunned expression. "Why do you look so shocked? Did you really not know it was me?"

The familiar sulk returned to his features.

She swallowed hard. "I—I thought it was Christopher."

"Christopher?" His eyes darkened instantly. "Since when do you have a brother?"

Evelyn swiftly redirected the conversation, her voice sharp. "Answer me, Nathaniel Whitmore. Why did you beat Jonathan Reeves to a pulp?"

If she had known the truth earlier, she wouldn’t have wasted her time at the hospital, subjected to Jonathan and Judith’s revolting behavior.

Nathaniel scoffed. "Why not? Do I need a reason?"

Evelyn was speechless. Because of him, she had endured days of Jonathan and Judith’s disgusting antics.

She had blamed Christopher, only to realize the real culprit was standing right in front of her—this infuriating man!

A pillow flew straight at Nathaniel’s face. "Are you out of your mind? Couldn’t you have warned me before pulling something like that? I wouldn’t have gotten involved!"

She wouldn’t have cared less if Jonathan had gone to the police.

Why? Because Nathaniel could walk through hell untouched.

Her voice trembled with fury. "Get out. I don’t want to see you right now."

Nathaniel dodged the pillow effortlessly, his gaze piercing. "Is this how you react when you find out I was the one who did it?"

He had genuinely believed her concern was for him.

She arched a brow. "My attitude depends entirely on the other person’s actions. This is what you get. Fair, don’t you think?"

His expression darkened.

"Three years ago, I married you when you were on the brink of death after that car accident. No one knew if you’d survive. And what did I get in return?" Her voice turned icy. "Only a fool makes the same mistake twice."

Nathaniel stepped closer, his voice low. "How do you know it’ll be a mistake if you don’t try again?"

Evelyn could only stare at him, lost for words.

His gaze sharpened. "You still haven’t answered me. Who is this brother of yours?"

She waved a dismissive hand. "Just someone from back home."

She had no intention of revealing her family secrets to Nathaniel—especially not the fact that she had three brothers and three cousins.

Not when she was planning to leave for Nord City and start a new life.

The less he knew, the harder it would be for him to find her.

For the sake of her babies, she had to be careful.

Nathaniel’s eyes narrowed dangerously. "What brother?"

As far as he knew, Evelyn was an orphan.

She shrugged. "We have a lot of relatives in the village. They’re my cousins."

His gaze dropped to her stomach, his tone turning stern. "Cut the act. You mean the father of the baby, don’t you?"

Her breath hitched.

Nathaniel knew?

He knew about the babies?

Since waking up, her thoughts had been consumed with worry for them—until Nathaniel’s presence turned her into a nervous wreck, making her forget everything else.

Somewhere in the back of her mind, she had foolishly convinced herself he would never find out.

Now, reality was crashing down on her.

She had imagined this moment countless times—Nathaniel discovering the truth. She had prepared herself mentally for it.

Taking a deep breath, she steadied herself.

He only knew about the pregnancy.

Not that he was the father.

As long as she never admitted it, she could still protect them.

At least, that’s what she told herself.
###Chapter 380

From the very beginning, Nathaniel Whitmore had been unequivocal about not wanting children. If he discovered Evelyn Carter's pregnancy, he would undoubtedly demand she terminate it.

Evelyn's decision came swiftly. "You're absolutely right!" she declared.

His face darkened instantly. "So this is why you've been so desperate for a divorce? You're carrying another man's child? I knew your sudden change of heart was suspicious - bringing up divorce out of nowhere. Not only have you found someone else, but you're pregnant with his baby!"

Cold sweat trickled down Evelyn's back as she fought to maintain her composure. The timing was critical - with the pregnancy progressing, paternity tests could now be performed prenatally. She couldn't take that risk!

Her fingers curled into fists beneath the blanket, though her expression remained calm. "I conceived after we signed the divorce papers. Legally, I've done nothing wrong."

A bitter relief washed over her. Nathaniel's poor opinion of her actually worked in her favor this time, providing cover for the child's existence.

"We haven't finalized the divorce yet. You're still my wife!" Nathaniel countered sharply.

Evelyn met his glare without flinching. "And aren't you engaged to Victoria Sinclair? That's the pot calling the kettle black! We've only been maintaining this charade for Eleanor Whitmore's sake, with an agreement not to interfere in each other's lives. I've kept my end of the bargain."

As the words left her lips, the air grew thick with Nathaniel's silent, dangerous energy.

But retreat wasn't an option. Any sign of weakness could endanger her child.

Nathaniel's voice turned icy. "Our agreement never included you getting pregnant!"

"Did it include your engagement to Victoria?" Evelyn shot back, her protective instincts flaring like a mother bear's.

Nathaniel leaned in until their faces were inches apart, his dark eyes burning. "No man tolerates being cuckolded, Evelyn. I'll give you one choice."

She instinctively recoiled, but the headboard stopped her retreat.

At this proximity, she could see every perfect feature of his face - the flawless skin, the faint shadow of stubble, even the individual lashes framing his piercing eyes.

Their breaths mingled in the charged space between them.

Evelyn's lips trembled. "What choice?"

"Terminate the pregnancy," he growled.

"Never!" Her refusal was immediate and absolute.

Her heart shattered even as she spoke. He would never accept this child.

Nathaniel's expression hardened. "You misunderstand - this isn't a request. Since you refuse the easy way, I'll have a doctor perform the procedure."

"No!" Evelyn clutched his arm desperately. "Please!"

His fingers dug into her chin. "Since when do I grant favors? Until those divorce papers are signed, you remain my wife. Did you think I'd raise another man's bastard?"

Desperation clawed at Evelyn's throat. "Nathaniel Whitmore, you have no right to take my child from me!"

His cruel laugh sent chills down her spine. "It's not my child."

"Who says it isn't?" Evelyn screamed, her voice breaking with raw emotion.
###Chapter 381

Evelyn lost control and shouted at Nathaniel, her maternal instincts roaring to life.

She knew his stubborn nature all too well. If he threatened to arrange an abortion, he would make it happen.

The hospital room plunged into silence.

Nathaniel's eyes darkened with disbelief. "What did you just say?"

His fingers gripped her chin, forcing her to meet his piercing gaze.

Evelyn swallowed hard. "You heard me."

Regret twisted inside her, but she had no choice. This was his territory—his influence could erase her child in an instant.

Nathaniel's attention dropped to her stomach.

A shudder ran through Evelyn as she instinctively shielded her belly, but he shoved her hand away. The weight of his stare paralyzed her. She and her unborn child were at his mercy.

He exhaled sharply, his expression unreadable. Then, his voice came out rough. "That's mine?"

"Yes," Evelyn admitted quickly. She needed to pacify him, buy time until she could reach her brothers in Nord City. Once there, Nathaniel would never find her.

But his lips curled into a sneer. "Evelyn Carter, do you think I'm an idiot? Lying to protect some bastard? Where's your dignity?"

Her breath hitched. He doubted her?

"It is yours," she insisted.

Nathaniel scoffed. "You've spread your legs for half the city. How can you be sure?" His voice dripped with venom. "I never even wanted you."

Her cheeks burned. "You did. Once. Or have you forgotten?"

His jaw tightened. "Because you drugged me."

Her heart cracked. "So you don't believe me."

"Not a chance." He released her and stepped back, his voice glacial. "I'll arrange the procedure."

Evelyn's voice trembled as he turned to leave. "Would you keep it... if it were really yours?"

She held onto that fragile hope. If he hesitated, she'd demand a paternity test.

But Nathaniel didn't even glance back. "There's no if in this world."

The door slammed shut behind him.

Evelyn's composure shattered. Hot tears spilled down her face as she stared at the ceiling, choking back sobs. She'd asked him this before—why hadn't she learned?

Why did she keep hurting herself? The man she loved never existed.

Curling into herself, she cradled her stomach, whispering, "Don't be afraid, little one. Mommy won't let anything happen to you."

Outside the ward, Nathaniel stood rigid in the hallway, his tie ripped off, fists clenched. The urge to destroy something clawed at him.

Robert, his assistant, paled at the sight. It had been years since he'd seen Nathaniel this unhinged.
###Chapter 382

Nathaniel glared at the hospital director standing beside him. "What are the risks if she terminates the pregnancy?"

The director blinked in confusion. Why was Nathaniel suddenly discussing abortion when Evelyn had only just been confirmed pregnant?

But he didn’t dare question the order. "It varies, Mr. Whitmore. Early termination is safer, but multiple procedures can lead to complications."

Nathaniel’s jaw tightened. "Schedule the surgery."

The director hesitated. "Sir, with all due respect, Mrs. Whitmore’s condition is delicate. An abortion now could… permanently damage her fertility. And given she’s carrying twins—"

"Twins?" Nathaniel’s expression turned thunderous.

Robert, his assistant, winced. This was the last thing his boss needed to hear—his wife pregnant with another man’s child.

Realizing his blunder, the director quickly backtracked. "Shall I arrange the procedure immediately?"

Nathaniel’s scowl deepened.

Robert shot the director a warning look. Stop talking.

Suddenly, a nurse burst in, breathless. "Director! The patient—she jumped out the window!"

Nathaniel was out the door before she finished speaking. He kicked open the hospital room door, only to find the window wide open and the bed empty.

"Find her!" he roared. "If she’s hurt, I’ll burn this place to the ground!"

He stormed to the window, expecting to see Evelyn’s broken body below. But there was nothing.

"You said she jumped. Where is she?" he demanded.

The nurse stammered. "I—I only heard someone say she did!"

The head nurse rushed in to clarify. "She didn’t jump, sir. She climbed down the drainpipe from the balcony and escaped through the first floor."

The director exhaled in relief. "Thank God." If Evelyn had died, his career would be over.

Nathaniel kicked the bedframe with a snarl. "Evelyn Carter, you’ve got nerve! Track her down—now!"

Meanwhile, Evelyn sprinted through the streets, her hospital gown flapping behind her. She couldn’t let Nathaniel’s men catch her.

Her phone buzzed. Julian’s name flashed on the screen. She answered instantly, gasping. "Julian! I need help!"

Julian had been about to ask where to meet her. Instead, he slammed the accelerator. "Where are you? Hide somewhere safe—I’m coming!"

Evelyn ducked into a nearby park, but her gown made her stand out. A jogger slowed. "Miss, do you need assistance?"

She shook her head. "No, my brother’s picking me up."

Only Julian could save her now.

Her phone rang again. Nathaniel’s name this time.

She rejected the call and silenced her phone, scanning the park with wide eyes. Every shadow felt like a threat.

Then—footsteps. A man’s voice called out.
###Chapter 383

The crisp autumn air carried the faint scent of fallen leaves as Evelyn Carter pressed herself deeper into the shadows of the park bench. Her fingers trembled against the rough fabric of her hospital gown, the chill seeping into her bones.

Footsteps crunched against the gravel path.

Her breath hitched.

Both siblings had their secrets, and the topic was dropped.

Back at Julian's apartment, Evelyn immediately called Jonathan from the bathroom. "Withdraw the charges. We're not pursuing this anymore."

"Evelyn, giving up so soon? What did your ex offer you?" Jonathan sneered.

"None of your business. Just drop it. And as for your mother, I won't press charges against her either. We're even now," Evelyn snapped.

Jonathan persisted, "Evelyn, now that everything's cleared up, why don't you come back to the studio? I—"

Evelyn hung up before he could finish. She wasn't sparing Judith for Jonathan's sake—she was protecting her child. The thought of seeing either of them again made her stomach turn.

Soon, Christopher returned with an assortment of delicious food for Evelyn.

His careful attention told her he still blamed himself for her injury. She could feel the love radiating from her brothers.

That settled it. She would return to Nord City and live with them.

Late that night, Andrew arrived straight from the airport, but Evelyn was already asleep.

Julian waited for him in the living room. "Don't let Evelyn find out," he murmured.

Andrew nodded. "I know. I've already arranged Jonathan's... consequences."

Christopher's expression darkened. "We can't let them off easy. That snake still thinks he has a chance with her. Dream on."

After a brief discussion, the three brothers agreed—Jonathan wouldn't escape unscathed.

Evelyn stayed at Julian's place for two more days. Once her wounds had nearly healed, she returned to her studies to prepare for exams.

As she stepped out of the library, a middle-aged woman rushed toward her. "Evelyn! I've been looking everywhere for you! Why aren't you answering my calls?"

Evelyn's smile vanished at the sight of Judith. "I don't owe you anything."

She had blocked Judith's number long ago.

"Evelyn, I know I acted rashly at the hospital. I'm sorry. Please don't hold it against an old woman like me," Judith begged.

Evelyn frowned. "Let go. I don't want to see you, and I don't accept your apology. I made myself clear to Jonathan. Don't come looking for me again."

"Evelyn, wait! Don't you know?" Judith cried. "Jonathan's been arrested!"
###Chapter 395

Evelyn froze when she heard that Jonathan had been arrested. "What are you talking about?"

"Evelyn, you're the only one who can help me now. Ever since my son was taken into custody, the entire studio staff has abandoned their posts. Some even demanded their unpaid salaries from me. Where am I supposed to get that kind of money? My son trusted you more than anyone. He always said you were the most gifted designer in the company. If you come back and support his business, there might still be a chance to save it," Judith pleaded, desperation thick in her voice.

Now Evelyn understood why Judith had sought her out with such humility. She had been waiting here, hoping to manipulate her into returning.

Evelyn remained unmoved. "I'm sorry, but I've already resigned. I won't be going back."

"Evelyn, I know you and my son were once close. It was my fault for interfering. I regret it now. But with him in trouble, you're the only person I can turn to. If you help him through this crisis and get him out, I won't stand in your way anymore. You can be together," Judith begged again, her voice trembling.

Evelyn frowned in disbelief. "Do you and your son share the same delusion? I never had feelings for Jonathan. He was the one who wouldn't leave me alone. I will never be with him. Is that clear enough?"

She turned to leave, unwilling to waste another second on this conversation.

Judith's face twisted in anger. "Oh, so now that my son is down on his luck, you're abandoning him? Don't forget—you're a divorced woman! Who do you think you are to look down on him?"

Evelyn's expression remained icy. "I'd rather stay single for the rest of my life than be with Jonathan."

"Evelyn Carter, stop pretending! You rushed to the hospital to take care of him when he was injured last time. This is just a temporary setback. My son has powerful connections—he'll bounce back soon enough. And when he does, you'll regret turning your back on him!" Judith snapped, her face red with fury.

Evelyn arched a brow. "Is that so? I'll be waiting for that day, then."

"Evelyn Carter, no wonder your marriage failed! You're nothing but a gold-digger! What man would ever want someone like you? Let me tell you—no decent man will look twice at a divorced woman like you. Do you really think you're some prize? You'll never find another man as devoted as my son!" Judith shrieked, her voice rising hysterically.

Before Evelyn could respond, a firm hand settled on her shoulder, and a smooth voice cut in. "I'm afraid you're mistaken. I happen to be her suitor. And even if she were twice her age, she'd still have admirers lining up for her."

Evelyn recognized Christopher's voice and stayed silent, letting him handle Judith. The woman's venomous words were making her stomach churn.

Judith's eyes bulged when she took in Christopher's striking features. "Where did this pretty boy come from?"

Christopher smirked. "Nord City. And for the record, my net worth would make your mama's boy look like a pauper."

"Liar! You're probably just some gigolo. How could a woman like Evelyn land a wealthy man? She's an orphan! Her family has nothing!" Judith spat.

Christopher's expression darkened. He lifted his wrist, flashing an expensive watch, then glanced at Evelyn. "Let's go. I just bought a new sports car. Want to take it for a spin?"

Evelyn played along, tilting her head. "Is it a gift for me?"

"Of course. If you asked for the stars, I'd pluck them from the sky for you," Christopher said with a playful wink.

Evelyn followed him outside the school gates. Sure enough, a sleek, high-end sports car gleamed under the sunlight, parked right by the curb.
###Chapter 396

Evelyn Carter's eyes widened as she took in the sleek sports car parked before her. Her breath hitched. Was this man truly that wealthy?

Judith Reeves, still stubborn, sneered. "Evelyn Carter, he's just toying with you. Only my son would offer you marriage."

A soft laugh escaped Evelyn's lips. "Marriage? As if that's some divine gift. I couldn't care less."

Christopher Montgomery leaned casually against the car, his sharp gaze flickering toward Judith. She visibly shrank back. "What do you want?"

His voice was ice. "If you dare harass Evelyn again, I'll ensure your son never sees the outside of a prison cell."

Judith paled. It wasn't until Christopher drove away that the realization struck—he was likely behind her son's arrest.

But the sports car was already gone.

She collapsed onto the pavement, regret clawing at her chest. If only she hadn’t provoked Evelyn. Now, with her son locked away, what could she do?

Meanwhile, Evelyn walked beside Christopher, her mind racing.

Jonathan Reeves' arrest had stunned her. She quickly texted her former colleagues, piecing together the truth.

One reply read: "Heard Mr. Reeves got busted for financial fraud. Apparently, he fabricated names to embezzle school funds and diverted investor money into his own accounts—bought himself properties."

Another chimed in: "Now that his schemes are exposed, he’s done for. Facing years unless he repays everything. Disgusting. Good thing you left when you did."

Evelyn exhaled sharply. She hadn’t expected Jonathan to be so corrupt. She’d never noticed before.

Now, she saw him for what he was—a fraud.

She hadn’t pressed charges against Judith, but karma had caught up with Jonathan.

Christopher hesitated. "Evelyn... was that woman Jonathan’s mother?"

She nodded. "Yes. He was arrested. It doesn’t look good for him."

"Are you... worried about him?" Christopher asked carefully.

Evelyn arched a brow. "Why would I waste a thought on a man like him? He dug his own grave."

Christopher relaxed slightly.

Then, cautiously, he broached the subject. "Evelyn, I might have misheard, but... did that woman mention a divorce?"

Evelyn paused. "You heard right."

Christopher’s grip tightened on the wheel. "You’re serious? Who was it?"

How dare anyone divorce Evelyn? Marrying her was a privilege, and that fool had thrown it away!

Evelyn pressed her lips together. "It doesn’t matter who he was. It’s over."

"Evelyn," Christopher said firmly, pulling the car over. "You’re not alone anymore. You have us now. Who was he? I swear—"

She cut him off softly. "I was the one who wanted the divorce."
###Chapter 397

Christopher paused. "Well, that's also your ex-husband's fault. Even with your gentle nature, you can't tolerate him. Clearly, he's the problem."

Evelyn was kind-hearted, pure, and utterly adorable. What kind of fool wouldn't cherish such a woman? To drive her to file for divorce?

Without question, the blame lay entirely with that man.

Evelyn gave a resigned smile. "Christopher, I share some responsibility too."

She shouldn't have married Nathaniel on impulse all those years ago.

Christopher ruffled her hair affectionately. "To me, Evelyn, you're perfect! Divorce means nothing these days. I know plenty of eligible bachelors in Nord City. When you're ready, I'll arrange introductions."

"Christopher, I'm not looking for any relationships right now," Evelyn sighed.

"Exactly! Marriage is where love goes to die. You should play the field. Move on when you get bored."

Evelyn shot him an exasperated look. This was classic Christopher's perspective on romance.

After a thoughtful pause, she said, "Please don't tell the family about my divorce yet."

"Evelyn, we wouldn't judge. We'd just be furious you suffered alone. If we'd found you sooner... But if you're worried about your ex causing trouble, Andrew's a lawyer. We could make him pay—literally."

"That's not it. I just want a clean break. I'll be leaving soon anyway, and I want all ties with Nathaniel severed completely." Evelyn shook her head firmly.

"If that's what you want." Christopher relented. "But about Alexander—"

Evelyn understood. "I'll tell Alexander myself when we return to Nord City."

And about the baby growing inside her. Once safely in Nord City, she wouldn't need to hide anything from her brothers anymore.

Christopher nodded. "By the way, there's an exciting music festival at your university. They're hosting a prestigious piano ensemble from Nord City."

"I know—the renowned Clair de Lune ensemble. Music majors are competing fiercely for apprenticeship spots. It's a career-making opportunity." Evelyn nodded.

Christopher turned to her intently. "Evelyn, do you want to attend?"

"If time permits, I'd love to experience world-class musicianship firsthand." Her eyes sparkled with anticipation.

"That's not what I meant." Christopher leaned closer. "Do you want to join the ensemble? You've got remarkable talent. In Nord City, you could pursue music professionally."

Christopher genuinely believed in his sister's potential. Her childhood circumstances had stifled her gifts. Had she grown up with them, she'd undoubtedly be a concert pianist by now.

Evelyn looked stunned. "Christopher, I'm far too old to start. I only know basic pieces—not even at a child's competition level. Joining Clair de Lune? Don't tease me."

"Evelyn, dreams matter. What if this one comes true?" Christopher's tone held hidden meaning. If she agreed, arrangements could easily be made.

He had years to nurture Evelyn into the brilliant pianist she was meant to be.
###Chapter 398

The morning sun cast golden streaks across Evelyn Carter's path as she hurried toward campus. Her textbooks felt heavier than usual today, weighted with unspoken worries.

Her phone vibrated violently in her pocket.

"Evelyn Carter? This is Detective Morrison from the 12th precinct." The voice crackled through the receiver. "We need to discuss your involvement with Jonathan Reeves and Elite Studio. Come down to the station at your earliest convenience."

The call ended before she could respond. Evelyn's fingers trembled against her phone case. Why would the police want her? She'd only worked part-time at that damned studio - no benefits, no contracts, just minimum wage and empty promises.

Were Jonathan and his viper of a mother Judith setting her up?

The cab ride to the precinct passed in a blur of neon signs and honking cars. The interrogation room smelled of stale coffee and desperation.

"State your relationship to Jonathan Reeves." The detective's pen hovered over a notepad.

"We attended the same university. Later, I did part-time administrative work at his studio." Evelyn kept her voice steady despite the ice forming in her veins.

"Part-time?" The detective smirked. "Multiple witnesses claim you were romantically involved. Bank records show the studio used your identity for several loans. Care to explain?"

Evelyn's nails bit into her palms. "I never authorized any of that."

"Miss Carter," the detective leaned forward, "we don't bring people in without evidence. Lying will only make this worse."

"Everything Jonathan did was without my knowledge or consent." Evelyn met his gaze squarely. "Check my employment records - no bonuses, no stock options. Just hourly wages."

The detective flipped a page. "Then how do you explain paying off a $2.3 million mortgage last month? Jonathan claims he gave you that money under the table."

A cold realization slithered down Evelyn's spine. That bank encounter. Jonathan's sudden interest in her after years of indifference. Not attraction - reconnaissance. Nathaniel had been right all along.

"That money came from my cousin," Evelyn said.

"You're listed as having no living relatives." The detective's eyebrow arched.

A familiar baritone voice cut through the tension. "She forgot to mention me."

Evelyn whirled to see Nathaniel Whitmore silhouetted in the doorway, his tailored suit looking more like armor than business attire. Behind him, two attorneys materialized with briefcases full of legal artillery.

"What are you doing here?" Evelyn hissed as Nathaniel steered her into the hallway.

"Jonathan told the police I assaulted him during that kidnapping farce." Nathaniel's jaw tightened. "His lawyer suggested dropping charges... if I help bury his financial crimes."

Evelyn's stomach churned. "That spineless—"

"Now you understand why I warned you about wolves in sheep's clothing?" Nathaniel's gaze burned into hers.

"You said there was no evidence!"

"Because there wasn't." Nathaniel adjusted his cufflinks with sharp precision. "Until your statement connected us. Now they're building a conspiracy case."

Evelyn's breath hitched. "I'll tell them I lied—"

"Don't." Nathaniel's hand closed around her wrist. "Your 'help' nearly got me arrested yesterday. From now on, my legal team handles everything. Stay silent."

Before Evelyn could protest, another voice sliced through the tension. "Actually, Miss Carter has her own representation."

A silver-haired attorney stepped forward, business card extended. The game had just gotten more complicated.
###Chapter 399

Evelyn froze at the familiar voice. She turned slowly to see Andrew standing there.

Her heart leaped with unexpected joy as she rushed toward him. "I thought you'd gone back to Nord City."

Just last week, Andrew had come all the way to North City to defend her honor against Jonathan's schemes.

Though she'd struck a deal with Jonathan to drop the matter, she assumed Andrew had returned to his busy practice.

Andrew reached out, ruffling her hair affectionately. "I had a case here. What perfect timing. Since Jonathan insists on being difficult, you shouldn't hold back anymore."

Memories of Nathaniel's revelations about Jonathan's manipulation and threats flashed through Evelyn's mind. Enough was enough.

She nodded decisively. "You're right. The hospital security footage and my medical records are still available. Filing charges should be straightforward."

Suddenly, she felt an intense gaze burning into her back.

Evelyn turned to meet Nathaniel's piercing stare. Lowering her eyes, she followed Andrew to file the official report.

From across the room, Nathaniel's attention fixed on the well-dressed man beside Evelyn. A lawyer?

His jaw tightened as he approached Robert. "Find out everything about that man."

Robert studied the stranger briefly before responding, "That appears to be Andrew Montgomery, Nord City's top litigator."

"The Montgomery family?" Nathaniel's brow furrowed at the mention of the powerful clan. Another Montgomery connection.

Of course.

Given Evelyn's relationship with Julian, it made sense the Montgomerys would get involved. Yet something felt... off.

Evelyn seemed unusually comfortable with the Montgomerys.

After completing her statement, Evelyn prepared to leave with Andrew, deliberately avoiding Nathaniel's gaze as they passed each other in the hallway.

Outside the police station, Evelyn exhaled deeply. Andrew hesitated before asking, "Evelyn, are you still... involved with Nathaniel?"

"No, it was just coincidence. You know I'm close to his grandmother. That's why he wanted to help."

"Is that really all there is?" Andrew pressed.

Evelyn's pulse quickened. "Why the sudden interest, Andrew?"

"According to my sources, you originally came here with Jonathan to accuse Nathaniel of assault. Yet today you recanted. Evelyn, what's really between you two?"

Evelyn's breath caught. She hadn't realized Andrew knew so much. There was no point denying it now.

She bit her lip. "I thought Jonathan was the victim, but I learned the truth. He deserved what happened, so I changed my testimony."

Andrew recognized her evasion but didn't push further. Still, he couldn't shake the sense of deeper history between Evelyn and Nathaniel.

As they returned to campus for her afternoon classes, an uneasy premonition settled over Evelyn. Something was coming. Something bad.
###Chapter 400

The school counselor approached Evelyn after her classes. "Evelyn, we're hosting a music festival next week and the administration wants to use your award-winning design concept. What do you think?"

"I'd be honored," Evelyn replied with quiet confidence.

This was perfect. As the lead designer, she'd have front-row access to all the performances. The thought sent a thrill through her.

"Here's the auditorium key." The counselor handed her a brass key. "Feel free to make any necessary modifications. The school wants to impress our special guests - the visiting musicians could help our seniors get recruited."

Evelyn nodded firmly. "I won't let the school down."

She clutched the key tightly. This was her chance to prove herself again.

"Just a warning," the counselor added. "The lead musician has a reputation for being... difficult. Try not to take it personally."

"Understood." Evelyn smiled politely.

Keys jingling, she headed straight to inspect the auditorium.

She'd barely begun her assessment when unfamiliar voices echoed through the empty space. The group's designer outfits marked them as outsiders.

"Ugh, this place is huge but so outdated," a female voice complained.

"I still don't get why we're performing at some no-name school," a man grumbled.

Evelyn froze. These must be the visiting musicians - and they sounded unpleasant.

She considered slipping out the side exit, but her foot caught a trash can, sending it clattering across the floor.

"Who's there?" a sharp voice demanded.

Evelyn took a steadying breath and stepped into view.

Her breath caught. Among the group stood Victoria Sinclair - her rival from the design competition.

Victoria's presence here made no sense. She'd disappeared after the competition's first round, rumored to have returned to Nord City.

A man in a floral shirt glared. "Are you some stalker trying to sneak photos?"

Evelyn straightened her shoulders. "I'm the student designer for the festival. I was assessing the space."

Victoria's lips curled. "Relax, Anthony. This is Evelyn Carter - first prize winner at the Fleur International. She's practically a celebrity."

Anthony scoffed. "Some country girl winning an art contest? Our orchestra performs at Carnegie Hall. This dump will ruin our reputation."

Evelyn noted their arrogance but couldn't deny their credentials. These were world-class musicians.

"Mr. Kensington," she said evenly, "do you have any specific requirements for the setup?"

"Can you even play piano?" he challenged.

Victoria laughed cruelly. "Don't be ridiculous. An orphan from the sticks? She's probably never seen a real piano before."
###Chapter 401

Evelyn heard Victoria’s taunts but chose to remain silent. Instead, she admitted, "You’re right. I don’t actually know how to play the piano."

"Why sugarcoat it? If you lack the skill, just admit it. Evelyn, is your pride that fragile? Why not confess that you can’t play?" Victoria sneered.

Before Evelyn could respond, Anthony, standing nearby, cut in. "It’s ridiculous to entrust the venue design to someone with no musical knowledge or piano skills."

"I’ll be discussing this with the college to find a more suitable replacement."

Evelyn stayed quiet, unable to ignore the smug gleam in Victoria’s eyes.

Victoria was trouble, always appearing wherever Evelyn went.

Anthony and his group walked away, their expressions dripping with contempt.

Victoria lingered, casting a triumphant look at Evelyn before remarking, "You’ve been on a lucky streak lately, Evelyn. But sorry to disappoint—I’m back now. Your fun is over."

She thought about how she’d had to rush to Nord City to tend to Eleanor, just to secure her position as the Montgomery family’s young lady.

Only by doing so had she managed to keep her status. Alexander no longer pressured her to sign the adoption termination agreement.

Now, Victoria was determined to eliminate Evelyn—that nobody—so she could marry Nathaniel without any obstacles.

With Nathaniel as her future husband, she’d soon forget about being the Montgomery heiress.

Evelyn smirked. "We’ll see about that."

After all, she had nothing to lose. She’d be leaving this place soon anyway.

With that, Evelyn walked past Victoria without so much as a glance.

Victoria stomped her foot in frustration before storming out of the hall.

Approaching Anthony, she said, "I recall there’s a special segment planned for this event—a student performance at the end, right?"

Anthony nodded. "Yes, the college recommended two candidates. We’ll select one to perform."

"But where’s the fun in that if it’s already decided? Given this college’s standards, we might as well draw lots."

"Any embarrassment would only reflect poorly on the institution."

Victoria had already devised a plan. She’d make sure Evelyn was chosen to perform.

Watching Evelyn flounder under the spotlight would be entertaining.

Then, Victoria could swoop in and save the situation.

It would be the perfect chance for Nathaniel to see how ordinary Evelyn was compared to her.

Back at home, Margaret had prepared a feast for Evelyn. "You must have been busy with schoolwork. Eat up," she urged.

After dinner, Evelyn turned to Christopher. "I want to learn a piano piece. Can you teach me?"

She felt an inexplicable urge to prove herself.

Christopher agreed, noticing her determination. "What’s sparked this sudden motivation?"

"Anthony, the head of the music team, doubts my piano skills and musical understanding. He thinks I’m unqualified for the project. That’s why I want to work harder."

She needed the credits for graduation.

Christopher frowned. "Anthony said that about you?"

He cursed Anthony inwardly. What was his problem?

He’d organized this event for Evelyn. How dare Anthony question her musical ability?

With her talent, how could she not understand music?

Evelyn nodded. "I want to lead this project. It offers a lot of credits, and I’m eager to try."

"Alright, Evelyn. I know you’ll succeed. Let’s rehearse the piece I taught you earlier," Christopher said with a smile, though his eyes darkened.

He’d confront Anthony later. What was his issue, anyway?
###Chapter 402

Evelyn couldn't believe Anthony Kensington had the nerve to suggest replacing her.

The audacity!

This music show was meant to be Christopher Montgomery's apology gift for her.

And now Anthony wanted to cut her out?

The next morning at university, Evelyn received a call from Adrian Blackwell, Jonathan Reeves' defense attorney.

"Mr. Reeves and Mrs. Dawson are proposing a settlement. What are your thoughts?"

"A settlement?" Evelyn scoffed. "Jonathan has the gall to ask for that? Where's his dignity? Even if I don't press charges, he's still going to jail for financial fraud."

Adrian cleared his throat. "My client hopes for your forgiveness, given your past relationship. If you could lend him the funds to cover his debts, he could avoid prison. He promises repayment upon release."

Evelyn laughed coldly. "Not interested. Any further discussions can go through my lawyer."

She hung up.

Jonathan wasn't worth another second of her time.

Later, Evelyn was summoned to Elizabeth Hartwell's office.

"Evelyn, the university wants to discuss the venue setup—"

"Professor Hartwell," Evelyn interrupted, "I still want to perform. I may not have formal training, but I love music. I understand the piano."

Elizabeth paused, then smiled.

"You're misunderstanding. The university isn't replacing you. However, due to Mr. Kensington's concerns, you'll receive private lessons at the Music School. A dedicated instructor will train you. Are you willing?"

"Absolutely," Evelyn answered without hesitation.

This was an opportunity she wouldn't refuse.

After her lectures, Evelyn headed to the Music School.

It was her first time in a class there. Her peers all carried an air of sophistication.

After the session, her piano instructor, Donovan Prescott, approached.

"You must be Evelyn. Come with me."

He led her to a private room.

"Do you have any experience with the piano?"

"A little," she admitted.

"Then play your favorite piece for me."

Evelyn sat at the grand piano, memories flooding back.

The song she had learned as a child at the orphanage, taught by the director, Walter Simmons.

He had always praised her talent, but there had been sadness in his voice.

She understood why now—she'd never had the chance to pursue it properly.

But things were different now.

Taking a deep breath, Evelyn let her fingers glide across the keys, playing the melody from memory.

The music filled the building, rich and haunting.

Outside, Victoria Sinclair froze mid-step, Anthony Kensington beside her.

They had come to cause trouble, but the university clearly valued Evelyn.

Anthony had no choice but to let her stay—for now.

Victoria frowned. "Could we change the venue? Or postpone?"

That might be their only leverage.

Anthony shook his head. "No. Christopher called last night. He insisted the show happens here."

Victoria clenched her fists.

Christopher Montgomery never backed down.

Fine. Let Evelyn stay.

She'd humiliate herself at the show anyway.

Then—

Victoria's breath caught.

That melody.

Who was playing that piece here?

Could it be... her?
###Chapter 403

Victoria couldn’t suppress the rising tide of dread. Was it really her coming back?

But that couldn’t be.

She remembered clearly—she had made sure she would never return.

Yet, the haunting melody drifting through the halls sent chills down Victoria’s spine.

It hadn’t been Victoria whom the Montgomery family had originally sought. It had been Cassandra.

Blinded by envy, Victoria had orchestrated the perfect deception, stealing Cassandra’s identity and ensuring she would never learn the truth.

But Alexander had eventually uncovered the switch. Victoria had feigned ignorance, claiming she’d only met a girl like Cassandra at an orphanage years ago, unable to recall what had become of her.

In truth, that girl had been in the same orphanage as Victoria.

Her scheming had driven Cassandra away, adopted by another family before Alexander could ever find his real sister.

Alexander had brought Victoria into the Montgomery family, where she played the part of the amnesiac heiress flawlessly.

Over time, Victoria had almost convinced herself she was the true Montgomery heir.

Now, hearing that melody again, her blood ran cold.

The piece had been composed by Harrison to comfort the orphanage children—a secret only they knew.

Back then, none of the other children could play the piano except Cassandra, the real Montgomery heiress.

Harrison had adored her, praising her talent endlessly, always wishing for her to find a wealthy family.

Victoria had seethed with jealousy.

She, too, had dreamed of being adopted into luxury. But every time an opportunity arose, Harrison would only recommend Cassandra, leaving Victoria forgotten.

That bitterness had festered until she stole Cassandra’s life.

Later, she learned Cassandra’s adoptive family wasn’t rich—they had taken her in only because they couldn’t have children of their own.

For years, Victoria had reveled in her stolen wealth.

At first, she had lived in constant fear, terrified the Montgomerys would discover the truth and cast her out.

But as time passed, her worries faded. She began to believe she’d gotten away with it.

Now, hearing that melody—every note, every pause, exactly as she remembered—her breath caught.

It was her. Cassandra had returned.

Panicked, Victoria bolted through the halls, her hands trembling as she flung open doors, searching desperately.

The thought of the real heiress being found filled her with terror. It would ruin everything.

She had to protect her place in the Montgomery family. No matter what.

Upstairs, in a quiet classroom, Evelyn stopped playing and sighed. “I can’t remember much… just these few notes.”

When she was adopted as a child, she had fallen gravely ill, and most of her memories of the orphanage had faded.

But this melody—this one piece—remained sharp in her mind.

“It sounds like a lullaby. You played it beautifully. That’s a strong foundation,” Donovan said.

“What you need now is practice. Pick one piece to master. If Anthony tries to cause trouble, you’ll be ready.”

Evelyn nodded gratefully. “Thank you, Mr. Prescott.”

After a few more instructions, Donovan left her to practice alone.

Apart from this lullaby, Evelyn only knew the pieces Christopher had taught her.

Donovan had given her a few more to work on. But for now, this was all she had.
###Chapter 404

Evelyn decided to practice a new composition. Unfamiliar with the piece, she played at a slow tempo, her fingers stumbling over the keys.

Outside, Victoria scoured the building with growing desperation, checking every floor in a frantic search for the pianist whose music she had heard moments earlier.

But it was the end of classes, and the halls were filled with students practicing, making it nearly impossible for Victoria to identify the one she sought.

After an exhaustive search, Victoria resorted to adding senior students on WhatsApp, planning to investigate their backgrounds later.

Determining if any of them were orphans would be simple enough.

Breathless and exhausted, Victoria paused when an unfamiliar melody drifted from a nearby classroom. Pushing the door open, she found Evelyn seated at the piano.

Victoria froze.

At the sound of the door, Evelyn turned and saw Victoria standing there, disheveled and drenched in sweat, strands of hair clinging to her forehead.

Leaning against the doorframe, Victoria caught her breath, a cold smirk curling her lips.

"Trying to sneak in some practice, are you?" she taunted. "With your current skill, even a year wouldn’t be enough. You might as well quit now."

Recognizing Evelyn, Victoria assumed she had been motivated by Anthony’s praise the day before.

But having just heard Evelyn’s clumsy performance, Victoria was certain she posed no threat.

She was confident Evelyn would humiliate herself during the recital, making it effortless for Victoria to outshine her.

Without another word, Victoria turned and strode toward another classroom, determined to find the pianist she had heard earlier.

Evelyn ignored the jab, refocusing on her practice. She knew she still had time to improve.

After searching the entire building, Victoria had collected the contact information of over a hundred students.

Sitting on the stairs to catch her breath, she quickly dialed Gregory. "Can you run background checks on these people for me?"

If Victoria was going to locate the true heiress of the Montgomery family, she needed a plan to ensure they never crossed paths.

She couldn’t risk them recognizing her.

Her jaw clenched in determination. She had worked too hard to lose everything now.

Why should some be born into privilege while she had to claw her way up?

If fate had brought the real Montgomery heiress into her path, then fate would have to be dealt with.

If the girl was smart, Victoria might offer compensation—but she would never let her reclaim her place in the family.

After hours of practice, Evelyn returned home feeling defeated. Despite her efforts, she hadn’t improved as much as she’d hoped.

Frustrated, she couldn’t understand why she was struggling so much.

Christopher noticed her downcast expression. "What’s wrong? Did something happen at school?"

Had Anthony said something to upset her?

"I practiced some new pieces today," Evelyn admitted. "But I just couldn’t get them right."

"What did you play?" Christopher asked.

When Evelyn explained, he sighed. "Those pieces aren’t suited for you. It’s not your fault—everyone has their own style. Stick to what you know."

"Then what should I focus on?"

"The songs I’ve been teaching you. Master those first."

Evelyn nodded. The pieces she knew best were the childhood melodies and the ones Christopher had recently taught her.

She had intended to practice the sheet Donovan had given her, but it seemed beyond her current ability.

Then Christopher asked quietly, "Evelyn… do you still remember the orphanage?"
###Chapter 405

Evelyn hadn't anticipated Christopher bringing up her past. She shook her head slowly. "My memories are fragmented at best."

"Nothing concrete? Yet you remember that childhood piano piece perfectly," Christopher noted with narrowed eyes.

"I had a severe illness as a child." Evelyn's fingers absently traced the piano keys. "After the fever broke, my orphanage memories became... scattered."

She couldn't even picture Nathaniel's face clearly anymore - just fleeting impressions of piano duets and those elegant hands guiding hers.

Christopher knew the story well. When the Montgomery brothers first found Evelyn, their investigation had uncovered the truth. Margaret Dawson had confirmed it herself.

After being adopted by the Simmons family, Evelyn had nearly died from neglect-induced fever. Her miraculous recovery came with complete amnesia about the orphanage years.

"Evelyn," Christopher leaned against the grand piano, "do you recall having any close friends at the orphanage?"

Another head shake. "Why do you ask?" Evelyn's brow furrowed. "Are you suggesting I did?"

"Just curious." Christopher straightened abruptly. "You look exhausted. Rest now - we'll continue tomorrow."

He wasn't being entirely truthful. Since discovering Evelyn had been found in a different orphanage than Victoria claimed, doubts had festered.

Victoria's initial vague clues about Evelyn's whereabouts had sent Alexander Montgomery searching in wrong directions for years. The timing felt too convenient.

But with Evelyn's memories gone and Alexander finally cutting ties with Victoria, Christopher saw no reason to stir the past... unless Evelyn remembered on her own. Then Victoria would answer for everything.

In the following days, Evelyn divided her time between piano rehearsals and designing the concert hall decor.

Despite her packed schedule, she stole lunch hours to visit Eleanor Whitmore at the hospital. She'd promised frequent visits - breaking that promise might raise suspicions.

"Grandmother, you're looking stronger today," Evelyn greeted, setting down a fruit basket.

Eleanor, no longer ventilator-dependent, smiled weakly. "You're the one who looks worn thin, dear."

"Just end-of-term projects." Evelyn squeezed Eleanor's hand. "Nothing I can't handle."

"Remember you're caring for two now," Eleanor chided gently. "Don't neglect yourself."

After sharing lunch and light conversation, Evelyn departed. As she approached the elevators, a figure emerged from the emergency stairwell - Victoria Sinclair.

"Well if it isn't the Barrett family's little fraud," Victoria sneered. "Still sweet-talking your way into that old woman's will?"

Evelyn didn't flinch. "Bitterness ages you prematurely. Not a good strategy if you're still hoping to catch Nathaniel's eye."

Victoria's lips curled. "Enjoy your borrowed time. That hag won't live forever. Then we'll see who really belongs in the Whitmore family."

One elegant eyebrow arched. "Even if you paraded naked through Nathaniel's office, he'd still have security remove you. The canceled engagement should've been clue enough."
###Chapter 406

Victoria Sinclair's face twisted in displeasure. "Evelyn, I'm a wealthy heiress. You could never compare to someone like me."

Evelyn Carter arched a brow, her tone dripping with indifference. "You're right. I could never match your level of shamelessness."

With that, she stepped into the elevator, leaving Victoria fuming in the lobby.

Frustration bubbled inside Victoria as she stomped her foot. She had come to visit Eleanor Whitmore at the hospital, only to be blocked by security.

Yet Evelyn had strolled right past them without so much as a second glance.

The injustice of it made Victoria's blood boil.

Still, she consoled herself with the thought of Evelyn's impending humiliation at the college's music showcase.

She could already picture it—Evelyn fumbling over the piano keys, the audience whispering in pity.

The anticipation alone was delicious.

Meanwhile, Evelyn hailed a cab and headed back to campus.

Her phone buzzed mid-ride. Andrew Montgomery's name flashed on the screen.

"Evelyn, there's been a major update in Jonathan Reeves' case. The fraud charges against him have been confirmed."

His voice was steady. "He's looking at several years in prison. As for Judith Reeves, she's been sentenced to a year for assault."

Evelyn's lips pressed into a thin line. "I see. And what about the incident where Jonathan's leg was broken?"

She couldn't help but wonder how Nathaniel Whitmore had maneuvered his way out of that one.

Andrew hesitated. "There wasn't enough evidence to pursue it. Nathaniel isn't implicated."

"Of course not," Evelyn murmured. She had expected nothing less.

"Andrew, thank you for your help. I owe you coffee later. But right now, I need to rest before my afternoon lectures." She stifled a yawn.

"Take care of yourself, Evelyn. Don't push too hard," he replied before hanging up.

Once the call ended, Andrew stared at the documents in front of him.

The headline glared back at him: "Evelyn Carter is married to Nathaniel Whitmore."

The revelation had left him reeling all morning.

Suddenly, so many things made sense—the odd tension between Evelyn and Nathaniel, the way Nathaniel had mobilized every resource when Evelyn was kidnapped by Walter and Beverly Simmons.

Even Evelyn's evasiveness outside the police station now had an explanation.

Andrew straightened his tie and dialed Julian Montgomery. "Got a minute? I need to ask you something."

"If it's not about Evelyn, can it wait until after work?" Julian replied distractedly.

"It is about Evelyn. What's her connection to Nathaniel?"

A beat of silence. Then Julian sighed. "You found out, huh?"

Of course he had. As a lawyer, Andrew was bound to uncover the truth eventually.

Andrew's frown deepened. "You knew. Why didn't you tell us?"

"I found out by accident, and Evelyn begged me to keep it quiet. What was I supposed to do?"

Andrew exhaled sharply. "She must have suffered something terrible in that family to want a divorce."

"You think I don't know that? Evelyn is stubborn—she has her own plans. We've only just started building a real bond with her as her brothers."

Julian's voice turned firm. "If we push too hard, she'll just pull away."

Andrew's jaw tightened. "What did she get in the divorce? Money? Stocks? Properties—what assets does she have?"

Julian hesitated. "I don't know for sure. But given Evelyn's financial independence and her pride, she probably didn't ask for much."

As a top-tier lawyer with an impeccable reputation, the thought of Evelyn walking away with nothing after a divorce was unacceptable.

Andrew clenched his fists.

Nathaniel Whitmore wasn't going to get away with this.
###Chapter 407

Julian Montgomery frowned at Andrew's words. "You should discuss this with Evelyn first before making any decisions. What if she doesn't agree with your plan?"

"I can handle this on my own. Evelyn doesn’t need to be involved."

Andrew’s voice was firm. "After everything she’s endured—being mistreated and abandoned by the Whitmore family—I won’t stand by and do nothing. I refuse to let her walk away with nothing."

If Evelyn left the marriage empty-handed, then what was the point of Andrew being here?

"What I mean is, our family is more than capable of supporting her financially. She’ll be returning to Nord City soon. There’s no need to complicate things."

Julian sighed. "Besides, Evelyn has made it clear she wants nothing more to do with the Whitmores."

"This isn’t about complicating things. It’s about ensuring she gets what she deserves."

Andrew’s tone sharpened. "Otherwise, Nathaniel will think he can treat her however he pleases. Let me handle this. I’ll talk to Evelyn myself."

As one of Nord City’s top lawyers, Andrew believed that if Evelyn divorced without securing what was rightfully hers, then his reputation meant nothing.

Before, she had no one to rely on. Now, she had family.

Why should she suffer in silence?

Meanwhile, Evelyn sat through her afternoon lectures, an uneasy feeling settling in her chest. She couldn’t pinpoint why.

Later, she emailed the finalized design drafts to the university officials.

Given Anthony Kensington’s perfectionist standards and Victoria Sinclair’s interference, the task had been far from simple.

Evelyn wasn’t confident her designs would be approved. She had a sinking feeling they’d be sent back for revisions.

When Anthony received the drafts, he immediately forwarded them to Christopher Montgomery with a message:

"Mr. Montgomery, what do you think of these designs?"

Christopher barely glanced at them before replying sharply, "Why are you showing me this? Are you out of your mind? Who designed these?"

Anthony hesitated. "Mr. Montgomery, didn’t you specifically request to review the university’s submissions?"

He added, "I agree with your initial reaction. The designs seem amateurish. They’ll only slow us down. That’s why I suggested replacing Evelyn in the first place."

Wait—

Christopher suddenly straightened, his fingers flying over his phone as he called Anthony. "Hold on. Are you saying these are from the university?"

"Yes, they’re from Evelyn Carter," Anthony confirmed.

Christopher’s breath hitched.

Evelyn had designed these?

He cleared his throat, backtracking instantly. "Actually, on second thought, I might have been too hasty. These designs are impressive—full of energy and raw talent!"

Anthony blinked, baffled by the sudden shift. "I… I thought they were underdeveloped?"

Hadn’t Christopher just criticized them? Why the change of heart?

"Underdeveloped? Hardly." Christopher scoffed. "If you can’t appreciate originality, maybe you should keep quiet. This has character!"

He continued, "Evelyn’s a student. Her style might be unconventional, but that doesn’t make it tasteless. It fits the university’s vibe perfectly. I say we proceed as-is."

Anthony hesitated. "So… no revisions?"

"None. It’s perfect."

Christopher wouldn’t risk exhausting Evelyn with endless edits.

She had already spent countless hours practicing piano and refining these drafts.

Besides, this music showcase was for her. Even if she’d scribbled the designs on a napkin, he’d have approved them.

Anthony had no choice but to comply, though suspicion gnawed at him.

Was Christopher… interested in Evelyn?

It was the only explanation.
###Chapter 408

Christopher Montgomery had always been known as somewhat of a playboy.

Now it all made sense—why he suddenly organized a music showcase at the university and even endorsed such a youthful design concept.

But Christopher had never gone to such lengths for a woman before. He had never used his professional projects to impress anyone. Yet, Evelyn Carter seemed to be the exception.

Anthony Kensington couldn't shake the feeling that he had been too harsh on Evelyn. What if she became Christopher’s wife one day?

Later that afternoon, Evelyn was stunned to find her design draft approved without a single revision.
