Disbelieving, she double-checked with Elizabeth Hartwell multiple times. Elizabeth’s response remained unchanged: "Evelyn, you should trust your talent."

"After all, you were the first-place winner in the Fleur International Design Competition. The university has high expectations for you."

"I understand. I’ll do my best," Evelyn replied, her cheeks warming at the praise.

When she arrived home in a daze, Christopher was already there, watching her with a tentative smile. "Evelyn, how did the review go? Approved?"

Still slightly dazed, Evelyn nodded eagerly. "First try, no revisions. I was prepared to make changes, so this was a surprise."

Christopher gently ruffled her hair, his smile widening. "Happy?"

"Of course! Now I can start decorating the hall right away. There’s still enough time."

After a quick dinner, Evelyn retreated to her room to finalize the hall’s decor.

She realized she’d have to work tirelessly tomorrow—otherwise, she’d fall behind schedule.

Watching her dedication, Christopher couldn’t help but smile. As long as she was happy, nothing else mattered.

The next morning, Evelyn arrived on campus early to begin decorating.

By noon, she was so absorbed in her work that dizziness hit her. Only when her stomach growled in protest did she finally pause to order food.

After eating, she felt slightly better.

"Tsk, tsk. This setup is underwhelming. How did Anthony even approve such a mediocre design?" Victoria Sinclair sneered.

Penelope Whitmore smirked. "Isn’t it obvious? Maybe Evelyn persuaded him in some special way."

Victoria’s grin widened. "Penelope, we shouldn’t make accusations without proof."

Penelope scoffed. "What more proof do we need? Everyone knows how Evelyn earned her place in the Whitmore family."

Evelyn set down her tools sharply.

"I was wondering what that awful smell was. Turns out, it’s just the two of you. I thought a sewer pipe had burst."

Penelope’s face twisted. "Who are you calling foul? Did we lie? You did use dirty tricks to get your design approved, didn’t you?"

Evelyn’s expression turned icy. "Spreading rumors has consequences, Penelope. Remember that."

"Please. Everyone already knows the truth. I’ll make sure the entire campus hears about your little hotel rendezvous with Anthony last night. My friend saw it firsthand—don’t even try denying it."

Evelyn nodded calmly and pulled out her phone, dialing the police.

"Hello? I’d like to report defamation. I’ve been falsely accused of misconduct, and I have two witnesses here who can attest to the slander."
###Chapter 409

Evelyn's fingers trembled slightly as she dialed the emergency number, her piercing gaze never leaving Victoria and Penelope.

Penelope's lips curled into a smug smirk. "Why bother calling the police? Do you really want the whole world to know about your little rendezvous with Mr. Kensington?"

Victoria's face paled. She hadn't anticipated Evelyn would actually involve the authorities!

A cold smile played on Evelyn's lips. "You both saw everything, didn't you? You'll need to give your statements to the police. How else are we going to track down Anthony?"

Victoria caught on quickly, her voice laced with irritation. "Must you drag the police into every petty dispute? When will this nonsense end?"

Evelyn's eyes flashed with defiance. "Why wouldn't I call them? Especially when I have no memory of the events you're accusing me of."

"If Penelope truly has a friend who claims to have seen me at that hotel, then it's obvious I was drugged and taken there against my will."

"Whoever is behind this will pay dearly."

Even Penelope, usually so dense, finally grasped the gravity of the situation.

Her claims about a witness spotting Evelyn with Anthony at the hotel were nothing but lies, fabricated to ruin Evelyn's reputation.

But now, with the police involved, the truth would inevitably come to light if an investigation was launched.

Evelyn's smirk turned icy. "Once Mr. Kensington arrives, we can settle this face-to-face."

Panic flickered in Penelope's eyes. What had she gotten herself into?

Victoria's frown deepened. This was spiraling out of control. How could Penelope be so foolish as to hand Evelyn such an advantage?

If this escalated, it could damage Victoria's standing with Anthony. And if that happened, how could she expect him to help her take Evelyn down?

Victoria shot Penelope a sharp look and hissed under her breath, "Penelope, you need to clarify things. Making baseless accusations won't help anyone."

Penelope hesitated. Her earlier words had only been meant to humiliate Evelyn.

Leaning closer, Victoria whispered urgently, "If Mr. Kensington finds out you lied, you can forget about meeting those famous pianists. It's better to end this now."

Penelope swallowed hard, then turned to Evelyn with reluctant resignation. "I—I just remembered, I only heard rumors. I didn’t actually see you with Mr. Kensington."

"Then you can explain that to the police," Evelyn replied coolly, already turning away to resume decorating the hall.

Victoria's voice stopped her. "Evelyn, Penelope was just joking earlier. There's no need to involve the police."

"If this gets out, the paparazzi will have a field day. It’ll tarnish both the university and the Music School’s reputation."

Though it pained her to back down, Victoria couldn’t risk the police digging deeper.

Evelyn arched a brow. "Oh? So it's just a joke when you're not the one being slandered. How convenient."

"What do you want?" Victoria ground out between clenched teeth.

Evelyn glanced pointedly at Penelope. "The one who spread the lies should apologize."

"I won’t!" Penelope snapped immediately. Apologize to Evelyn? Never.

Victoria exhaled sharply before pulling Penelope aside. "Penelope, remember—the Music School belongs to Christopher."

"If this escalates and my brothers find out, it won’t reflect well on you. How do you expect to marry into the Montgomery family then?"
###Chapter 410

Evelyn's words sent Penelope into a rage.

The thought of this upstart ruining her carefully laid plans to marry into the prestigious Whitmore family was unbearable.

Clenching her fists, Penelope forced herself to approach Evelyn. "I... apologize for my earlier remarks," she ground out between clenched teeth. "It was just foolish chatter. Pay it no mind."

Evelyn studied Penelope with cool detachment. "You know perfectly well these accusations are groundless, yet you spread them with such conviction. What kind of woman stoops to such malice?"

Penelope swallowed her fury, knowing she had to maintain composure. One wrong move now could destroy everything.

Victoria quickly intervened. "Evelyn, Penelope has apologized. Surely you can explain to the authorities that this was all a misunderstanding?"

Evelyn remained unmoved. "I'll speak with the police when they arrive. But first, Penelope, there's something you can do for me."

She gestured toward the tangled mass of decorative lights nearby. "Help me move these from the ground floor to the upper level. Consider it proof of your sincerity."

Penelope's control snapped. "How dare you order me about!"

Victoria grabbed her arm before she could say more.

Defeated, Penelope muttered, "What exactly do you need done?"

"It's simple," Evelyn replied, crossing her arms. "You and Victoria will carry all these lights upstairs without assistance. Do that, and I'll explain everything favorably to the authorities. Fair?"

Watching their casual dismissal of their vicious rumors, Evelyn wondered why they should escape consequences so easily.

Penelope, unaccustomed to physical labor, reluctantly lifted the heavy bundle of lights. Her designer heels clicked angrily against the stairs as she ascended. "These stairs are treacherous! And I'm ruining my new Louboutins!"

Victoria made no move to help. "No need to hurry, darling," she called sweetly.

Evelyn's expression hardened. "If those lights aren't moved before I return, I'll have quite the story for the police."

Panic flashed across Penelope's face. "But how am I supposed to—"

"That's your concern," Evelyn cut in, already walking away. "Fail to complete the task, and the consequences are yours to bear."

Penelope stamped her foot. "Victoria, you'll help me with this!"

Seeing no alternative, Victoria reluctantly removed her own expensive shoes. "This better be worth it," she muttered.

From a discreet corner, Evelyn watched the two socialites struggle with the lights, their perfect hair now disheveled, their designer clothes smudged with dust. She couldn't resist recording the priceless scene on her phone.

An hour later, Evelyn returned to find Victoria and Penelope collapsed in chairs, their makeup streaked with sweat.

Victoria gasped, "What did you tell the police? Why haven't they come?"

Evelyn blinked innocently. "Oh, I never actually called them."

Victoria's mouth fell open in outrage. She'd been played—again!
###Chapter 411

Evelyn couldn't help but notice the darkening expressions on Victoria and Penelope's faces after her revelation.

Penelope's voice trembled with barely contained fury. "You're telling me you never actually called the police?"

Evelyn shrugged nonchalantly. "That's right. It was just a little bluff to rattle you."

The words sent Penelope flying out of her chair, her face flushed with rage. "Evelyn Carter, I've had it with your games!"

Her manicured nails dug into the table. "Do you have any idea how exhausting it was hauling all those lights upstairs? And now you admit it was all for nothing?"

Evelyn took a graceful step back, her lips curving. "You should be thanking me. If I'd actually called them, you'd be explaining stolen property to officers right now."

She tilted her head. "Given how things turned out today, does it really matter?"

Penelope froze, realization dawning—she'd been played.

Victoria looked equally furious but too drained to continue. Clutching her designer heels, she stood with a wince. "Let's go. My spine feels like it's about to snap."

"Same. These blisters are killing me." Penelope sighed dramatically. "I need a spa day after this nightmare."

Victoria waved a dismissive hand. "Agreed. We're done here."

Before leaving, Penelope shot Evelyn a venomous glare. "This isn't over."

Evelyn's smile turned razor-sharp. "Do come back anytime."

She watched with amusement as the two women hobbled away, their earlier arrogance reduced to pained grimaces. The sight was deeply satisfying.

Would they dare cause more trouble? Evelyn doubted it. Between finalizing hall decorations and preparing for the show, she had zero patience for their antics.

Let them stay gone. But if they returned? She wouldn't hold back.

Later, while scrolling through the event's VIP list in the group chat, one name made her pause—Nathaniel Whitmore.

Her finger hovered over his name. Since when did a busy CEO attend college music shows?

Meanwhile, at Whitmore Enterprises...

Nathaniel strode from the conference room, issuing crisp orders to his team.

Back in his office, Robert approached with an envelope. "Sir, you've received an invitation to Halvard University's music showcase."

Nathaniel's gaze sharpened as he examined it. "This is Christopher Montgomery's department, correct?"

Robert cleared his throat. "Indeed."

Nathaniel studied the invitation. "What's Evelyn's role in this event?"

The memory of Evelyn leaving that hotel with Christopher still burned.

Robert hesitated. "From what I gathered, Ms. Carter is handling venue design this year. Her proposal was approved without revisions."

A muscle twitched in Nathaniel's jaw. He hadn't expected Christopher to be so... persuasive.

A knock interrupted them. A secretary entered. "Mr. Whitmore, a visitor—Andrew Montgomery. He's representing Ms. Carter as legal counsel."

The air turned glacial.

Nathaniel's voice dropped dangerously. "Send him in."

Robert suppressed a shiver. Why did everything escalate at once?

Minutes later, Andrew entered—impeccable in a tailored suit, briefcase in hand. Behind his gold-rimmed glasses, his calm gaze met Nathaniel's like a silent challenge.
###Chapter 412

Nathaniel leaned back in his leather chair, his piercing gaze fixed on Andrew standing across from him.

The silence stretched between them like a taut wire.

Andrew finally extended a crisp business card across the polished mahogany desk.

"I'm from Montgomery & Associates in Northridge. I'm representing Ms. Carter regarding your divorce proceedings."

Nathaniel barely glanced at the card before pushing it aside. "What exactly does Evelyn want now?"

Andrew smoothly produced a thick folder from his briefcase, spreading the documents across the desk.

"This outlines the proposed asset division. I suggest you review it carefully, Mr. Whitmore."

Nathaniel didn't even look at the papers. "She swore she wouldn't take a dime. What changed?"

Evelyn hadn't just changed her mind - she'd sent the Montgomery family's top attorney to negotiate!

The woman had certainly stepped up her game.

Andrew suppressed a smirk. Just as Julian predicted, Evelyn genuinely hadn't wanted anything.

But as a seasoned divorce attorney, Andrew knew money was the best leverage. He'd make Nathaniel pay dearly.

"The reasons don't matter," Andrew said smoothly. "For an amicable divorce, I recommend signing as is."

Nathaniel snatched the papers without reading, scrawling his signature violently across the last page before shoving them back.

"Tell Evelyn this is her last chance to change her mind," he growled. "I won't be so accommodating next time."

Andrew arched an eyebrow at the signature. "You're not even going to read it?"

"Nothing in there interests me," Nathaniel snapped.

Typical Nathaniel - always brutally direct.

Andrew nodded, leaving one copy on the desk. "Per the agreement, you'll need to begin transfers within 48 hours."

Nathaniel simply flicked the documents toward Robert. "Handle it."

As Andrew packed up, he shot Nathaniel a final look. "At least you're ending this marriage with some dignity."

Nathaniel's stony silence spoke volumes.

Once Andrew left, Robert scanned the agreement and went pale. "Sir... shouldn't you review this?"

Did Nathaniel realize he was signing away his entire fortune?

After her last lecture, Evelyn checked her watch and hurried toward campus gates.

Exhausted from back-to-back classes, she craved an early night.

At the entrance, she spotted Andrew leaning against a sleek black sedan.

"Evelyn!" he called.

She jogged over. "Andrew? What are you doing here?"

He handed her a takeout bag. "Thought you might be hungry. Traffic's terrible this time of day."

"Thanks," she smiled, sliding into the passenger seat.

Her fingers brushed against a leather briefcase. "Coming from work?"

"Just wrapped up a divorce case," Andrew said casually as he pulled into traffic. "Go ahead, take a look."

Evelyn froze, sudden dread coiling in her stomach.

She pulled out the documents, her breath catching at "Asset Division Agreement."

As her eyes flew down the staggering list of holdings being transferred to her name, all color drained from her face.
###Chapter 413

Evelyn hesitated for a moment before speaking. "Andrew, are you serious?"

"I don't joke about matters like this," Andrew replied firmly.

A knot of unease twisted in Evelyn's stomach. "Then... you must not have gone to see Nathaniel yet, have you?"

"I just did. I came straight here to pick you up afterward," Andrew answered.

Dread pooled in Evelyn's chest.

If only she had clarified everything with Andrew sooner, none of this would be happening.

She turned to him, frustration lacing her voice. "Andrew, why didn't you tell me about something this important?"

"Evelyn, this is my job. You shouldn’t have to worry about any of it."

"Walking away from a marriage with nothing is unacceptable. Demanding what you’re owed doesn’t make you greedy."

"Those are just toxic ideals men push on women to make them feel guilty for valuing financial security. In the end, it’s always the men who benefit," Andrew explained.

Evelyn exhaled sharply. "I know you’re trying to protect me, but my situation with Nathaniel is more complicated than most divorces."

"There’s no difference, Evelyn. Trust me," Andrew reassured her. "I’ll make sure you get everything you’re entitled to."

Exhaustion weighed on her as she murmured, "Andrew, these terms you’ve laid out—Nathaniel transferring all his shares to me, millions in cash, multiple properties, stakes in subsidiaries—how did you even uncover all this?"

Of course, Evelyn knew the Whitmore family’s wealth was staggering.

Nathaniel’s shares alone were worth a fortune.

How could she possibly demand control of the entire Whitmore Group?

Andrew smirked. "Have you forgotten what I do for a living?"

"Andrew, there’s no way the Whitmores would agree to this," Evelyn said skeptically.

Andrew shrugged. "Nathaniel already did."

What?

Evelyn froze. "Nathaniel agreed? That’s impossible!"

"He even signed it. See for yourself," Andrew insisted.

Evelyn flipped to the last page—and there it was. Nathaniel’s bold, unmistakable signature.

Now she was completely lost.

How could he have agreed?

Was he out of his mind?

Andrew glanced at the traffic light ahead. "For all his flaws, Nathaniel is surprisingly generous when it comes to your divorce."

"He signed without even reading the terms. Seems he trusts you a great deal."

Evelyn thought bitterly, Of course he didn’t read it. Just as I expected.

Given Nathaniel’s personality, it made no sense for him to agree to such extreme demands.

She struggled to find words. "How did the conversation go? Why would he sign without even looking?"

This wasn’t like Nathaniel at all.

Andrew arched a brow. "I drafted it this way as a negotiation tactic, never expecting him to agree. But he signed it blindly."

"He probably assumed it was the settlement you prepared. That’s why I said he must trust you."

Evelyn was stunned. Had she really underestimated Nathaniel’s trust in her?

As she stared at the signed agreement, emotions tangled inside her.

"Evelyn, you don’t need to deal with any of this. I’ll handle everything," Andrew assured her.

"Andrew, there’s something you don’t know. Before marrying Nathaniel, I signed a prenup. None of these assets are legally mine."

"What?"

Andrew jerked the car to the side of the road, his eyes wide with disbelief. "Evelyn, tell me you didn’t."

"I did," she admitted.

Andrew cursed under his breath. "No wonder Nathaniel signed so easily. He was expecting this all along, wasn’t he?"
###Chapter 414

It appeared Nathaniel had outmaneuvered Benjamin, the renowned attorney from Northridge.

Evelyn placed a comforting hand on Benjamin's arm. "Benjamin, this isn't your failure. I never expected anything from this arrangement anyway. Let's just leave it be."

Benjamin remained silent, the bitter taste of defeat heavy on his tongue.

"Promise me you won't confront Nathaniel about the settlement," Evelyn pleaded, her voice barely above a whisper. "All I want is to cut all ties with the Whitmore family."

Nothing else mattered now. Not when she carried her most precious treasures—the twins growing safely within her.

As Benjamin met Evelyn's pleading gaze, he exhaled sharply.

Suddenly, he understood Julian's warning about never being able to refuse Evelyn.

Now, he too found himself powerless against her requests.

Yet even as he agreed, a simmering sense of injustice burned in his chest.

After organizing the paperwork, Evelyn returned home, maintaining her carefully constructed facade of normalcy.

Only when night fell, after dinner and tucked safely in bed, did she finally examine the divorce settlement documents.

Steeling herself, she dialed Nathaniel's number. The line rang endlessly with no answer.

Unbeknownst to her, Nathaniel sat secluded in a VIP lounge of an upscale bar, surrounded by an alarming number of empty liquor bottles.

When Gregory arrived, the scene before him made his blood run cold.

"Nat," Gregory's voice held barely concealed alarm as he took in the wreckage of the room, "what the hell happened?"

It had been years since he'd seen Nathaniel consume alcohol like this.

Sinking onto the leather couch, Gregory quipped, "Did the apocalypse start and nobody told me?"

Nathaniel's tie hung loose around his neck, his dress shirt unbuttoned to reveal his collarbones. The usually impeccable businessman looked utterly disheveled.

Without a word, he drained another glass of burgundy liquid before muttering something unintelligible.

Alarmed, Gregory grabbed Robert by the arm. "Explain. Now."

"Mr. Whitmore is facing financial ruin," Robert confessed.

Gregory's eyebrows shot up. "That's impossible. The Whitmore empire doesn't just collapse. Why wasn't I informed?"

"The divorce settlement was finalized today."

"That shouldn't bankrupt him."

Robert hesitated. "He transferred all his shares to Ms. Carter."

Gregory's glass slipped from his fingers, shattering against the marble floor. "He did what? Has he lost his damn mind?"

As Robert recounted the events, even he seemed stunned by how things had unfolded.

Gregory turned to Nathaniel, his voice sharp. "There's still room to negotiate with legal counsel."

"Besides, Evelyn signed a prenup. She wasn't entitled to anything. Are you seriously just surrendering like this?"

This wasn't the ruthless Nathaniel Whitmore he knew!

Nathaniel set down his glass, the remaining wine staining his lips crimson. His eyes darkened as he rasped, "You don't understand."

"Damn right I don't! How could you sign without reviewing the terms?"

"You're the most meticulous bastard I know. This isn't like you."

Gregory was genuinely baffled.

Nathaniel slumped deeper into the couch cushions, his voice rough. "You think I have answers?"

"You signed the damn papers! What were you thinking?"

"I wasn't thinking at all."

Nathaniel's grip tightened around his glass, his knuckles turning white. Never in his life had a woman caused him to make such a catastrophic mistake.

The realization of Evelyn's power over him—that's what terrified him most.

Gregory studied his friend carefully before voicing the dangerous thought. "Nathaniel... are you in love with Evelyn?"
###Chapter 415

Nathaniel's dark eyes widened in shock as the words sank in.

His response came instantly, sharp and defensive. "Absolutely not!"

The mere suggestion that he might harbor feelings for Evelyn was absurd.

Gregory's voice turned stern. "If you truly don't care for Evelyn, why are you so vulnerable around her? Your subconscious trusts her more than you realize."

He leaned forward, pressing further. "And let's not forget—this divorce has dragged on for months. She's moved on with other men, yet you've tolerated it. Is that fair to you?"

Nathaniel's lips pressed into a thin line, his expression cooling. "I'm doing this for Grandmother Eleanor."

Gregory scoffed. "Before her surgery, everyone assumed Evelyn would use the situation to cling to you."

His tone sharpened. "But the surgery is over. Why hasn't the divorce been finalized?"

A pause. Then, pointedly: "And when Evelyn's lawyer presented the property settlement, you signed without even reviewing the terms."

His gaze bore into Nathaniel. "Tell me that wasn't spite."

Nathaniel frowned. "Spite?"

Gregory crossed his arms. "You signed because you were angry—angry that Evelyn initiated the divorce, angry she drafted the agreement without consulting you."

His voice dropped. "That sounds like unresolved feelings to me."

Nathaniel fell silent. Gregory's words struck a nerve. Ever since signing those papers, he'd noticed something unsettling—his attention kept drifting back to Evelyn.

But it made no sense.

"Nat, drowning yourself in alcohol won't solve anything," Gregory said firmly.

Nathaniel lifted his gaze. "You think I should find her?"

"Yes. Immediately."

Nathaniel's fingers tightened around the wine bottle, unease coiling in his chest. "I... need to sort out my feelings first."

Gregory blinked, taken aback.

He stared at Nathaniel in disbelief. "I suggested you see Evelyn to discuss the settlement—not your emotions. That's something I can't help you with."

Gregory couldn't fathom it. Nathaniel was on the brink of financial ruin, yet his mind was fixated on Evelyn.

Nathaniel looked away, his expression shifting uncomfortably. "This can wait."

"Wait?" Gregory's voice rose. "You're about to lose everything! If your ancestors knew you were handing over company shares in a divorce, they'd—"

Nathaniel swirled the wine calmly. "Evelyn isn't that kind of person. She wouldn't take what's mine."

Gregory's patience frayed. "Then why did her lawyer push for the settlement?"

Nathaniel's jaw clenched at the mention of the lawyer. "The terms were problematic. Evelyn likely didn't know."

If Evelyn had truly wanted his assets, she would have demanded them long ago.

Before this, Nathaniel had even prepared his own settlement—only for Evelyn to refuse everything and tear it up.

There was no way these unreasonable terms had come from her.

Gregory's lips twitched. "You trust her that much?"

"It's not just her. It's Grandmother Eleanor's judgment too," Nathaniel insisted.

Gregory nearly rolled his eyes. Using Eleanor as an excuse again?

Only a fool would believe that.

With a sigh, he asked the obvious. "Then who is this lawyer?"
###Chapter 416

"Andrew Montgomery." Nathaniel Whitmore said.

"Another Montgomery?" Gregory Thornton raised an eyebrow. "You mentioned Evelyn's closeness to Julian before. Could the Montgomerys have some hidden agenda against your family?"

Nathaniel swirled his wine glass before taking a sip. "Not against my family. Against Evelyn herself."

"Let me tell you something, Nate," Gregory leaned in, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. "If you've developed feelings for Evelyn—and considering you two haven't finalized the divorce yet—it wouldn't be hard to keep her by your side."

"After all, she used to worship the ground you walked on, playing the perfect devoted wife. If you just show her a little attention, won’t she come running back?"

Nathaniel’s mind flashed to Evelyn’s recent words: "If you replace your boyfriend fast enough, you won’t have time to be sad."

"As long as your new man measures up, you’ll forget your ex in no time."

His jaw tightened. "She’s not that easily swayed anymore."

Ever since Nathaniel had brought up divorce, Evelyn had transformed into someone unrecognizable—distant, untouchable.

Gregory clicked his tongue. "Are you seriously considering coaxing her back? Just admit it—you’ve fallen for her."

The truth was painfully obvious.

Nathaniel cleared his throat. "I just think whether we divorce or not doesn’t matter much."

"Grandmother Eleanor adores her, and I don’t have strong feelings about marriage either way. It’s not a big deal."

Gregory scoffed. "You’re lying to yourself. If you truly felt that way, why file for divorce in the first place?"

Nathaniel hesitated. "At the time, I thought keeping Evelyn tied to the Whitmore name for three years was unfair."

"A woman like her shouldn’t waste her life in a loveless marriage. She deserved a fresh start."

Gregory countered immediately, "Then why are you stopping her from leaving now?"

He couldn’t understand Nathaniel’s stubborn denial.

Setting his wine glass down, Nathaniel finally admitted, "Because Evelyn is pregnant."

Gregory choked on his drink, coughing violently as he gaped at Nathaniel. "Yours?"

Nathaniel’s expression darkened. "Probably not."

"What do you mean, probably not? Wait—are you saying the baby is Julian’s?" Gregory’s voice rose in disbelief. "With all this, shouldn’t you be speeding up the divorce? Why would you want to deal with this mess?"

Nathaniel shrugged, feigning indifference. "I don’t care about the child."

"Before, I lied about Evelyn being pregnant to convince Grandmother Eleanor to undergo surgery."

"Now that she’s recovering, the truth about the fake pregnancy would’ve come out eventually. But now, Evelyn is actually pregnant."

"Even if the child isn’t mine, I can overlook it—for Grandmother’s sake."

Gregory stared at him like he’d lost his mind. "Nathaniel, are you serious?"

Signing divorce papers was one thing. But willingly raising another man’s child? That was something else entirely.

It was clear—Nathaniel still loved Evelyn.

No man would endure this if he didn’t.

Ignoring Gregory’s shock, Nathaniel checked his phone and saw a missed call from Evelyn. He didn’t return it.

His lips thinned. She was probably calling about the divorce agreement they’d discussed earlier.

Gregory leaned closer. "Who called? Evelyn?"

"Yeah. I didn’t answer."

Nathaniel stared at his screen, his voice low and hesitant. "…Should I call her back?"
###Chapter 417

Nathaniel stared at the missed call notification, his fingers hovering over the screen. He could already imagine why Evelyn was trying to reach him.

Gregory hesitated before responding, "It's your call."

Nathaniel frowned, his expression conflicted. "What if she asks about the divorce settlement? What do I say?"

Gregory sighed, rubbing his temples. "Just answer honestly. Or don’t. Either way, you’re digging your own grave here."

The situation was undeniably tense.

After a long pause, Nathaniel set his phone down without returning the call.

Gregory raised an eyebrow. "You’re not going to call her back?"

Nathaniel smirked, though there was a flicker of uncertainty in his eyes. "Let her come to me first."

"You really think that’s a good idea?"

"With the amount of money she just inherited, she won’t be able to sleep tonight. She’ll reach out," Nathaniel said, though he knew Evelyn wasn’t the type to be swayed by wealth.

Gregory exhaled sharply, shaking his head.

At first, he had assumed Nathaniel’s feelings for Evelyn were fleeting—just another passing infatuation.

But now, watching Nathaniel’s stubbornness, it was clear his emotions ran much deeper than Gregory had realized.

The next morning, Evelyn woke up and immediately checked her phone.

Still no response from Nathaniel.

She had tried calling him last night, but when he didn’t answer, she assumed he was in a meeting. She had waited, expecting him to call back, but eventually, exhaustion overtook her.

Now, with the morning light streaming through her window, she was met with the same silence.

What was Nathaniel thinking?

He had to know the divorce agreement had granted her full control of Whitmore Enterprises, stripping him of his power.

Yet, he didn’t seem the least bit concerned.

Meanwhile, Evelyn couldn’t shake her unease. These weren’t assets she had any right to claim.

Worse, if word got out about the sudden shift in shares, it could destabilize the company’s stock.

And if Eleanor found out? The truth about their divorce would be exposed.

No—she had to handle this carefully.

Evelyn headed straight to campus that morning.

With the music showcase approaching, she needed to oversee the final preparations herself.

She couldn’t afford any last-minute sabotage, especially not from Victoria Sinclair.

The university had spared no expense for the event, and the setup was nearly complete.

Evelyn surveyed the hall, satisfied with the progress. Most of the decorations were in place, leaving just minor details to finalize.

At noon, she made her way to the music building to practice.

And of course, she ran straight into Victoria.

Evelyn suppressed a groan. Why did it feel like Victoria was always lurking wherever she went?

Victoria smirked. "Here to practice in secret again, Evelyn? You should really give up."

Charlotte Ellington, standing beside her, added with a sneer, "Why embarrass yourself? You’ll never compare to the real musicians here."

Evelyn arched a brow. "Do you know why Edwin Girod’s grandfather lived so long?"

Victoria blinked. "What does that have to do with anything?"

Charlotte scoffed. "Yeah, what’s your point?"

Evelyn smiled sweetly. "Because he minded his own business."

Then she walked past them without another word.
###Chapter 418

"Honestly, it's none of your concern, and you have no right to interfere!" Evelyn snapped before striding purposefully toward the academic building.

Victoria clenched her fists, watching Evelyn's retreating figure with barely concealed frustration. "Evelyn Carter, you better stop right there and explain yourself!"

Evelyn glanced over her shoulder, her tone dripping with sarcasm. "Nathaniel's grandfather lived a long life because he knew when to stay out of other people's business. Whether I learn or not is my choice—not yours."

With that, she continued walking, a faint smirk playing on her lips as she dismissed Victoria's earlier insults.

Playing the piano had always been nothing more than a personal indulgence for Evelyn.

She had no interest in competitions or performing in the upcoming showcase. Her only goal was to reclaim the childhood joy that had been stolen from her.

Though her early memories had faded with time, the familiar notes of the piano stirred fragments of the past she thought she'd lost.

Evelyn headed straight to an empty classroom on the fourth floor. Taking a deep breath, she let her fingers dance across the keys, playing the melody from memory.

This lullaby always brought her an inexplicable sense of peace.

The room filled with the soft, melancholic notes of the piano, blending seamlessly with the distant harmonies of other instruments echoing through the halls.

Victoria froze mid-step, her expression twisting as she recognized the hauntingly familiar tune.

Her voice came out strained. "Did you hear that?"

Charlotte frowned, confused. "Hear what, Ms. Sinclair? There are multiple instruments playing—classes are still in session—"

"No, the piano. That lullaby. Who usually plays it?"

Victoria had previously tasked Gregory with investigating everyone she'd added on social media.

Yet none of them matched the person she was searching for, and all claimed ignorance about the lullaby's existence.

Still, there was no mistaking it—the melody was unmistakable.

Despite her frequent visits to this part of campus, she hadn’t heard the tune again—until now.

For a moment, doubt crept in. Had she imagined it? Was her mind playing tricks on her?

But this time, the music was real.

Victoria quickly pulled out her phone and recorded the faint strains of the piano, barely audible beneath the other instruments.

Yet to her, it stood out like a beacon.

That melody—she would recognize it anywhere.

Charlotte hesitated before speaking. "If you're looking for the person who plays that piece, maybe I can help? I've been around this university for years. I might know who it is."

Victoria forced a smile. "Yes, I'm searching for a childhood friend. We were inseparable, but life tore us apart."

Her voice softened with fabricated nostalgia. "This lullaby... it was something only the two of us knew. A secret between us."

"What's your friend's name, Ms. Sinclair?"

"She was a girl I met while volunteering at an orphanage."

Victoria carefully omitted the truth—that she, too, had grown up in that orphanage.

As her gaze fixed on the building ahead, a shadow flickered in her eyes.

Now, she was certain.

The true heiress of the Sinclair family was inside.
###Chapter 419

Evelyn Carter stood frozen before the grand building, the haunting melody of the piano intertwining with other instruments, sending chills down her spine.

It awakened a primal fear she had buried deep within.

Ever since she had deceived her way into the Montgomery family, nightmares plagued her—visions of the true heiress being discovered, while she was stripped of everything and thrown back into the gutters of poverty.

A dark shadow flickered in Evelyn’s eyes. She would never return to that life. Never.

She had to find the real heiress before the Montgomerys did. No matter the cost.

This was the only way to secure her place—to ensure the rightful heir never had the chance to reclaim what was hers.

The music stopped abruptly.

Evelyn exhaled sharply, her back damp with cold sweat. Sleep had been elusive lately.

If the Montgomerys uncovered the truth before she did, it would be the end of her.

Meanwhile, in the practice room, Mia finished her piano session and made her way to the hall to oversee the final preparations.

Today was crucial—the last adjustments before the event. She needed everything to be flawless.

As she entered, she spotted a small crowd gathered, including Elizabeth Hartwell.

Elizabeth smiled warmly when she saw her. "I was just about to call you, but Mr. Winslow mentioned you were in the study hall. Didn’t want to disturb you."

Evelyn blinked in surprise. "Oh, you could’ve called anytime. It’s no trouble."

"Well, we have some VIP guests arriving soon, and we need someone to host them."

"Since you’re handling the hall design, your presence would be ideal. You’d know all the details if they have questions."

"Of course. No problem at all."

As she followed Elizabeth inside, she nearly collided with Theodore Winslow, who had just arrived.

"Evelyn, have you finished your tasks? Setting up must’ve been exhausting. If you need any adjustments with the staff, don’t hesitate to ask."

His politeness was almost unsettling. Was she about to be expelled?

She forced a tight smile. "The university’s support has been more than enough. I don’t have any additional requests."

"Excellent. Once the guests arrive, I’ll need you to put in a good word for us."

"A strong impression could secure more funding for new facilities."

Evelyn nodded. "Understood."

After inspecting the setup, she noticed a minor error and directed the workers to correct it.

Before long, Elizabeth rushed over. "Evelyn, are you done here?"

"Almost. Are the guests here?"

As they approached the entrance, a group of well-dressed visitors stepped inside. Among them stood a man in an impeccably tailored suit—Nathaniel Whitmore.

Evelyn’s breath hitched.

She had been trying to reach him for days, but he’d ignored her calls. And now, here he was—at her university.

Was he avoiding her?

Nathaniel’s gaze swept across the room before locking onto her.

The moment their eyes met, the entire hall seemed to still.

Theodore’s voice snapped her back to reality. "Evelyn, don’t just stand there. Come greet our guests."

Her pulse spiked.

If she had known Nathaniel would be here, she would’ve found an excuse to leave hours ago.
###Chapter 420

Evelyn Carter had pressing matters to discuss with Nathaniel Whitmore.

As she moved toward him, a flustered woman rushed past her. The woman's cheeks burned crimson as she breathlessly asked, "Mr. Whitmore, did you request my presence?"

Evelyn froze mid-step.

Theodore Winslow paused and corrected, "I summoned Evelyn, not you."

Clearing her throat nervously, Evelyn approached, catching the woman's displeased glare.

She understood the unspoken resentment. After all, Nathaniel was every woman's fantasy - devastatingly handsome with the Whitmore fortune at his disposal.

Stepping away from the murmuring crowd, Evelyn felt dozens of envious eyes tracking her movements. She exhaled quietly, blaming Nathaniel's magnetic presence for the unwanted attention.

Keeping her head down, she trailed behind Theodore, hoping to disappear into the background.

To her surprise, Theodore stepped aside and gestured forward. "Evelyn, since you're most familiar with the hall's design, why don't you give Mr. Whitmore the tour?"

Evelyn's marriage to Nathaniel made the Whitmore Group's funding for Halvard University a foregone conclusion. Theodore's eyes sparkled with barely concealed excitement - after all, as a student here, Evelyn gave Nathaniel every reason to invest.

Biting her lip, Evelyn hesitated. Yet for the sake of professionalism, she forced herself forward.

Keeping her gaze lowered, she murmured, "Mr. Whitmore, what aspects would you like me to explain?"

Nathaniel's lips quirked at her submissive act. He knew better - Evelyn was a master at masking her true thoughts.

"Proceed with your presentation," he instructed smoothly.

Evelyn suspected Nathaniel was deliberately making things difficult. But recognizing his status as the university's honored guest, she maintained composure and began explaining her design concepts.

Time slipped away unnoticed. Evelyn's throat grew hoarse from continuous speaking.

When Nathaniel offered a water bottle, she couldn't help noticing his elegant, pianist fingers.

Accepting it gratefully, she drank deeply, the cool liquid soothing her parched throat.

Turning to Nathaniel, she asked, "Any further questions, Mr. Whitmore? If not, I should return to my duties."

Clutching the bottle cap, Nathaniel studied her intently. "I wasn't aware of your musical interests."

He hadn't expected Evelyn to incorporate musical motifs into the hall's design. The youthful, vibrant aesthetic showcased unexpected talent.

Evelyn paused before answering. "I pursued music passionately in my youth, but financial constraints forced me to abandon it."

Nathaniel knew all about Evelyn's humble beginnings. "And now?" he probed.

"I've rediscovered music recently," she replied evenly. "Learning never truly ends."

"Is Christopher Montgomery your instructor?" Nathaniel's tone turned icy.

Sensing his disapproval, Evelyn avoided further mention of her cousin.

Glancing around the nearly empty hall, she changed tack. "You saw my message yesterday."

"I did," Nathaniel acknowledged casually.

Evelyn lowered her voice. "I tried calling you-"

Her jaw tightened. "If you saw it, why didn't you respond?"

Nathaniel's smirk unsettled her. "If it was truly urgent, you'd have called again."

Pursing her lips, Evelyn countered, "Considering you're transferring all assets to me, shouldn't you show more concern?"
###Chapter 421

Evelyn found Nathaniel's behavior utterly baffling. The divorce agreement clearly stipulated that he would surrender all his shares to her.

According to Benjamin's conditions, Nathaniel would essentially walk away from their marriage with nothing.

How could he remain so composed? It made no sense to her.

Nathaniel leaned back in his chair, his piercing gaze fixed on Evelyn. "I'm in no hurry. Why are you so tense?"

Evelyn blinked. Had she heard him correctly?

A disbelieving laugh escaped her lips.

"Nathaniel, if you're not concerned, then I'll simply take this agreement to Whitmore Enterprises tomorrow and assume your position as CEO."

To her surprise, Nathaniel didn't react with anger. Instead, an amused smirk curled at the corners of his mouth.

"Sounds perfect. The workload has been exhausting lately. I could use a break."

His tone was infuriatingly casual.

"If you ever need help with company matters, don’t hesitate to ask."

Evelyn’s confusion deepened.

In a burst of frustration, she grabbed his tie, pulling him closer. "Nathaniel, are you toying with me?"

Nathaniel sprawled lazily in his seat, one leg stretched out casually.

His eyes gleamed with mischief as he studied her. She was practically in his lap now, her almond-shaped eyes glistening with unshed tears, a mix of anger and defiance swirling in them.

She was like a wildcat—beautiful yet unpredictable, her claws always ready to strike.

Nathaniel’s throat bobbed as his voice dropped lower. "Hmm, you’ve gotten sharper this time."

He was definitely provoking her on purpose.

Evelyn’s temper flared. What game was he playing?

But when she met his gaze, the intensity in his dark eyes sent a jolt through her. It reminded her of that reckless night months ago.

Heat rushed to her cheeks.

Suddenly, she became acutely aware of her position—half-sprawled across his lap, as if she’d thrown herself at him when she grabbed his tie.

Embarrassed, she tried to pull away, but Nathaniel’s hands tightened around her waist.

The warmth of his palms seeped through the thin fabric of her dress, making her skin prickle with awareness.

She squirmed, her face burning, but Nathaniel held firm.

As they struggled, the air between them grew thick with tension.

Evelyn huffed. "Nathaniel, let go! This is a public office!"

His grip only tightened, his gaze darkening. "We’re still married, aren’t we? There’s nothing inappropriate about this."

"I’m pregnant!" she snapped.

Was he out of his mind?

Nathaniel’s expression darkened further. Instead of releasing her, he cupped the back of her head, his lips curling into a cold smile.

"I don’t need reminding. I’m well aware the child isn’t mine." His voice was icy. "But that just means we don’t have to worry about protection, doesn’t it?"

Evelyn’s lips parted in shock. What was he implying?

Before she could react, Nathaniel pulled her fully onto his lap, her legs straddling his.

Her ear pressed against his chest, the steady rhythm of his heartbeat loud in her ears. The heat radiating from him made her pulse race.

Her entire body trembled as she struggled, but Nathaniel’s hold was unyielding.

His gaze dropped to her lips, lingering there.

Then, without warning, he closed the distance between them.
###Chapter 422

A sudden cold sensation sealed Evelyn's lips, making her eyes fly open in shock.

Her breath hitched as she realized Nathaniel was kissing her.

Her mind went completely blank, her body frozen in disbelief.

Three years of marriage, and this was only their second physical contact.

They'd never even held hands before, yet now Nathaniel was pressing his lips against hers with startling intensity.

What was he thinking?

As awareness returned, Evelyn shoved against his chest, but Nathaniel didn't budge.

Her palms flattened against his shirt, feeling the rapid thud of his heartbeat beneath her fingers. It was racing—faster than she'd ever felt it.

Nathaniel's breathing grew uneven, his grip tightening as if intoxicated by her taste.

Everything felt surreal, like a hazy dream she couldn't escape.

When she managed to open her eyes, she saw Nathaniel's face hovering close, his expression unreadable but his posture tense.

"Stop this! What are you doing?" Victoria's sharp voice sliced through the moment.

Nathaniel stiffened at the interruption, breaking away abruptly.

Evelyn seized the chance to push him back, stumbling several steps away, her pulse hammering.

A faint flush colored Nathaniel's sharp cheekbones, his shirt rumpled where she'd gripped it.

His dark eyes burned with intensity, his lips slightly parted and glistening.

For a fleeting second, Evelyn was mesmerized by how devastatingly attractive he looked.

His ragged breathing filled the silence between them, sending an unexpected shiver down her spine.

She still couldn't process that Nathaniel had just kissed her—without warning, without permission.

Tears welled in Victoria's eyes as she glared at them. "Nathaniel, what was that? Did Evelyn throw herself at you?"

Evelyn let out a disbelieving laugh at the accusation.

The audacity of Victoria to spin it that way!

Fury ignited in her chest, and before she could stop herself, Evelyn closed the distance between her and Nathaniel again.

Nathaniel arched a brow, watching her with faint amusement as she approached.

In one swift motion, Evelyn grabbed his loosened tie and yanked him down, pressing herself against him as she shot Victoria a defiant look.

"Does it matter who started it? We're legally married. Kissing behind a stage curtain isn't a crime, is it?"

Nathaniel's gaze locked onto hers as she held him close.

Though his tie was uncomfortably tight around his neck, he tilted his head slightly, as if silently agreeing with her bold claim.

Victoria's face twisted with rage. "Evelyn, stop lying! Nathaniel would never kiss you willingly!"

Evelyn turned, meeting Nathaniel's eyes with a challenging smile. "Darling, Ms. Sinclair seems doubtful. Maybe you should clarify things for her—once and for all."

She wanted to see how Nathaniel would explain this.

A smirk tugged at Nathaniel's lips as he leaned in. "Words won't convince her."

Before Evelyn could react, Nathaniel kissed her again—right in front of Victoria.

Evelyn's eyes flew wide, stunned by his boldness.

Victoria's face crumpled, tears streaming down her cheeks as she choked out, "How could you... Nathaniel, how could you do this to me?"
###Chapter 423

Evelyn's ears rang with Victoria's desperate, broken voice. She could hardly process what was happening right before her eyes.

Nathaniel finally broke the kiss, his dark eyes studying Evelyn's stunned expression. A low chuckle rumbled in his chest. "I believe that explanation was rather persuasive, don't you think?"

Evelyn stood frozen, her mind reeling.

Up this close, Nathaniel's sharp features were even more striking. Her jaw tightened in frustration.

She raised her hand to slap him, but Nathaniel caught her wrist effortlessly. His palm burned against her skin.

With effortless strength, he pulled her against him, tilting her chin up with his other hand. His voice dropped to a dangerous murmur. "Were you planning to hit me?"

"And what if I was?" Evelyn snapped.

"You could try," Nathaniel mused, releasing her wrist. His lips curved. "Haven't you heard? 'Lovers' quarrels are but love renewed'?"

The suggestive glint in his narrowed eyes made her blood boil.

Evelyn's hand trembled midair. "You vile, insufferable—"

Nathaniel merely tilted his head, clearly amused by her fury.

Victoria chose that moment to intervene, her tear-filled eyes accusing. "Nathaniel! How could you? Did she seduce you?"

The idea that Nathaniel would initiate a kiss was unthinkable. He'd always been untouchable, keeping women at arm's length.

Yet here he was, cradling Evelyn's face with surprising tenderness, his gaze burning with unmistakable desire.

Jealousy twisted Victoria's heart into knots.

Why did Evelyn deserve his attention? Victoria was the heiress—beautiful, wealthy, accomplished. What did this nobody orphan have that she didn't?

Evelyn turned to see Victoria weeping dramatically. She felt no sympathy—only bitter amusement.

Watching Victoria's meltdown reminded Evelyn of her own past heartbreak. She'd learned the hard way that men weren't worth the pain.

Nathaniel regarded Victoria with icy detachment, clearly annoyed by the interruption. "What are you doing here?"

Evelyn blinked in surprise at his harsh tone.

Victoria recoiled as if struck. Tears streamed down her cheeks, her perfect makeup smearing.

Evelyn couldn't stomach the scene any longer. She reached for her canvas bag, ready to leave.

Victoria grabbed her arm viciously. "Oh no, you don't! Explain yourself!"

"Let go!" Evelyn yanked free, but the sudden movement sent her bag tumbling. Papers scattered across the floor.

A thick document slid to Victoria's feet.

The bold print on the first page read: "DIVORCE AGREEMENT."

Evelyn's stomach dropped. She'd nearly forgotten about the papers.

She lunged for them, but Victoria was faster, snatching the documents with a triumphant smirk.

"Well, well," Victoria purred, waving the papers. "All this drama, yet you're still getting divorced. Planning to seduce Nathaniel again for round two?"
###Chapter 424

With Eleanor's surgery completed, Evelyn's divorce from Nathaniel was inevitable.

Victoria's smug smirk made Evelyn's stomach twist with unease.

Evelyn arched an eyebrow, her lips curling into a mocking smile. "Victoria, darling, did you skip the property division section? Let me enlighten you—scroll to page seven."

She leaned in, her voice dripping with amusement. "Turns out, I'm about to become the richest woman in the city. Who needs a husband when you can have billions?"

Victoria's fingers trembled as she flipped to the section. Her face paled.

The document clearly stated Nathaniel would transfer all his Whitmore Group shares to Evelyn.

"This is absurd!" Victoria spat, her nails digging into the paper. "Nathaniel would never agree to this!"

If he signed this, he'd be left with nothing.

Evelyn crossed her arms, unfazed. "Oh, but he did. His signature is right there. Legally binding, sweetheart."

Victoria's breath hitched. She frantically turned to the last page—and there it was. Nathaniel's bold, unmistakable signature.

Her vision swam.

She whirled toward Nathaniel, clutching the papers like a lifeline. "Tell me this is a forgery! You wouldn’t—you couldn’t—"

Nathaniel didn’t even glance at her. "I signed it," he said flatly.

Victoria's voice rose to a shriek. "Are you insane? Do you realize what this means?"

Evelyn watched, stunned. She had the same question burning in her throat—but before she could speak, Nathaniel suddenly yanked her close.

His lips crashed onto hers in a searing kiss.

When he pulled back, his expression was unreadable. "Not your business," he told Victoria dismissively.

Victoria looked like she might combust.

Evelyn, still reeling from the kiss, barely registered her own shock. Was Nathaniel out of his damn mind?

Nathaniel’s gaze locked onto the divorce papers in Victoria’s grip. "Give them back," he ordered.

Evelyn hadn’t planned to reclaim them—but seeing Victoria’s fury, she couldn’t resist.

With a saccharine smile, she held out her hand. "Be a dear and hand it over, Victoria. That document is worth more than your entire wardrobe."

Victoria jerked away. "It’s not finalized yet!"

Evelyn smirked. "Thanks for the reminder. I’ll sign it right now. Then I’ll be the first self-made female billionaire in history." She tilted her head. "Don’t worry—I’ll send you both an invite to my victory gala."

Victoria’s face twisted.

All these years, she’d schemed to marry into the Whitmore fortune. And now, Nathaniel was signing it away?

No. She wouldn’t let Evelyn win.

With a snarl, Victoria ripped the papers to shreds.

Evelyn sighed. "Really, Victoria? Petty even for you."

But inside, she was grinning.

This was far from over.
###Chapter 425

Evelyn gasped as she watched the confetti-like scraps of paper flutter to the ground, astonished by how effortlessly Victoria had demolished the hefty legal document.

The fury radiating from Victoria was palpable.

With the contract now in irreparable pieces, Victoria locked eyes with Evelyn. "Now you can't sign it," she declared triumphantly.

Without Evelyn's signature, the divorce agreement was effectively nullified.

Evelyn remained silent, instead turning her attention to Nathaniel. "What now?" she asked quietly.

Though she couldn't interfere directly, Evelyn recognized that Victoria had inadvertently provided a solution. The destroyed document carried no legal weight anymore.

Noticing the subtle satisfaction in Evelyn's expression, Nathaniel's smile disappeared instantly. In an eerily calm voice, he stated, "I have another copy."

Evelyn's breath caught in her throat.

Victoria's sobs intensified nearby.

Despite the anger bubbling inside her, Evelyn forced a smile when she saw Victoria's distress.

"How convenient, Mr. Whitmore. Just remember to bring it next time. I'll happily print another copy and sign it for you. Don't forget now, will you?"

Victoria froze at Evelyn's words.

"Evelyn, have you no shame?" Victoria spat. "I've never seen anyone try to take everything from their spouse in a divorce. Who do you think you are to leave Nathaniel penniless?"

Evelyn arched an eyebrow, meeting Victoria's glare. "That's simply how it is. Nathaniel feels he owes me, so he's chosen to transfer all his assets to me."

"He's worried about how I'll survive after our divorce," Evelyn added with biting sarcasm.

Seeing the envy flash in Victoria's eyes, Evelyn couldn't resist taunting, "Oh Victoria, didn't you once claim to adore Nathaniel?"

"Well now that he's about to become destitute, that shouldn't be a problem for you, should it?"

Victoria recoiled as if struck.

Who in their right mind would marry a bankrupt man?

After all, Victoria had clawed her way out of orphanhood to become the Montgomery heiress.

Her lifelong ambition had been to marry into wealth and become a society darling.

Still, Victoria wasn't about to admit her true feelings. She recovered quickly, snapping back, "Of course it wouldn't bother me. But what gives you the right to take everything?"

"Because Nathaniel is willing. Do you get a say in this?" With that final jab, Evelyn strode off the stage.

Panicking, Victoria whirled toward Nathaniel. "You're seriously going to give her everything and walk away with nothing?" she demanded.

Victoria couldn't comprehend it!

What kind of man would do such a thing? Especially Nathaniel, who came from old money and controlled vast assets. He hadn't built his empire with Evelyn - a modest settlement would have sufficed!

Nathaniel's expression remained impassive as he fixed Victoria with a cold stare. "That's my concern, not yours," he stated firmly.

"Nat, don't misunderstand," Victoria backpedaled quickly. "I'm only thinking of your reputation. If word gets out you're transferring all your shares to Evelyn, the Whitmore Group stock will plummet."

"Besides," she continued smoothly, "you could just give her some cash and maybe a property. With Evelyn's humble background, she'd never spend it all in her lifetime."

"Is there really any need to hand over everything?"

Nathaniel didn't dignify her question with a response. Instead, he turned on his heel and exited the stage.

Left alone, Victoria stared at the shredded paper littering the floor, her face twisting with bitterness.

She would never let Evelyn win this.

Composing herself, Victoria pulled out her phone and dialed a familiar number.

"Mrs. Whitmore? I hope I'm not disturbing you. Remember when I visited Nord City recently? I brought back some exclusive skincare products for you. I'll deliver them personally this evening."
###Chapter 426

Evelyn ended the call with a renewed determination burning in her chest. Victoria Sinclair wouldn't get away with her schemes this time.

With Beatrice Harrington's support, Evelyn felt an unshakable confidence. Together, they could dismantle Victoria's carefully laid plans.

Across campus, Victoria stepped out of the auditorium, a smug smile playing on her lips. The look on Evelyn's face when she'd torn up those divorce papers had been absolutely priceless.

Nathaniel's unexpected intervention had worked perfectly in Victoria's favor.

Just then, Theodore Winslow approached. "Evelyn, how did your discussion with Mr. Whitmore go? Any feedback on the stage design?"

Evelyn hesitated only a moment before answering. "He confirmed everything was perfect. No changes needed."

She hadn't actually spoken to Nathaniel about it, but she knew him well enough. Such trivial details wouldn't concern him. There was no need to bother him with questions.

A deep voice cut through her thoughts. "When exactly did I say that?"

Evelyn spun around to find Nathaniel standing right behind her. Her breath caught. Hadn't he gone to verify details with Victoria?

The air grew thick with tension.

Theodore cleared his throat nervously. "Mr. Whitmore, do you have any suggestions for improvements?"

Nathaniel stepped closer, his piercing gaze locked onto Evelyn's lowered head. A smirk tugged at his lips. "I believe Evelyn has some thoughts about me she'd like to share."

Evelyn's jaw tightened. Forcing a smile, she said, "I assumed your silence meant approval."

"And if I hadn't spoken up? Would you have asked?"

Evelyn blinked. What game was he playing now?

When she met his eyes, she saw the familiar mischievous glint. He was teasing her. Again.

"Isn't that what I'm doing now?" she countered smoothly.

Nathaniel surveyed the auditorium before focusing on the stage's centerpiece. "That drapery looks excessive. It doesn't fit the theme."

Evelyn's brows knitted together. "It complements the design perfectly."

She moved closer to inspect the fabric. Up close, it looked perfectly acceptable to her.

Theodore shifted uncomfortably. Who would've thought the university's power couple would be arguing over stage decorations?

Elizabeth Hartwell caught Evelyn's eye and gave a subtle nod. Given Nathaniel was the primary investor, a small adjustment to please him wouldn't hurt.

"Why don't you test the mechanism?" Nathaniel suggested, moving beside her.

Evelyn frowned. "The effect is designed for a single use during the actual performance. Each activation costs a hundred thousand dollars."

Nathaniel raised an eyebrow. "After my investment, another hundred thousand is nothing."

"You invested?" Evelyn hadn't realized all the equipment came from his company.

Nathaniel remained impassive. "Test it. I'll cover the cost."

Evelyn considered. If Nathaniel was footing the bill, why not? Truthfully, she'd been curious about the full stage effect herself.

Theodore eagerly arranged the demonstration. As music filled the hall, the curtains rose dramatically, bringing Evelyn's vision to life. Her heart raced with excitement watching her creation unfold.

When the demonstration ended, Evelyn paused thoughtfully. "You know... the drapery does seem a bit much. Let's remove it."

As she directed the changes, a sudden wave of nausea overwhelmed her. Evelyn barely made it to a nearby trash can before doubling over.
###Chapter 427

Evelyn felt like her stomach was turning inside out.

Had it been something she ate for lunch?

As she paused to catch her breath, a bottle of chilled water appeared in front of her. She couldn’t help but notice Nathaniel’s long, elegant fingers as he held it out.

Without hesitation, Evelyn took it, twisting the cap off and gulping down a few sips. The cool liquid soothed her throat, but the discomfort in her abdomen lingered.

She pressed a hand lightly against her stomach, frowning. Something didn’t feel right.

Nathaniel’s sharp gaze followed the movement. "What’s wrong?"

"Nothing serious," Evelyn murmured. "Just a bit queasy from lunch."

She didn’t think much of it—her pregnancy had been smooth so far, with only occasional bouts of nausea.

But as she turned to leave, Nathaniel caught her wrist, his grip firm. "You should get checked at the hospital."

Evelyn blinked, startled by his insistence. She pulled her hand free. "It’s really not necessary."

Nathaniel stepped in front of her, his jaw tight. "Do you even realize your condition? What if something’s wrong?"

His tone was edged with frustration, as if he couldn’t believe her carelessness.

Evelyn opened her mouth to argue, but Theodore cut in smoothly. "You’ve been working nonstop, Evelyn. Since everything’s nearly wrapped up here, why not humor Mr. Whitmore and get checked? For his peace of mind."

Evelyn couldn’t fathom why Nathaniel would be concerned about her.

Theodore’s words were clearly meant to placate him, not her.

Nathaniel’s expression darkened slightly, the air between them growing tense.

Uncomfortable, Evelyn turned away. "It’s just a stomachache. I’ll be fine."

She wasn’t about to rush to the hospital over morning sickness. The thought was embarrassing.

But as she took a few steps, her vision blurred. Her legs buckled beneath her.

Just before she hit the ground, Nathaniel’s arms wrapped around her, steadying her.

Evelyn’s eyelids fluttered weakly. The last thing she saw was Nathaniel’s striking profile—sharp, aristocratic, and unreadable.

Then darkness swallowed her.

Nathaniel lifted her effortlessly, striding out of the hall without a word.

As he settled her into the car, his voice was clipped. "Drive to the hospital. Now. Notify Dr. Whitmore—have the OB-GYN team ready."

His gaze dropped to Evelyn’s pale face, his fingers tightening slightly around her.

He kicked Frederick’s seat. "Faster."

The car surged forward.

By the time they arrived, Dr. Diana Whitmore was already waiting at the entrance.

Nathaniel carried Evelyn out, his expression unreadable. Simon hurried forward. "Mr. Whitmore, the team is prepped as you requested."

"Where’s the operating room?" Nathaniel demanded.

"Third floor," Theodore confirmed.

Nathaniel didn’t hesitate, heading straight for the elevators.

Theodore watched, baffled but silent.

Robert caught up quickly. "Sir, a gurney would be faster. The doctors can examine Ms. Carter immediately."

Nathaniel didn’t slow down. "No time."

His grip on Evelyn never loosened.
###Chapter 428

Nathaniel's voice turned razor-sharp when Robert made his suggestion. "Where's the nearest gurney?"

Simon immediately signaled a nurse to bring one. With careful movements, Nathaniel transferred Evelyn onto the rolling bed before turning back to the hospital director.

"She's pregnant," he explained, his voice tight. "Fainted after severe morning sickness."

In his initial panic, Nathaniel had completely forgotten about hospital protocol and the efficiency of medical equipment.

Now composed, he gave Diana a thorough rundown of Evelyn's symptoms.

Simon's entire demeanor changed upon hearing about the pregnancy. "Mr. Whitmore, rest assured we'll ensure both mother and babies receive the utmost care."

"See that you do." Nathaniel's gaze burned with intensity. "Any harm comes to them, this hospital will face consequences you can't imagine."

His eyes followed the gurney until it disappeared behind operating room doors.

Sweat had soaked through his dress shirt. He shrugged off his suit jacket and tugged at his constricting tie.

The blinking red light above the OR doors held Nathaniel captive. After several tense minutes, he turned to Robert.

"Is childbirth really that dangerous?" The question came out rougher than intended.

Robert's expression turned grave. "My cousin nearly died from a postpartum hemorrhage. The doctors fought for hours to save her."

He swallowed hard before continuing. "Her own mother-in-law refused to pay for the life-saving surgery at first. Said it wasn't worth the expense."

Nathaniel's jaw tightened. "That's monstrous."

"Exactly why pregnancy terrifies most women." Robert shook his head. "Never understood the risks until I witnessed it firsthand."

Silence fell between them as Nathaniel absorbed this new perspective.

For the first time, doubts crept in. Was bringing children into the world worth endangering Evelyn? If things went wrong, adoption remained an option...

The OR doors swung open, cutting through his thoughts. Diana scanned the hallway. "Family for Evelyn Carter?"

Nathaniel stepped forward. "That would be me."

"You're the husband, I presume?" Diana didn't wait for confirmation. "Your wife has been pushing herself too hard. The stress combined with poor nutrition caused her blood sugar to crash dangerously low."

She fixed Nathaniel with a stern look. "As the father of her twins, you need to step up. Handle more responsibilities so she can rest properly."

Nathaniel's fingers curled into fists at his sides.

Simon quickly intervened. "Dr. Whitmore means well, Mr. Whitmore. She's our top OB-GYN, just...blunt."

Through gritted teeth, Nathaniel asked, "Will she recover?"

"For now, yes." Diana adjusted her glasses. "But continued stress could lead to complications. She's also anemic and needs calcium supplements."

Guilt twisted in Nathaniel's gut as he recalled Evelyn working tirelessly to prepare the university event space these past weeks.

Moments later, nurses wheeled Evelyn out, still unconscious. Nathaniel followed them to a private suite, throwing Robert a glance.

"Make arrangements per Dr. Whitmore's instructions," he ordered, tension lining every word.

Robert placed Evelyn's tote bag on the nightstand before slipping out. Alone now, Nathaniel studied his sleeping wife.

Color had returned to her cheeks, though her lips remained pale.

A sudden ringing shattered the quiet. The sound came from Evelyn's bag.

Nathaniel reached inside without thinking. The screen displayed a single name: "Christopher."
###Chapter 429

The phone screen flashed with the name "Christopher." Nathaniel Whitmore's brows knitted together in confusion. Who the hell was Christopher?

His gaze remained fixed on Evelyn Carter's buzzing phone as it continued to ring.

Unable to suppress his curiosity any longer, Nathaniel finally answered.

Christopher's voice came through, warm and familiar. "Evelyn, I'm at the university gates. Are your classes over? I'm waiting outside for you."

The moment Nathaniel heard a man's voice, his expression darkened. "She doesn't need you to wait for her."

"Who is this?"

Christopher's tone turned icy as Nathaniel responded. "Let's keep this civil. Hand the phone to Evelyn. If you're after money or have demands, we can talk terms."

Nathaniel was momentarily stunned. Money? Since when had he ever needed to beg for it?

His lips thinned into a sharp line. "That's my line. From now on, you and your family stay away from Evelyn. Or don't blame me for what happens next."

With that, he ended the call.

Christopher stood frozen, the abrupt disconnect leaving him bewildered.

Had Evelyn been kidnapped again?

Panic surged through him as he dialed Andrew Montgomery. "Andrew, it's bad. Evelyn might be in danger."

"What happened? Tell me everything."

Christopher recounted the call, his voice tight with agitation. "You won't believe who answered. The guy was insufferably arrogant! But last I checked, Jonathan Reeves was still in custody, right?"

Andrew paused, considering. "Do you have a recording of the call? Play it for me. I might recognize the voice."

Christopher forwarded the recording immediately, then called back, impatience gnawing at him. "Well? Who was it?"

Andrew exhaled sharply. "If I'm not mistaken, that was Nathaniel Whitmore."

Christopher stiffened. "Nathaniel Whitmore? The heir to the Whitmore fortune? The same man Victoria Sinclair was bragging about marrying?"

"Exactly."

Christopher's jaw clenched. "You heard what he said. That wasn't the tone of a reasonable man. He clearly has ulterior motives toward Evelyn—and now he's got her."

"I understand your concern. But if Evelyn is with Nathaniel, at least she's safe for now. I'll handle this. Don't worry."

"Don't worry?" Christopher snapped. "Evelyn is my sister too. Why do I get the feeling you're hiding something? Is there history between her and Nathaniel?"

Christopher had always had a sharp instinct for these things.

Nathaniel's warning to stay away from Evelyn only confirmed his suspicions—there was more to this than met the eye.

But Andrew remained silent, refusing to elaborate.

The longer Christopher thought about it, the more unsettled he became.

He knew Evelyn had once worked as a caretaker for Eleanor Whitmore in the Whitmore estate—a role that, in wealthy households, was little more than a glorified maid.

What could possibly develop between a maid and a billionaire heir?

No matter the outcome, Evelyn would be the one to suffer.

Christopher's hands balled into fists. If Nathaniel hurt her, he swore he'd make him pay.

In the sterile hospital room, Evelyn stirred awake.

Her eyelids fluttered against the harsh fluorescent lights as she slowly took in her surroundings.

Instinctively, her hands flew to her abdomen.

Where were her babies?

Had Nathaniel ordered the doctors to terminate her pregnancy without her consent?

"What are you looking for?" Nathaniel's deep voice cut through the silence.

Evelyn's gaze snapped up to find him standing by the window. Her voice trembled as she demanded, "Where are my children? What did you do to them?"
###Chapter 430

Evelyn's disbelief was evident, and Nathaniel grew increasingly irritated. Was this really how she saw him?

He lifted his gaze, his tone sharp. "What did you expect? They're not my children. Why would I want them?"

His words struck her like a physical blow. Her hands trembled as she lowered them to her stomach, tears spilling over.

Were her babies really gone?

Seeing her tears, Nathaniel instantly regretted his cruel joke. "Evelyn, don't—"

But before he could finish, she launched herself at him, fueled by fury and grief. "Nathaniel, I swear—!"

Alarmed by her sudden movement, he shoved his laptop aside and caught her before she could hurt herself.

In the next second, her hands locked around his throat.

She flipped him onto the sofa, straddling him, her grip tightening. If he had taken her babies from her, she would make him pay.

Nathaniel winced at the pressure but didn’t push her away. Gritting his teeth, he managed to choke out, "Let go."

"Never! You're a murderer!" she hissed.

Just then, the door swung open.

Diana Whitmore and Isabelle Laurent froze in the doorway, stunned by the scene before them.

Evelyn was pinning Nathaniel down on the sofa, their bodies pressed close in what looked like an intimate embrace.

Diana’s brows furrowed. "What on earth is going on here?"

At the sound of her voice, Evelyn loosened her grip but remained tense. Nathaniel, however, pulled her closer against him.

She shoved him away, disgusted by his touch.

Nathaniel remained composed. "We should stop. We have an audience."

Evelyn stiffened.

Diana crossed her arms, her expression stern. "This is highly inappropriate behavior for a hospital, especially for a pregnant woman carrying twins."

Evelyn’s breath caught. "Wait—my babies are still here?"

"Of course they are," Diana said. "Mr. Whitmore was very clear when he brought you in. If anything happened to those babies, this hospital would face serious consequences."

"So rest assured, both you and your twins are perfectly safe."

Evelyn turned to Nathaniel, stunned.

She had expected him to demand an abortion, but instead, he had ensured her babies' safety.

She had misjudged him entirely.

Nathaniel leaned back, watching her with calm amusement. "Do you understand now?"

Evelyn swallowed hard. "Then why did you say those things?"

"What things? You misunderstood."

She clenched her fists, resisting the urge to hit him.

Flushed with embarrassment, she pulled away. Now that she knew her babies were safe, her anger faded.

Diana cleared her throat. "Pregnancy hormones can be intense, but you must exercise restraint, especially in public."

Evelyn’s face burned. "It’s not what you think!"

Nathaniel smirked. "I didn’t exactly resist."

Diana gave him a pointed look. "As the father, you should educate yourself on these matters. Allowing reckless behavior could harm the babies."

Nathaniel tilted his head. "Where can I find more information?"
###Chapter 431

Evelyn's cheeks burned with humiliation at Nathaniel's words.

What on earth was he talking about?

But Dr. Diana remained perfectly composed, unfazed by the awkwardness. "We have educational materials on this subject available at the hospital. If you're interested, you can purchase one to take home."

Nathaniel stroked his chin thoughtfully. "Is that so? How considerate."

Evelyn quickly cut in, turning to Diana. "Are my babies really okay?"

Even though Diana had already assured her about the twins' health, Evelyn needed to hear it again for her own peace of mind.

She couldn’t shake the suspicion that Nathaniel and Diana might be conspiring to deceive her.

Diana gave her a knowing look. "If your children weren’t alive, you wouldn’t have the energy to argue so passionately right now. An abortion isn’t exactly a walk in the park."

Evelyn found some comfort in her words. She felt no pain in her abdomen, no telltale scent of blood.

If she had really lost them, it would have destroyed her.

She exhaled in relief, grateful to wake up and find Nathaniel beside her.

Yet, the memory of him forcing her toward an abortion and locking her in the hospital still lingered like a shadow.

After finishing her examination, Diana turned to Evelyn. "As you enter the later stages of pregnancy, you must take better care of yourself."

"You’re showing signs of malnourishment, especially since you’re carrying twins. Given your husband’s wealth, is there really a need for you to overexert yourself daily?"

Nathaniel received another pointed glance from Diana, prompting him to interject. "This isn’t my fault. It’s not like she has to work so hard at home."

Evelyn smirked and shot him a look. "Oh? Who was the one cooking? Who handled all the chores? Who picked out your outfits every morning?"

The moment she finished, both Diana and Isabelle turned their disapproving stares toward Nathaniel.

Diana’s tone softened as she addressed Evelyn. "As an expectant mother, your health comes first. If you neglect yourself, how will you care for the babies growing inside you?"

Evelyn nodded earnestly. "I understand now."

Once Diana and Isabelle left, Nathaniel spoke cautiously. "Are you happy now that you’ve publicly shamed me?"

Evelyn scoffed. "I wasn’t shaming you. Was anything I said untrue?"

"But that was in the past. It’s not like you collapsed this time because of housework, right?"

Guilt flickered in Evelyn’s chest, and she quickly deflected. "Didn’t I just say it was in the past?"

Nathaniel’s jaw tightened. "Evelyn, is this how you thank someone who saved your life? If I hadn’t caught you in time and rushed you here, do you honestly think you’d be sitting here lecturing me?"

He was so furious he reached for his tie to loosen it, only to find it already undone from the hours spent waiting for her to wake.

Evelyn shuddered at the thought of what might have happened if he hadn’t been there when she collapsed.

Even though the babies were his, she had no intention of telling him—not yet.

Taking a deep breath, she cleared her throat. "Thank you for helping me earlier."

Nathaniel arched a brow. "Well, well. A 'thank you' from you? That’s rare."

Ignoring his sarcasm, Evelyn grabbed her bag from the bedside table, ready to leave.

If she didn’t return home soon, Margaret and her brothers would start asking questions.

Nathaniel frowned. "Where do you think you’re going?"

Clutching her bag tighter, she answered, "Home, obviously."

He smirked. "In such a hurry? Afraid I’ll take advantage of you?"

Remembering his earlier call with Christopher, Nathaniel’s mood darkened. Soon, she’d be facing the Montgomerys—and he wasn’t sure she was ready for that.
###Chapter 432

Evelyn clutched her tote bag tightly and turned to face Nathaniel. "I'm perfectly fine, really. Just exhausted and my blood sugar dropped too low."

His stormy gray eyes darkened as he rose from his seat. "I'm driving you home."

"No, thank you. I'll call a cab." She forced a polite smile. "We're going opposite directions anyway. You've already done enough by bringing me to the hospital. I can't possibly inconvenience you further."

The deliberate distance she created made his jaw tighten. "Is this about appearances? Worried someone might see you in my car and get the wrong idea?"

Evelyn blinked in genuine confusion. "That's not what I meant at all. I simply don't want to waste Mr. Whitmore's valuable time."

Without waiting for a response, she strode out of the room. Within seconds, she heard the steady rhythm of his leather shoes following her.

The elevator doors slid open and Nathaniel stepped in right behind her. The confined space forced them uncomfortably close - close enough that she caught the faint scent of his cologne mingling with laundry detergent.

Her stomach flipped. That scent. She'd chosen that particular detergent herself during their three years together.

At the next floor, a flood of people crammed into the elevator, including an elderly woman pushing a wheelchair-bound man. A hyperactive boy darted around them, bouncing a rubber ball.

Evelyn instinctively pressed a protective hand to her abdomen and tried to step back. "Excuse me, could you please—"

The grandmother cut her off sharply. "This elevator is small enough as it is! Should I let my grandson get crushed instead?" She jabbed a bony finger near Evelyn's face. "Young people these days have no respect for their elders!"
