Without a word, she tugged the brim of her hat lower, spotted a gap in the crowd, and bolted.

Nathaniel’s outstretched hand hung in the air as he watched Evelyn disappear.

His expression turned thunderous.

She’d run from him.

Was he really that terrifying?

He withdrew his hand just as a striking woman sidled up to him. "Hey, handsome," she purred. "You look like you could use some company. How about a drink tonight?"

Nathaniel barely spared her a glance. "No, thank you."

With that, he turned on his heel and strode back to his car.

As he drove away, he dialed Evelyn’s number.

No answer.
###Chapter 470

Nathaniel stared at the crimson rose resting on the passenger seat, wondering what madness had possessed him to make such a romantic gesture.

Across town, Evelyn quickly flagged down a taxi and left the university campus. As the car pulled away, she glanced back through the rear window, her phone vibrating relentlessly in her hand.

She watched the screen light up repeatedly but refused to answer. Evelyn couldn't comprehend Nathaniel's sudden change in behavior.

Memories surfaced of their last conversation while shopping for nursery items. Was this his attempt at salvaging their marriage? The realization hit her - he was only doing this because of Eleanor.

Her phone chimed with a WhatsApp notification. "Why did you run?" Nathaniel's message read.

Evelyn's fingers hovered over the keyboard before she decided against responding.

Another message followed moments later. "Remember, this is Bern City. You can't hide from me."

Anger flared as she immediately called back. "What do you want, Nathaniel?"

His smooth voice answered, "Finally. Why did you leave like that?"

"You appeared out of nowhere causing a scene! How could I focus on my exams with you disrupting everything? What's your real motive here?"

Evelyn's unease grew. Why was she being questioned like this?

"I merely wanted to make amends," Nathaniel replied calmly.

Make amends?

The statement caught her off guard. "I won't be manipulated. And why would you even try?"

Suddenly, understanding dawned on Evelyn.

"You can't possibly think a single rose would make me forget everything and cancel our divorce?" she scoffed.

There was a thoughtful pause before Nathaniel responded, "I don't do this for just anyone."

Evelyn laughed bitterly. "Well Mr. Whitmore, I don't accept gestures from just anyone either."

"Would you like to find out?" His voice dropped an octave.

"Find out what?" she asked cautiously.

"What it's like to be properly courted by me," Nathaniel's deep voice purred through the phone.

Evelyn felt her chest constrict with familiar pain. For three years she'd bent to his will, and now that she'd finally found the strength to leave, he dared to tempt her back.

"No thank you," she said firmly. "I've already had that experience. Never again."

Ending the call, she gazed out at the passing city lights, lost in thought.

Arriving home, Evelyn found Julian and Andrew lounging in the living room. She'd assumed Andrew would have returned to Nord City by now.

As Margaret disappeared into the kitchen, Andrew leaned closer. "Evelyn, there's an issue with your immigration paperwork in Bern City."

"What's wrong?" she asked.

"Since your divorce isn't finalized, Nathaniel's signature is required," Andrew explained.

Evelyn shook her head immediately. "No, he'd never agree. I can't risk telling him."

Given Nathaniel's behavior today, he might not only refuse but actively interfere.

"Evelyn, you should expedite the divorce. If you need help—" Andrew began.

"I'll handle it myself," Evelyn interrupted. "Everything will be settled by week's end."

Andrew smiled. "Good. Alexander arrives in a few days - perfect timing to take you home."

Soon, Alexander and their brothers would expose Victoria's deception and reveal Evelyn as the true Montgomery heiress.
###Chapter 471

The news of Alexander Montgomery's imminent arrival sent Evelyn Carter's heart racing.

Her palms grew clammy at the thought.

If Alexander arrived before Evelyn finalized her divorce from Nathaniel Whitmore, questions would inevitably arise.

Andrew Montgomery wouldn't be able to keep the truth hidden any longer.

Knowing Alexander's volatile nature, Evelyn feared he might cause trouble for Nathaniel upon discovering the situation.

She needed to act fast. No more delays could be tolerated.

The following morning, Evelyn walked into the university library as usual, but Danielle Spencer was conspicuously absent.

Remembering yesterday's awkward encounter outside the library, Evelyn pulled out her phone. "Danielle, are you coming to study today?"

Evelyn understood Danielle's pride and sensitivity, especially given their shared background as orphans. Clear communication was essential.

Meanwhile, Danielle sat reclined in a plush chair at an exclusive spa. She handed her phone to Victoria Sinclair with a smirk. "Evelyn just texted me."

"Danielle, that girl clearly doesn't respect you. How dare she humiliate you like that yesterday?"

"Honestly, you outclass her in every way. Why would a wealthy, handsome man choose her over you?" Victoria remarked.

Danielle's cheeks burned with humiliation. The memory of yesterday's rejection had kept her awake all night.

Walking across campus this morning, she'd imagined whispers and mocking laughter at every turn.

Victoria opened the university forum on her phone.

"People are already gossiping about yesterday's spectacle outside the library. Some are calling you delusional. It's disgusting."

Danielle's face drained of color. "What should I do?"

"This can be fixed easily. That man from yesterday is a billionaire. He wouldn't seriously be interested in Evelyn."

"Probably just some casual flirtation after their meeting at the university event. Evelyn played hard to get for money."

"And you've heard the rumors about her Fleur Design Competition win and scholarships, right? People say she slept her way to those achievements."

Danielle's envy flared. Why did Evelyn always get everything? That handsome billionaire should have been hers!

Victoria smiled knowingly. "Expose Evelyn's true nature, and her reputation will be ruined. Wealthy men care about appearances - he'll drop her immediately."

"But isn't that too harsh?" Danielle hesitated. Evelyn had been kind to her, and Danielle already carried guilt for stealing Evelyn's place as the Lane family heiress's childhood friend.

"Danielle, if you don't act now, how will you face campus gossip when these forum posts spread?"

The words struck home. Danielle valued her reputation above all else and couldn't bear public humiliation.

After a tense silence, Danielle accepted the USB drive from Victoria with a reluctant nod. "Okay, but what if Evelyn finds out?"

"Don't worry. Even if she does, she'll be too busy with her own problems to bother you. Besides, you have me, don't you?"

Somewhat reassured, Danielle pocketed the drive. As she prepared to leave, Victoria stopped her.

"Why not finish your facial first? Use my membership. Ask for whatever treatments you want."

"Thank you, Ms. Sinclair." Danielle's eyes lit up with greedy delight. She'd never imagined experiencing such luxury.

Watching Danielle's vain excitement, Victoria slipped from the private room, her smile vanishing instantly.

"Keep close watch on Danielle. No mistakes," she ordered an assistant.

"Ms. Sinclair, I've heard Mr. Alexander is returning to Bern City. The exact date isn't confirmed, but likely within days."

"I know. Alexander will come. After all, I've announced we've found the true Montgomery heiress. Naturally he'd want to see for himself."

Victoria's expression turned icy at the mention of the real heiress. The Montgomerys' urgency in these matters always reminded her she was merely a placeholder.
###Chapter 472

The possibility that Evelyn might be the true heiress of the Montgomery family only deepened Victoria’s reluctance.

Something felt off to Julian.

"Ms. Sinclair," he said carefully, "I can’t shake the feeling that something isn’t right here."

"In the past, whenever rumors about finding the real heiress surfaced, the family would react immediately—passionately."

"But this time, their response has been strangely muted, don’t you think? Alexander didn’t even ask about it."

Victoria frowned. Now that he mentioned it, it was odd.

Just as doubt crept into her mind, Julian’s call came through.

A faint smirk curled her lips. "Julian’s calling. He’s fishing for information."

"Aside from Sebastian, they all distrust me—especially since I’m the one who ‘found’ the heiress this time. Their caution is understandable."

She answered smoothly. "Julian. To what do I owe the pleasure?"

It was unusual for him to reach out first.

"Victoria, Sebastian arrives in two days. I’d like to meet the girl you found before he gets here."

"Julian, there’s no need to rush. If you visit her alone, she might grow suspicious."

"Let’s wait until everyone is present. We don’t want to scare her off, do we?"

Victoria couldn’t risk him meeting Danielle alone. That would ruin everything.

After a pause, Julian relented. "Fine. We’ll go together the day after tomorrow."

"Make sure she’s safe until then."

"Of course," Victoria purred. "She’s my dearest friend. I couldn’t be happier she’s coming home."

The moment the call ended, Julian scoffed. "That should ease her suspicions."

Andrew nodded. "I never trusted Victoria. But Sebastian insisted on keeping her around for Grandmother’s sake."

Christopher’s expression darkened. "At least now the mastermind won’t escape justice."

Julian agreed. "Once Sebastian arrives, he’ll deal with Victoria directly. She can’t stay here."

When Evelyn returned to Nord City, they’d have to protect her carefully.

Meanwhile, in the library, Evelyn sneezed sharply.

Rubbing her nose, she muttered, "Who’s talking about me?"

As she stepped out to refill her water bottle, she noticed her classmates staring. The moment she turned, they looked away.

Weird.

Her phone buzzed—Sophia.

"Evelyn, are you still on campus?"

"Yeah, in the library."

"Check what I just sent you. Someone’s trying to ruin you."

Evelyn opened the link. The university forum’s headline blared:

"Evelyn Carter: Genius or Gold Digger?"

The post featured a photo of Nathaniel outside the library last night—his tall frame striking, while Evelyn, half-hidden behind others, looked washed out and older.

The tactic felt familiar.

But who was behind it this time?

The scandal had exploded after an anonymous tip reached the student council. The university locked the forum, but the damage was done.

Whispers spread: Evelyn had secured scholarships through connections, relied on men to design the university hall, and—despite her leave of absence—somehow graduated early.

Coincidentally, today was the scholarship announcement.

Evelyn’s name was listed.

But as she approached the board, a group of students surrounded her, their expressions hostile.

"Evelyn," one snapped, "you’ve got some explaining to do."
###Chapter 473

Evelyn studied the restless crowd of students with sharp eyes.

"Someone is intentionally circulating lies to tarnish my name," she declared firmly.

A scoff came from the group. "Don't bother explaining. We've seen this pattern before - always with some powerful man backing you up."

"These honorary credits are crucial for our graduation," another student snapped. "Since you clearly have other avenues, why compete with those of us who actually need them?"

Just then, Danielle pushed through the gathering. "What's happening here? These accusations are completely unfounded! Someone's clearly jealous of Evelyn's accomplishments."

"Accomplishments?" A male student sneered. "We all know what kind of 'talents' she possesses. The kind that involves batting her eyelashes at wealthy men."

The murmurs of agreement spread through the crowd like wildfire.

Evelyn felt warmth spread through her chest at Danielle's unexpected defense. Turning to address the hostile faces, she suggested coolly, "Shall we involve campus security? A proper investigation might reveal who's behind these rumors."

Danielle's face paled at the mention of authorities. "Actually," she interjected quickly, "wouldn't it be better to take this directly to Dean Winslow?"

"Yes! Let Dean Winslow handle this!" several voices chimed in.

Evelyn had no reservations about facing Theodore Winslow - she had nothing to hide.

Danielle, however, couldn't suppress the nervous flutter in her stomach. The dean had resources to trace anonymous complaints, though she reassured herself that her burner email account would protect her identity.

The group marched toward the administration building, their footsteps echoing through the marble corridors.

When Theodore heard about the online allegations, his teacup nearly slipped from his grasp.

"Preposterous!" he exclaimed, adjusting his glasses. "Evelyn, rest assured we'll get to the bottom of this nonsense."

Evelyn simply nodded. "I appreciate that, Dean."

Danielle watched the exchange with barely concealed envy. "See, Evelyn? I told you the administration would support you."

This provoked immediate backlash from the other students.

"Dean Winslow, isn't this favoritism?" a bold girl challenged. "Just because she's connected to Nathaniel Whitmore?"

"Total injustice!" another cried.

Theodore rubbed his temples as the accusations flew. "Then what would you consider a fair resolution?"

"Revoke her scholarship!"

"Delay her graduation! If any of us took such a long leave of absence, we'd never catch up. Why does she get special treatment?"

Evelyn's voice cut through the chaos. "I'll voluntarily surrender the scholarship. But my credits meet all graduation requirements - that's simple academic policy."

"Policy for who?" someone jeered. "Regular students or sugar babies dating billionaires?"

Danielle bit her lip to hide her satisfaction. Finally, Evelyn was getting her comeuppance.

Evelyn's eyes flashed. "Who claims I've had inappropriate relationships?"

"The whole campus knows about you and Nathaniel Whitmore!" a voice shot back.

"Don't insult our intelligence by calling it friendship," another student sneered. "A college girl and a married CEO? Please. We all know the arrangement."

The air grew thick with tension as Evelyn squared her shoulders, ready to dismantle their accusations one by one.
###Chapter 474

Evelyn stood with her arms tightly folded, her gaze steady. "I must confess, my connection with Mr. Whitmore goes beyond mere friendship."

The room fell silent.

"Are you admitting to an inappropriate relationship with that tycoon?"

Theodore Winslow couldn't stay quiet any longer. "What inappropriate relationship? What kind of nonsense are you all being fed? Evelyn's relationship with Mr. Whitmore is genuine and honorable!"

The students scoffed. "Professor Winslow, Evelyn already admitted it. We don’t need your defense. What kind of relationship between a man and a woman could possibly be considered appropriate?"

"Marriage. Would that be legitimate enough for you?"

Nathaniel Whitmore’s deep, commanding voice cut through the tension as he stepped into the office doorway, his towering presence instantly dominating the room.

Dressed in an impeccably tailored suit, Nathaniel stood out starkly against the backdrop of curious onlookers.

A hush fell over the space as all eyes turned to him.

Evelyn’s breath hitched—she hadn’t expected him to show up.

Nathaniel approached her, his expression unreadable. "Are you being falsely accused?"

Evelyn pressed her lips together. "It’s just a misunderstanding."

Without hesitation, Nathaniel placed a reassuring hand on her shoulder, pulling her close in a protective embrace.

Turning to the students, his voice was firm. "My wife values her privacy and prefers to keep a low profile on campus. Unfortunately, that has led to baseless rumors."

He paused, letting his words sink in. "Let me make this clear—Evelyn is my wife."

The revelation sent shockwaves through the room.

The students who had been interrogating Evelyn moments ago now looked pale, their earlier confidence shattered. Who could have guessed that quiet, unassuming Evelyn Carter was actually Mrs. Whitmore?

Danielle Spencer, standing nearby, felt her knees buckle.

Never in her wildest dreams had she imagined Evelyn was married to Nathaniel Whitmore. Had she just made an enemy of one of the most powerful men in the city?

And Victoria Sinclair had never mentioned this. Danielle couldn’t shake the feeling she’d been played.

Theodore stepped forward, his tone firm. "See? I told you it was a misunderstanding. Now, apologize to Evelyn."

The students exchanged nervous glances before stammering out their apologies. "Evelyn, we were misled by the forum posts. We didn’t know the truth. Please forgive us."

"Yeah, we had no idea you were Mrs. Whitmore. Your discretion is admirable. It’s that anonymous reporter’s fault—they deliberately deceived us."

Evelyn’s expression softened slightly.

"I accept your apology. But I’d like to keep my identity private for now. Please respect that."

"Of course! We won’t tell a soul."

Theodore gestured toward the door. "Good. You’re all dismissed."

Danielle tried to slip away unnoticed, but Nathaniel blocked her path.

She swallowed hard. "Evelyn, I—I suddenly don’t feel well. I need to use the restroom."

Evelyn frowned, confused.

Nathaniel leaned in, his voice low. "She’s the anonymous reporter."
###Chapter 475

Evelyn gasped. "That can't be true!"

How could Danielle have betrayed her like this?

When Danielle realized her actions had been exposed, she panicked. "Evelyn, I swear I didn't report you. I'm being framed!"

Evelyn studied Danielle's face, searching for truth. "Maybe there's been some mistake?"

"It must be a mistake!" Danielle insisted quickly.

Evelyn refused to believe her friend would anonymously report her. They'd never had any issues before - what possible motive could Danielle have?

Nathaniel's piercing gaze intensified. "Are you doubting my investigation?"

Evelyn stiffened. Pressing her lips together, she ventured, "Perhaps someone set Danielle up?"

Tears welled in Danielle's eyes. "Exactly! I would never do this to you, Evelyn."

Theodore stepped forward at Nathaniel's signal. "The evidence doesn't lie." He unlocked his phone with a grim expression. "Danielle, these screenshots trace the report directly to your IP address. Explain this."

Evelyn's stomach dropped as she saw the damning proof on Theodore's screen. She turned to Danielle, hurt flashing in her eyes. "Why would you do this?"

Danielle clutched Evelyn's hands desperately. "Those must be fake! I swear it wasn't me! Think about it - what reason would I have?"

Evelyn's mind reeled. She desperately wanted to believe her friend, yet Nathaniel had no reason to fabricate evidence against Danielle. Though she resented his methods, she couldn't deny his thoroughness.

Only one conclusion remained.

Evelyn squeezed Danielle's hand gently. "I believe you. Someone must have framed you."

"Yes! Exactly!" Danielle nodded frantically. "Someone's trying to destroy our friendship!"

"Then let's go to the authorities," Evelyn declared. "We'll get to the bottom of this together."

But when Evelyn tried to lead Danielle toward the door, her friend suddenly resisted.

"What's wrong?" Evelyn asked.

With a shuddering breath, Danielle collapsed to her knees. "I'm so sorry... It was me. My jealousy... it made me do this terrible thing."

Evelyn inhaled sharply. The confession hit like a physical blow. She stared down at her weeping friend. "I never wronged you. Was pure envy enough to make you betray me?"

"I was stupid," Danielle sobbed. "We both came from nothing, but I couldn't stand watching you rise above me - especially with men like Nathaniel noticing you. The jealousy ate me alive. Please forgive me. You're my only real friend here."

Evelyn withdrew her hand as if burned. "Now I understand why you have no other friends at university. No one trusts a snake."

Without another word, she strode from the office.

Nathaniel exchanged a meaningful look with Theodore. "You'll handle this?"

"Of course, Mr. Whitmore," Theodore nodded. "University discipline procedures will be followed precisely."

Wiping her tears, Danielle slowly rose. Despite everything, a strange calm settled over her. Victoria had promised protection, after all. That knowledge alone gave her strength.
###Chapter 476

The moment Evelyn stepped out of the office, she immediately called Danielle.

"Ms. Sinclair, there's a problem at the university. My anonymous report was exposed, and now everyone knows about Evelyn and Mr. Whitmore's marriage. Why wasn't I informed about this earlier?"

Victoria's grip on her phone tightened. Nathaniel had personally gone to the campus to publicly declare his relationship with Evelyn.

Her voice dripped with frustration. "How could you be so careless? Getting caught this quickly is unacceptable."

Worse yet, Nathaniel's public declaration had only strengthened Evelyn's position.

Danielle was proving to be even more incompetent than Penelope.

"Ms. Sinclair, what am I supposed to do now? The university will definitely take action against me. You promised you'd protect me, didn't you?"

Victoria scoffed. "Relax, it's not that serious. Just sit tight and wait for further instructions."

With that, she hung up and turned to Gregory. "When does Alexander arrive in Bern City?"

"His flight lands tomorrow."

"Arrange a meeting. I'll handle the pickup myself."

Gregory hesitated. "Should we warn Danielle first? We don’t want her slipping up."

Victoria smirked. "No need. She’s too self-absorbed to suspect anything. Remember how easily she volunteered to impersonate Evelyn when I mentioned needing a childhood friend?"

As long as Danielle played her part, Victoria’s position remained secure.

Meanwhile, Evelyn walked along a quiet path on campus, her thoughts in turmoil.

She had suspected Penelope or Victoria might be involved, but Danielle’s betrayal had blindsided her.

The realization stung.

Just then, two unfamiliar men appeared beside her. They didn’t look like students.

Spotting her alone, they smirked and approached.

"Hey, you look upset," one said.

"Yeah, why don’t you come with us? We’ll cheer you up," the other added.

Evelyn’s instincts screamed danger. She tried to leave, but they blocked her path.

"Let me go!" she demanded, raising her voice. "This is a university. If you don’t back off, security will be here in seconds!"

One of them laughed. "Feisty, aren’t you?" He reached out to grab her.

Suddenly, a deep voice cut through the air. "Touch her, and you’ll regret it."

Evelyn turned toward the voice. A tall figure emerged from the shadows, his sharp gaze unmistakable.

Nathaniel.

Her heart leaped. "Sweetheart!"

The men froze at the term of endearment. Causing trouble on campus was one thing, but tangling with someone’s husband?

They exchanged a glance and bolted.

Evelyn rushed into Nathaniel’s arms, trembling. "I was so scared."

Regret flooded her. If something had happened, her unborn babies could have been in danger.

Nathaniel held her close, his hand gently stroking her back. "I’ve got you."

Tears pricked her eyes. "Why did you follow me?"
###Chapter 477

Evelyn had nearly given up hope when Nathaniel appeared out of nowhere, stepping between her and the two strangers who had cornered her.

Her heart pounded wildly in her chest.

With a tight voice, Nathaniel admitted, "If something had happened to you, I wouldn’t have known how to face Grandmother."

Evelyn lowered her lashes, hiding the storm of emotions behind them.

She forced a small smile. "Thank you for stepping in."

"Well, I couldn’t just ignore being called ‘sweetheart’ like that," he muttered dryly.

Silence stretched between them.

As they walked out of the secluded grove, Evelyn spotted a security vehicle nearby.

Two men were being shoved inside—bruised, limping, their earlier arrogance completely shattered.

If not for their clothes, she might not have recognized them.

She glanced at Nathaniel. "They look terrible. Did you do this?"

His expression remained icy. "They deserved worse."

A small, satisfied warmth curled in Evelyn’s chest as she watched them struggle.

Who wouldn’t appreciate someone defending them like this?

Then, her phone buzzed.

Julian’s name flashed across the screen.

She hesitated, stealing another glance at Nathaniel.

His jaw tightened when he saw the caller ID. "Go ahead. Answer it."

Stepping away, she lifted the phone to her ear. "Hello?"

"Evelyn, are you still on campus? I just finished work. I can pick you up."

"It’s fine. I’m already in the car. I’ll head back myself."

"Alright. Don’t forget your prenatal check-up tomorrow. For the next one, we can schedule it in Nord City. No need to hide it there."

After confirming, she hung up, his words lingering in her mind.

Yes. She was leaving Bern City soon.

When she turned back, Nathaniel’s voice was firm. "Get in the car. I’ll drive you home."

She nodded after a pause.

But Nathaniel didn’t move. His gaze pinned her in place.

Once inside the car, he finally asked, "Why did you lie? You weren’t in a car. Why refuse Julian’s offer?"

"Because I needed to talk to you."

Her almond-shaped eyes met his, clear and unwavering.

Nathaniel’s breath caught. "So. Have you made your decision?"

"Yes."

His pulse spiked.

Given her past deceptions, he had assumed he knew what she’d choose.

Clearing his throat, he said, "I trust you’ll make the right choice."

Evelyn inhaled deeply. "I’ve decided to leave. I’m moving to Nord City."

Nathaniel’s fingers twitched. Disbelief flickered in his eyes.

The air in the car turned suffocating.

His voice was dangerously soft when he finally spoke. "What does Julian have that I don’t?"

Evelyn looked away, afraid he’d see the truth in her eyes.

Swallowing hard, she whispered, "I’m having the twins in Nord City. They deserve a stable home. I won’t let them grow up in a broken family."

She knew Nathaniel despised children.

And she would never tell him the twins were his.
###Chapter 478

The wind howled outside as Evelyn gripped the edge of her seat. Nathaniel's refusal to finalize their divorce clearly stemmed from Eleanor's influence. A bitter realization settled in her chest—he didn’t truly care about her.

Beatrice’s disdain for Evelyn was no secret. If she couldn’t stand Evelyn, how would she ever accept their unborn children?

The thought of raising them in such a toxic environment made Evelyn’s stomach twist.

Nathaniel adjusted his cufflinks, rolling down the window. The cold air rushed in, biting at his skin.

He hadn’t expected to lose.

Not like this.

Not to Julian.

Evelyn stole a glance at Nathaniel. The shifting shadows masked his expression, but the tension in his jaw was unmistakable.

He had always been the one to walk away first.

After a heavy silence, Nathaniel’s voice cut through the air like ice. "Since you’ve made your choice, you can explain it to Grandma yourself."

Evelyn swallowed hard. "I will."

Nathaniel ripped off his tie, frustration boiling over. "And how exactly do you plan to break it to her? If she falls ill because of this—if she’s hurt—I won’t forgive you. You know how much she loves you. Is this how you repay her?"

Tears pricked Evelyn’s eyes. "I’ll handle it."

"How?"

The easiest solution would be to keep Eleanor in the dark. To pretend nothing had changed.

Yet, for reasons even Evelyn couldn’t fully explain, she was still choosing Julian.

Nathaniel’s expression remained unreadable.

But his gaze flickered to her, sharp and assessing, before he looked away again.

The rest of the ride passed in suffocating silence. When the car finally stopped outside her apartment complex, Evelyn barely registered it.

She reached for the door handle.

"Evelyn."

She turned. "What?"

Nathaniel’s voice was low, dangerous. "I hope you won’t regret this."

Her hand instinctively cradled her stomach. For her babies, she would never regret it.

She met his gaze. "Once I explain everything to Eleanor… will you finally sign the papers?"

Nathaniel’s jaw clenched. "Of course. If it weren’t for her, do you think I’d still be here?"

"Right."

The words stung more than she expected.

She stepped out of the car without another word.

Behind her, Nathaniel kicked the back of Frederick’s seat. "Drive."

When Evelyn walked into the apartment, Julian, Christopher, and Andrew were already there. She forced a smile. "Didn’t expect to see you all today."

"Alexander arrives the day after tomorrow," Julian said. "We’ll all go back to Nord City together."

Evelyn nodded, turning to Margaret. "Don’t worry. We’ll take Benjamin with us."

Margaret hesitated. "I told my mother, Edna, where we’re staying. She hasn’t been well… she needs to see a doctor."

"She can stay here," Margaret offered. "It’s better than a hotel."

Evelyn bit her tongue. After everything Edna had done, she hoped Margaret wouldn’t be too lenient.

But knowing they might never return to Bern City, she let it go.

The next day, Julian accompanied Evelyn to her prenatal appointment.

When the ultrasound revealed the two tiny heartbeats, a fragile smile touched her lips.

As long as her children were safe, she could bear the misunderstandings.

After the appointment, Evelyn headed straight to the university library to study.

But as she turned a corner, she nearly collided with Sophia.

"Sophia? What are you doing here? Don’t you have work?"

Sophia grabbed her arm, her voice urgent. "We need to talk. You have to be careful—Danielle is planning something."
###Chapter 479

Evelyn paused for a brief moment. The truth had already been revealed to her the previous night—Danielle was the mastermind behind it all.

With a hint of sorrow in her voice, she confessed, "I know Danielle was the one who made the anonymous report."

Sophia nodded. "Then why am I even telling you this? It was actually one of our classmates who tipped me off."

"She saw Danielle getting cozy with a wealthy socialite and suddenly flaunting designer bags and high-end makeup in the dorm."

"A socialite?" Evelyn's brows furrowed.

Her thoughts immediately went to Victoria. She knew Danielle wouldn’t act without a motive.

Sophia pulled out her phone. "I even found photos for proof. It’s definitely her—Victoria Sinclair, the woman trying to steal your husband."

Evelyn’s breath hitched. "Yes, that’s Victoria."

She recognized Victoria instantly in the images.

Yet, throughout this time, Evelyn hadn’t noticed anything amiss. Danielle had always played the role of a loyal friend in front of her.

"Sophia, thank you for telling me."

"Evelyn, you never know what schemes these rich people are plotting. Be careful."

"Once your exams are over, I suggest you leave Bern City immediately. That woman won’t be able to touch you once you’re gone."

Evelyn smiled warmly and hugged her friend. "I’m so lucky to have you watching my back. Once I’m settled in Nord City, you have to come visit."

Since Sophia had to return to work, their conversation was brief, and they soon parted ways.

Not long after, Theodore summoned Evelyn to his office to discuss the previous day’s incident. But Danielle was nowhere to be found.

Danielle’s advisor explained, "I haven’t been able to reach her. Apparently, she didn’t return to her dorm last night."

"Danielle has always been a bit of a loner, detached from reality. She often believes she’s being ostracized because she’s an orphan."

"In truth, everyone’s just busy with graduation season and doesn’t have time to pay her much attention."

Hearing this, Evelyn realized just how isolated Danielle truly was.

She couldn’t help but scold herself for letting her emotions cloud her judgment. Their shared background as orphans had made her sympathetic.

At first, she had believed Danielle’s claims of being mistreated. But now, it was clear Danielle had been manipulating her all along.

Glancing at the clock, Evelyn sighed. "Forget it. Let the university handle this matter. I need to get back to studying."

With Danielle being used as a pawn by Victoria, Evelyn felt no need to extend any further sympathy.

Meanwhile, Victoria waited eagerly at the airport for Nathaniel’s arrival. Today was crucial for her plans.

If she could successfully manipulate Danielle into discrediting Evelyn as the Montgomery heiress, everything would fall perfectly into place.

Soon, a group emerged from the VIP corridor.

Alexander and Olivia led the way, followed closely by Sebastian and Daniel, the latter disguised in a hat and mask.

Victoria greeted them with a practiced smile. "Alexander, Sebastian, Daniel."

Daniel scoffed. "Don’t address me like that. You were never officially part of our family. Now that we’ve found our real sister, maybe it’s time for you to start packing."

His harsh words made Victoria’s eyes flicker with suppressed anger.

"I’ve always known my place as a foster daughter. I never once thought of replacing the true Montgomery heiress."

"I’m grateful for everything you’ve given me, which is why I’ve spent years searching for her. Every lead I’ve found, I’ve brought to you immediately."

Daniel smirked. "Who’s to say you didn’t plant someone to deceive us?"

Victoria’s gaze darkened briefly before she turned to Alexander. "How could you even suggest something so vile? Alexander, you believe me, don’t you?"
###Chapter 480

Alexander maintained his composure as he studied Victoria's face. "Where is this so-called 'heiress' you claim to have found?"

"She's at my place. I can take you there immediately," Victoria answered with forced enthusiasm.

Yet beneath her eager tone, a flicker of unease crossed her features as she guided Alexander and the others through the airport terminal.

Soon, their group split up, each heading toward separate waiting vehicles.

Olivia shot Alexander a concerned glance. "I don't trust Victoria's intentions," she murmured.

"Whatever game she's playing, we'll discover the truth soon enough," Alexander stated firmly.

"It's unfortunate Evelyn lost most of her childhood memories. Otherwise she might recall how Victoria interfered with our search for her," Olivia added.

Alexander's jaw tightened. Bringing Victoria back from the orphanage remained his greatest regret.

Within minutes, they arrived at Victoria's luxurious penthouse.

Gregory rushed forward in panic. "Ms. Sinclair, Danielle has disappeared!"

Victoria's face drained of color. "What do you mean? Turn this place upside down!"

"We've searched everywhere. She's gone."

Victoria checked her phone and found a WhatsApp message from Danielle: "Ms. Sinclair, if you want my cooperation, fix my university expulsion first. I can't afford this stain on my record."

With trembling fingers, Victoria dialed Danielle's number repeatedly, but only got endless ringing.

As Alexander's group exited their vehicle, his voice cut through the tension. "Where is she?"

Victoria forced a smile. "Alexander, Danielle just needs time to process everything. I'll find her soon," she lied smoothly.

Alexander's patience snapped.

He tossed a document at Victoria. "This terminates our arrangement. Whether you sign or not, your citizenship transfers to Bern City effective immediately."

Victoria gasped, scrambling after him. "Alexander! Just because you found your real sister, you're throwing me away? I helped find her!"

Olivia blocked Victoria's path. "We'll handle the search from here," she stated with finality.

Watching Alexander's car disappear, Victoria turned to Gregory. "We must find Danielle first, or they'll learn everything about Evelyn!"

Victoria couldn't allow Evelyn to reclaim her rightful place in the Montgomery family.

That evening, Evelyn returned home to find all six brothers crowded in her modest living room.

The small space felt even more cramped with their imposing presence.

Evelyn blinked in surprise. "Your flight wasn't until tomorrow?"

Alexander smiled warmly. "Finished my work early. Wanted to surprise you."

Their original plan had been to confront Victoria that afternoon, but discovering her imposter missing made further pretense pointless.

Olivia took Evelyn's hand gently. "We heard about your graduation banquet. The whole family will be there to celebrate."

Daniel rested his chin on his hand with a playful grin. "Why didn't you tell us about this important event sooner?"

Evelyn's voice softened with emotion. "I thought you were all busy, and the flight from Nord City is so long..."

Still, what daughter wouldn't want her family present for such a milestone?

It reminded her of childhood dreams of parents attending school events.

Olivia squeezed Evelyn's hand. "This time, we're personally escorting you back to Nord City. We have a special gift planned for the banquet."

At the event, they would reveal Evelyn's true identity as the long-lost Montgomery heiress!
###Chapter 481

Evelyn's eyes sparkled with intrigue. "What kind of gift is this? Can't you give me just a little clue?"

Nathaniel shook his head firmly. "Telling you now would ruin everything. At minimum, before you depart Bern City, we want this chapter of your life to have the perfect ending," he explained.

The Montgomery brothers exchanged knowing glances.

Julian, Christopher, and Andrew's eyes gleamed with shared understanding. Alexander had already questioned Evelyn about her relationship with Nathaniel when he arrived earlier that day - some secrets could no longer stay hidden.

Julian had reluctantly disclosed Evelyn's secret three-year marriage to Nathaniel, but had kept her pregnancy confidential. As her doctor, he took his professional oath seriously.

After lengthy discussion, they'd unanimously decided to reveal Evelyn's true identity as the Montgomery heiress at the upcoming graduation banquet.

Alexander's voice carried steel resolve. "Evelyn, I swear we'll make right every injustice you've suffered." His hands clenched at the thought of Nathaniel's treatment of her.

Evelyn noticed her brothers' odd behavior but couldn't quite decipher its meaning.

As university graduation approached, rumors swirled about special guests attending the banquet and plans for a charity auction.

The next afternoon, Olivia took Evelyn shopping at Bern City's most exclusive boutique.

"Now that your brothers' businesses are flourishing, buy whatever your heart desires," Olivia insisted, pressing a black VIP card into Evelyn's palm. "With this, you'll never need appointments or waitlists here again."

Evelyn gratefully accepted the card, selecting an emerald gown from the rack. "Olivia, this would look divine on you. You must try it!"

Unable to resist, Olivia disappeared into the dressing room with the dress.

Meanwhile, Evelyn slipped into a sapphire cocktail dress, studying her reflection critically. While stunning, the fitted silhouette slightly accentuated her baby bump. These days, she preferred looser cuts.

"Well, well. Evelyn Carter in this store? Can trailer trash even afford the hangers here?" Penelope Whitmore's shrill voice cut through the air as she entered with Beatrice Harrington.

Beatrice's expression turned glacial. "This establishment is for ladies of breeding, Evelyn. Just as our family isn't for common gold-diggers." She sniffed disdainfully. "Even if you temporarily acquire nice things, they'll never truly be yours."

Evelyn crossed her arms defiantly. "Who says I can't afford it?" She handed the black card to the sales associate. "Please wrap this up."

Penelope's jaw dropped. "Is that...a VIP membership card? How did you get that? Did you steal it?"

Beatrice's face purpled with outrage. "She must have! Even I couldn't obtain that card!"

Penelope nodded vigorously. "Exactly! Aunt Beatrice, even you were denied this privilege!"

The barb struck home. Beatrice had coveted the exclusive card for years, but Eleanor Whitmore had vetoed the "extravagance." Yet here was Evelyn, casually wielding one!

Beatrice turned to the sales associate imperiously. "This pauper couldn't possibly own that card legally. You'd better verify her identity before getting implicated in fraud."

Evelyn hadn't realized the card's significance until now.

Penelope tittered maliciously. "Honestly Evelyn, do you even understand what you're holding? This requires annual spending over one million dollars and celebrity references for approval. People who carry this aren't just wealthy - they're elite. You've really stepped in it now!"
###Chapter 482

The boutique air crackled with tension as Chelsea Kent, the impeccably dressed store manager, glided toward Evelyn Carter and Beatrice Harrington. "Ms. Whitmore and Mrs. Whitmore, how may I assist you today?"

Penelope Whitmore's shrill voice cut through the perfumed air. "We've got a thief here! Shouldn't you verify stolen property?" Her manicured finger jabbed toward the VIP card in Evelyn's hand.

Chelsea's perfectly arched eyebrows lifted as she examined the platinum card. "Miss Carter, is this membership yours?"

Evelyn shook her head calmly. "It's not mine."

Penelope's triumphant cackle echoed off the marble floors. "See? She doesn't even know where she got it! Probably picked someone's pocket!"

Beatrice's lips curled into a cruel smirk. "Evelyn, darling, a street rat will always be a street rat. No amount of pretending can change that."

The fitting room door burst open with enough force to rattle the mirrors. Olivia Montgomery stormed out, her designer heels clicking like gunshots. "Who the hell do you think you're calling a street rat?"

Recognition flashed across Olivia's face as she took in Nathaniel Whitmore's mother and cousin. Years of suppressed rage bubbled to the surface. While Evelyn's brothers might play diplomat, Olivia had no such restraint.

She jabbed a finger at Beatrice's surgically-tightened face. "You wrinkled old bat! At your age, you should know better than to bully young women. Where'd your manners go - get botoxed out with your wrinkles?"

Beatrice's face turned an alarming shade of crimson. "How dare you! Do you know who I am?"

Olivia rolled up her sleeves. "I know exactly who you are - Nathaniel's nasty mother who made Evelyn's life hell. And I might just show you what happens to bullies."

Evelyn quickly stepped between them. "Olivia, please. We're in public." Her calm voice contrasted sharply with the electric tension.

Olivia snorted. "Public? These vipers don't deserve civilized treatment!"

Beatrice's diamond rings flashed as she gestured dismissively. "Oh look, the gutter rat found herself a matching friend. How... predictable."

Penelope seized the moment, snapping at Chelsea. "Call security! These thieves need to be arrested for fraud!"

Olivia burst into laughter. "Fraud? Over a shopping card? Did you time-travel here from the Victorian era?"

Chelsea hesitated, her gaze darting between the wealthy Whitmores and the unfamiliar but fierce Olivia. With a nervous gulp, she reached for the store phone. "I... I should contact the card's owner."

The moment Chelsea dialed, a phone erupted in ringing from the VIP lounge. Every head swiveled toward the sound.

Penelope gasped. "The owner's here?" The blood drained from her face as the implications sank in.
###Chapter 483

Evelyn Carter stepped back, her eyes widening in shock as she recognized the phone in question belonged to Olivia Montgomery.

So, Olivia was the VIP cardholder?

But according to Penelope Whitmore’s earlier explanation, obtaining such an exclusive membership required not just a million-dollar annual expenditure, but also proof of elite social standing. It wasn’t something just anyone could acquire.

Was Olivia’s family truly that wealthy?

Penelope smirked, her voice dripping with sarcasm. "Evelyn, did you two steal someone’s card? Now that you’ve been caught, what’s your excuse going to be?"

Beatrice Harrington glanced at the buzzing phone on the sofa before turning to the sales associate. "Is the owner of this phone in the fitting room, perhaps?"

Just then, Olivia strolled over, casually picking up the phone with a flick of her wrist.

"Sorry, but this is mine," she said coolly.

Penelope’s face twisted in disbelief. "That’s impossible. Just because the real owner isn’t here doesn’t mean you can claim their belongings!"

Since when did Evelyn have connections to people like this?

Beatrice fixed the sales associate with a sharp glare. "Answer me. Where is the actual owner of this phone? Bring her out now! Someone’s trying to steal her VIP card and phone."

The sales associate, visibly flustered, stammered, "Ms. Harrington, this phone does belong to Ms. Montgomery. I verified their details when they entered the store."

Beatrice’s expression shifted instantly as she rushed to Olivia, holding out the VIP card with both hands.

"My deepest apologies for the misunderstanding. This was entirely our mistake, and we sincerely regret any inconvenience caused."

Evelyn could only stare, struggling to process the sudden turn of events.

Then Olivia extended the card toward her. "Evelyn, take it."

Evelyn hesitated, eyeing the gleaming card. "This is too valuable. I can’t accept it."

"It’s a gift. Just take it," Olivia insisted, her voice firm. "Especially with so many judgmental people around."

Beatrice’s face flushed with humiliation. "Who do you think you’re insulting?"

Seething with jealousy, Penelope couldn’t resist a snide remark. "What’s the point of taking the card? You still can’t afford anything here."

Olivia arched a brow. "Not a problem. This card has a seven-figure spending limit. Evelyn can use it however she likes."

Beatrice narrowed her eyes. "Who exactly are you? And why are you being so generous to Evelyn?"

Penelope sneered, fueling the fire. "Evelyn’s nothing but a gold-digging fraud. She schemed her way into marrying Nathaniel, and when she realized she wouldn’t get a dime, she started talking about divorce and chasing other men. Watch out—she might set her sights on your husband next."

Evelyn’s expression darkened. She hadn’t expected Penelope to publicly expose her three-year marriage to Nathaniel.

Her voice turned icy. "If I were truly a gold digger, I’d have taken control of the Whitmore Group by now, and all of you would’ve been kicked out of the family estate."

Beatrice scoffed. "Oh, Evelyn, I knew you’d say that. That’s exactly why I made you sign a prenup. If you and Nathaniel divorce, you won’t get a single cent!"

Evelyn smirked. "Seems you’re not up to date. Nathaniel tore up the prenup right in front of me."

"What? That’s impossible!" Beatrice paled. The prenup had been their only leverage against Evelyn.

Evelyn pressed on. "And let’s not forget—before Eleanor Whitmore’s surgery, she made Nathaniel sign an agreement ensuring that any child I bear inherits the Whitmore Group."

Penelope’s eyes darted to Evelyn’s stomach, realization dawning. She was pregnant.

Though she didn’t know why Evelyn had kept it hidden, Penelope couldn’t shake the feeling that Evelyn was playing a much deeper game.
###Chapter 484

Olivia Montgomery clenched her fists, biting back the words that threatened to spill about Evelyn Carter's pregnancy.

If Beatrice Harrington discovered Evelyn was carrying Nathaniel's child, it could shatter Olivia's carefully constructed future with the Whitmore dynasty.

Beatrice trembled with barely contained fury. "Evelyn, your true nature finally reveals itself. Let me be perfectly clear - with your common upbringing, you'll never be worthy of my Nathaniel."

"Precisely! The divide between your worlds is insurmountable!" Penelope Whitmore added venomously.

Olivia rose to Evelyn's defense with a derisive laugh. "You can't even produce a VIP card, yet you dare pretend to be elite? Your arrogance is astounding! Evelyn wouldn't give your family a second thought!"

Beatrice lifted her chin haughtily. "How amusing. My son happens to be CEO of Whitmore Enterprises!"

"Is that supposed to impress anyone? You can't even secure basic membership privileges!" Olivia turned to the boutique manager. "According to store policy, VIP members can request removal of disruptive guests, correct?"

The manager nodded. "That is correct, Ms. Montgomery."

"Excellent. Then please escort these two unpleasant women out immediately. Their presence is ruining my shopping experience."

Beatrice's face flushed crimson. "How dare you! My son owns half this mall! No one in Crestwood City treats me this way!"

Olivia's smile turned icy. "Then today will be your first lesson in humility. No card means no privileges. Time to leave."

The manager wrung her hands nervously. "Mrs. Whitmore, you know our policies. As a VIP member, Ms. Montgomery has every right..."

Humiliation burned through Beatrice as she glared at Evelyn. "Pathetic, using wealthy connections to elevate yourself."

Olivia stepped between them. "Are you blind? Evelyn is my sister!"

Penelope's mouth fell open. "Impossible! Evelyn's an orphan - everyone knows this!"

"Our family nanny's negligence caused Evelyn's disappearance years ago," Olivia explained coldly. "She endured your petty snobbery alone all this time. Frankly, I'm astonished at your audacity!"

Slamming her black titanium membership card on the counter, Olivia declared, "Let this be your warning. Evelyn is a Montgomery. Harass her again, and we'll bury you."

Beatrice stood frozen, struggling to process that the "orphan" she'd scorned was actually Montgomery royalty.

When security approached, Beatrice hissed, "This insignificant boutique means nothing! My son owns this entire complex!" She stormed out, pride in tatters.

Penelope followed, mind racing. "Could Evelyn's family truly be that powerful? Why haven't we heard of them before?"

Beatrice scoffed. "New money, undoubtedly. Probably mining or oil fortunes. But no upstart fortune compares to the Sinclair dynasty in Northridge!"

Indeed, the Whitmores of Crestwood and Sinclairs of Northridge dominated high society.

Penelope nodded eagerly. "When Nathaniel marries Victoria Sinclair, our family will be untouchable."

"Enough chatter," Beatrice snapped, pulling out her phone. "I'm calling Nathaniel immediately to have those women banned permanently."
###Chapter 485

The longer Beatrice Harrington thought about it, the more furious she became.

As the esteemed matriarch of the Whitmore family, she was accustomed to nothing less than reverence and deference in Bern City.

Never in her life had she suffered such humiliation!

If Eleanor Whitmore hadn’t deemed the VIP membership card too excessive and wasteful, Beatrice would have undoubtedly owned one herself.

Then she wouldn’t have had to endure this disgrace at the hands of Evelyn Carter today!

Penelope Whitmore nodded eagerly, her voice sharp with indignation. "Aunt Beatrice, you must make Nathaniel understand—this mall belongs to our family. It’s absolutely outrageous that some insignificant boutique dared to throw you out!"

"They clearly don’t know their place. Nathaniel should shut that store down immediately and expel them—along with Evelyn!"

Penelope seethed, finding Evelyn’s arrogance unbearable.

Beatrice shared the sentiment. How dare Evelyn, a mere servant once cast out by their family, behave so boldly toward her? Without hesitation, she dialed Nathaniel’s number.

Meanwhile, Nathaniel had just finished a meeting and answered, his tone calm. "Mother."

"Nathaniel, I need to speak with you about something infuriating!"

Beatrice’s voice trembled with barely suppressed rage, her words dripping with wounded pride.

Nathaniel’s response was cool. "Who in Bern City would dare cross you?"

In Bern City, Beatrice’s name commanded respect. People fell over themselves to please her.

"Who else but Evelyn would have the audacity?"

At the mention of Evelyn, Nathaniel’s interest sharpened. "Where did you see Evelyn?"

"At Centura Mall. Nathaniel, you’re a major shareholder there. Call the manager and have that store shut down immediately. They shouldn’t be allowed to operate another day."

Nathaniel’s brow lifted slightly. "Why?"

"It’s all because of Evelyn! She had the nerve to have the staff kick Penelope and me out—just because she had some VIP membership!"

Beatrice’s voice rose in outrage. "As the mother of the Whitmore Group’s CEO, I’ve never been treated this way before. Nathaniel, Evelyn’s arrogance is intolerable. You must correct this!"

Nathaniel frowned. "She has a VIP membership there? That’s not easily obtained."

Given Evelyn’s current circumstances, it was unlikely she could have secured one herself.

Unless it came from Julian Montgomery?

Beatrice scoffed. "Exactly! But Evelyn had some woman with her, claiming to be her sister—and it was that woman who provided the membership."

Her tone turned suspicious. "But Evelyn is supposed to be an orphan, isn’t she? Where did this wealthy, influential ‘sister’ come from?"

"Her sister?"

Nathaniel’s mind raced with questions. Had Evelyn truly found her family?

Yet she hadn’t mentioned a word of it to him.

After a pause, he asked carefully, "Mother, is there anything else you noticed?"

"I—I don’t know much else. But I suspect Evelyn’s so-called sister might be involved in something shady."

Beatrice’s voice dripped with disdain. "She doesn’t seem like the type to legitimately own such a card. Maybe she stole it or works as a servant in some wealthy household!"

Penelope hesitated before adding softly, "But the name and number on the card matched hers. It was verified."

After all, a stolen card wouldn’t have matching details.

Beatrice shot her a glare before snapping, "Nathaniel, I’ve told you everything. Call the mall manager now and have Evelyn removed! I refuse to tolerate this humiliation any longer."

Nathaniel was genuinely stunned by the revelation of Evelyn’s possible family ties.

Something wasn’t adding up.
###Chapter 486

To Nathaniel's astonishment, Evelyn's family turned out to be the legitimate holders of the platinum membership card.

According to Penelope, Evelyn's sister owned the exclusive card, completely ruling out any chance of it being misplaced or taken unlawfully.

Clearly, the Carter family possessed considerable wealth!

No wonder Evelyn carried herself with such newfound confidence. Finding her biological family must have been an extraordinary occasion. Yet why would she choose to conceal this? Eleanor would surely rejoice at the news.

"Nathaniel, are you even listening? I'm telling you to have Evelyn removed from the premises immediately!"

Nathaniel felt a pang of exclusion, realizing he'd been deliberately kept unaware of Evelyn's family background.

Massaging his temples, he countered, "Mother, everyone knows the established policies regarding our premium membership privileges."

"When you cleared the mall last month, did you ever consider the silver-tier members?"

Beatrice faltered momentarily. "That's not a valid comparison, Nathaniel."

"Why shouldn't it be? The Whitmore Group's investment comes with strict operational guidelines. If we start bending rules arbitrarily, what credibility would remain?"

"If today's incident becomes public knowledge, it could severely damage the mall's reputation. Do you grasp the potential consequences?"

"But we're discussing Evelyn here! How can you treat her like some random shopper?" Beatrice snapped back.

Nathaniel's voice turned steely. "She possesses a platinum card, which automatically grants her VIP privileges!"

Beatrice's temper flared instantly. "Nathaniel! That wretched girl humiliated us, yet you're defending her because of some corporate policy!"

"Mother, it appears you're seeking retribution because you were denied access as a standard member. Now you expect me to abuse my position for personal vengeance."

"As CEO of Whitmore Group, I cannot authorize such actions. If I were to—"

"You're my son! Is supporting your own mother truly so difficult?"

Nathaniel replied coolly, "I can mediate this situation, but you'll need to justify your actions to the board yourself."

The line went dead as Beatrice slammed down her receiver.

Penelope inquired cautiously, "What happened? Did Nathaniel agree?"

"Agree? That boy's completely bewitched by that Carter girl!"

Though furious, Beatrice hesitated to involve Nathaniel further. Facing the board's inevitable censure would tarnish her standing irreparably!

Stamping her designer heels, she commanded, "Let's leave."

Penelope had no choice but to comply, though she secretly coveted a platinum card herself. Imagine having first access to all the exclusive collections!

Meanwhile, Nathaniel stared pensively at his darkened phone screen.

Recalling Beatrice's outburst, he found himself scrolling through Evelyn's Instagram. Her latest post caught his eye: "Graduation calls for a complete wardrobe refresh!"

The accompanying selfie showcased her in a stylish new ensemble, her heart-shaped face glowing under the boutique lighting, wispy tendrils framing her delicate features.

Nathaniel studied the photo momentarily before opening their direct messages.

At the luxury boutique, Evelyn reclined on the plush sofa, examining the platinum card. "Olivia, what exactly makes this membership so special?"

Initially, she'd assumed it was merely an upgraded shopping pass. But after Penelope's dramatic reaction, she realized its true significance.

Apparently, this small piece of metal could command security to remove even Beatrice Harrington from the premises!

Olivia hesitated, uncertain whether she should disclose the full extent of the card's privileges to Evelyn just yet.
###Chapter 487

Evelyn stared at Olivia. The entire situation felt surreal, especially when Olivia casually flashed her exclusive platinum membership card to put the other party in their place.

Olivia was absolutely breathtaking.

She cleared her throat with a dry chuckle. "Your brothers' ventures are thriving spectacularly. The companies meant to go public have already done so. I invested my wedding gift funds into their startups—shouldn't I be reaping the returns now?"

"Is their success really this overwhelming?" Something nagged at Evelyn, but she couldn't pinpoint what.

Olivia hesitated briefly. Just as she was about to speak, Evelyn's phone buzzed.

A text from Nathaniel. Finished shopping?

Her stomach twisted. Beatrice must have tattled to that insufferable man.

"Evelyn, who's messaging you?" Olivia inquired.

"Just a friend," Evelyn replied hastily, slipping her phone away.

The boutique manager approached with a polished smile. "This handbag is from our latest limited collection. It pairs perfectly with your dress. Would you like to see it?"

Olivia's gaze flicked over the bag. "Hmm, this leather is rare. Why wasn’t it presented earlier? Worried I couldn’t cover the cost?"

The manager stiffened. "Not at all. There’s a three-day holding policy before we can display this piece."

Evelyn arched a brow. "Then why show it now?"

"We’d like to compensate for the earlier misunderstanding… Mrs. Whitmore."

"Mrs. Whitmore?" Evelyn’s expression darkened. "Did Nathaniel order this?"

Realizing her blunder, the manager paled and pressed a hand to her mouth.

Olivia gripped Evelyn’s wrist. "We don’t need his charity. Tell Nathaniel Whitmore we buy our own luxuries. The Montgomery name carries its own weight."

Oddly, Olivia didn’t seem shocked. She hadn’t even flinched when the manager slipped up.

Evelyn studied her. "Olivia… you knew about Nathaniel and me?"

"Guess the cat’s out of the bag." Olivia waved the manager off before sighing. "Sweetheart, why hide it? Did you think we’d let the Whitmores intimidate us?"

Evelyn bit her lip. "We’re in Bern City now. That chapter’s closed—no need to drag you into it."

"That’s where you’re wrong." Olivia’s eyes flashed. "Nathaniel clearly hasn’t moved on. Gifting you a six-figure bag? Please."

Evelyn’s voice dropped. "His grandmother’s health is fragile. He’s stalling the divorce to spare her."

Olivia slammed her palm on the sofa. "That coward! Leave it to Andrew. We’ll drain every cent from him."

"I can handle this."

"Handle what?" Olivia cupped Evelyn’s face. "Three years of their cruelty, and you suffered alone. Not anymore. Alexander and I will storm Whitmore Estate and demand answers. That venomous Beatrice will regret crossing you."

###Chapter 488

Nathaniel Whitmore. Again.

Her fingers flew across the keyboard: Because I didn't want it.

A pause.

The idea had merit.
###Chapter 489

Victoria's lip curled. "See something you like?" She fluffed the couture skirts. "Not that you could ever afford it."
###Chapter 499

Evelyn burst into laughter. Victoria's sharp words rolled off her like water on a duck's back.

She strode toward the VIP lounge to double-check the floral arrangements.

Victoria's lips pursed in irritation at being dismissed. She turned to Penelope with narrowed eyes. "Don't you agree with me, Penelope?"

An uncomfortable expression flickered across Penelope's face. She cleared her throat awkwardly. "Ms. Sinclair, there's something you should know about Evelyn..."

"Well? Spit it out."

Penelope hesitated, then blurted, "Could you unfreeze my platinum card first? I'm in desperate need of funds."

Victoria's smile turned icy. "You're becoming quite the financial burden, cousin. Perhaps you should consider getting a job instead of leeching off family like some spoiled socialite."

Beneath her polished exterior, Victoria seethed. If not for Penelope's connection to the Whitmores, she wouldn't tolerate this gold-digging behavior.

Everything was part of her grand scheme to secure the Montgomery fortune.

But Penelope proved utterly useless - her only talent being reckless spending sprees.

With the Sinclair family tightening their purse strings, Victoria couldn't afford to indulge her anymore.

Penelope's cheeks flushed with anger. "How stingy! You're supposed to be my future sister-in-law!"

"Precisely why I'm teaching you financial responsibility," Victoria countered smoothly. "One doesn't mooch off distant relatives, does one?"

Penelope's eyes flashed. "What's that supposed to mean?"

"Consider this tough love, darling." Victoria's tone turned saccharine. "Now, about that secret concerning Evelyn?"

Penelope's expression shuttered. "Oh, I forgot."

No way would she reveal anything after that insulting lecture about money.

Victoria's phone buzzed with a text from her assistant. Her mood instantly brightened. "They've located Danielle. She fled the boutique but should be at the university."

She rose abruptly, smoothing her designer dress. "The gala begins shortly. My brothers will be arriving soon. Do try not to embarrass yourself tonight, Penelope."

Victoria swept out before Penelope could demand more funds, mentally dismissing whatever trivial gossip the girl might possess.

Meanwhile, Penelope stewed in resentment. "I was going to tell her Evelyn bought the same couture gown," she muttered. "But who cares about matching dresses? The real question is who'll look like a knockoff version."

A wicked smile curved her lips. "Now that Evelyn's reunited with her billionaire parents, she might even outshine the Sinclairs..."

The thought pleased her immensely. She went hunting for Evelyn.

"Psst! I've got juicy intel about Victoria," Penelope announced, blocking the doorway.

Evelyn didn't even glance up from adjusting a centerpiece. "Not interested. Move."

Penelope's face twisted in outrage. "You'll regret treating me this way, Evelyn Carter!" She planted herself firmly in the exit. "I've finally seen Victoria for the snake she is. You'd make a far better sister-in-law. Especially now that you're practically royalty yourself."
###Chapter 500

Evelyn's brows furrowed. "What exactly are you insinuating?"

Penelope smirked. "If you're so desperate to remain Mrs. Whitmore, fine. I'll back you up—but only under one condition."

Evelyn arched an eyebrow. "Which is?"

Penelope's eyes gleamed with greed. "Simple. Tell Nathaniel to unblock my credit cards. And you’ll give me one of yours—with an unlimited limit."

The sheer audacity left Evelyn momentarily speechless. "Who in their right mind would dare make such a demand? I’m genuinely curious."

Penelope shrugged. "Being part of this family isn’t easy. I could’ve told Victoria about your pregnancy and your real parents, but I kept quiet—for you."

Evelyn crossed her arms. "I thought you and Victoria were close. What changed?"

"Because she’s cheap!" Penelope scoffed. "She wants the Whitmore name without paying what she owes!"

Ah. So that was the reason for Penelope’s sudden betrayal.

Evelyn pretended to consider it. "Give me some time to think it over. I’ll get back to you."

Penelope grinned, triumphant. "Think carefully. With me on your side, you’re practically guaranteed to stay Mrs. Whitmore." She sauntered off, practically skipping.

Evelyn’s lips curled in derision. As if she’d ever agree.

It seemed Penelope hadn’t caught wind of the divorce. Not that it mattered.

Once the ceremony was over and her exams were done, Evelyn would leave Bern City for good.

By then, no one would believe a word Penelope said. Even if they did, Evelyn would be long gone—untouchable.

Her hand drifted to her stomach before she turned her attention to the remaining waiting rooms.

Just as she reached the last one, her phone buzzed. Olivia’s voice chirped through. "Evelyn! Why aren’t you wearing the dress I picked for you today?"

"I had errands. It wasn’t practical."

"That’s unacceptable. I’m bringing it over—with the stylist. Today’s important. You need to look flawless!"

Evelyn sighed. "Fine." No point arguing. Olivia would show up regardless.

Hanging up, she turned—and froze.

At the end of the hallway stood a familiar figure.

Evelyn approached cautiously. "Danielle…?"

The woman lurking in the shadows stepped forward, guilt written across her face. "Evelyn."

They hadn’t spoken since Danielle’s betrayal. The sting had faded with time, but the memory lingered. Evelyn had accepted it—some people couldn’t resist Victoria’s bribes.

Danielle clutched her hands. "Evelyn, I was wrong. Please, help me. Talk to the administration. Stop them from expelling me!"

Evelyn hesitated. "I don’t have that kind of influence."

Danielle’s expression darkened. "So you’re really going to ruin me?"

Evelyn met her gaze evenly. "You made your choices, Danielle. Own them."

She walked away without another word.

Behind her, Danielle’s voice turned icy. "Don’t say I didn’t warn you."
